Be quiet!
What do they represent?
I don't know... but I recognize that junction they're working on. It's the plasma conduit we installed with the new warp core...
"Respond"... respond to them... what does that mean?
What is it you're doing?
Go away. Leave us alone.
Who are you?
We are... your enemies.
Stop. You are hurting my friends and I must --
Be quiet!
Data, the shrieking noise you made -- it causes them pain!
Be... quiet!
I believe I understand.
Geordi, you must adjust my positronic subprocessor to emit an interphasic pulse.
Data, what's going on?

The workmen in my dreams represent the organisms which are trying to demolish the ship. The incessant ringing of the telephone, and Freud's cautions at the other end, were warnings of the dangers around us.
What about the shrieking noise you made?
My positronic subprocessors were detecting high-frequency interphasic signatures from the organisms... which were symbolically represented in my dreams by the high shriek.
When you made those sounds, the workmen reacted in pain...
That is why I have asked Geordi to adjust my subprocessor. If I can produce a high-frequency interphasic pulse, it may have a similar effect on the creatures.
Ready...
Picard to Sickbay. Beverly, we're going to be sweeping the ship with a high-frequency IP pulse. Monitor the creatures for any response.
Understood.
It's working, Captain...
Captain's Log, supplemental The creatures infesting the Enterprise have been completely eliminated. We believe the infestation originated within the warp core we obtained on Starbase Eighty-four.

This conduit was manufactured on Thanatos Seven using a new interphasic fusion process. We think that process must've attracted the organisms to the conduit... where they lay dormant... until we activated the warp core.
That's also why we couldn't get the warp core on-line. The creatures were disrupting the plasma flow.
How long until we have warp power again?
We'll have to manufacture a new conduit. I'd say another six hours.
The banquet is in eight hours... Take your time. Give yourself another twelve hours, if you need it.
Understood, sir.
Ensign Tyler.
Yes, Commander?
There's something I've been meaning to tell you...
Sir?
Thanks. You've been doing a great job. We've got to work on toning down your enthusiasm a little... but I think you're going to fit in just fine.
Thank you, sir.
Enter.
Counselor, I did not get a chance to apologize for my behavior...
Data, don't worry about it. Geordi explained everything. It wasn't your fault. But somehow I felt turnabout would be fair play... so I made us a little something to snack on...
I wonder... what would Freud say about the symbolism of devouring oneself?
Data... sometimes a cake is just a cake.
We are losing containment in the starboard nacelle tube --
Try to get more power to the field coils.
Yes, sir.
Geordi, report.
I can't shut down the plasma injectors -- someone's locked out the controls.
The plasma venting system has engaged.
Two more decks --
Riker to Bridge -- we've almost reached the nacelle tube.
Acknowledged. Release the exterior hull plate. We may have to jettison the core.
What happened?
He locked out the controls... before we knew what was happening, he stepped up onto the walkway.
See if you can shut down the plasma flow.
I'm afraid if we try to get any closer, he'll jump through the forecefield.
Dan...
It's me... Wil Riker.
I was here yesterday, remember?
I didn't... want to do it... but... I saw them... and... they laughed at me... they laughed...
Whatever happened, we can talk about it. I want to help.
Stay away!
I want you to be able to see me, that's all... so we can talk.
I... know... what I have to do...
Dan, wait --
I have unlocked the controls --
Shut down procedure initiated.
There's still plasma in the injector -- it'll take time to vent off...
Tell me what happened. Maybe I can help.
I know what I have to do...
A few more seconds and we could've saved his life...
Commander... you did everything you could. It was not your fault.
I had the strangest feeling that... he didn't even recognize me -- and I was with him just the other day when I supervised the tube refit.
How did he seem then?
Fine. In fact I complimented him for getting the refit done faster than expected. He was pleased that I noticed.
I met with him during crew evaluations about six weeks ago. He was very positive; he was looking forward to being posted to the nacelle tube.
He was a fine officer, with a good career ahead of him. I just don't understand why he would want to...

In my years as a Starship Captain, I've had to notify many families that they'd lost a loved one. But never to suicide. I'd like to be able to offer Lieutenant Kwan's family some explanation for what happened -- to help them make sense of it.
He may have left a message of some kind, explaining why he did it.
I want the two of you to try and piece together a picture of his last few days.
If he made any personal logs, it might be helpful to go through them.
You're authorized to do so.
La Forge to Captain.
Go ahead.
I've completed a damage assessment. We should be able to get underway within the hour.
Geordi, the medical situation on Barson Two has worsened -- Starfleet has given us permission to exceed warp speed limitations so we can get back on schedule.
We'll be able to give you warp eight if you need it.
Acknowledged.
Geordi, would you agree that the instinct for self-preservation is shared by most life forms?
I'd say it's probably the most basic instinct.
That being the case, I am having difficulty understanding why someone would deliberately terminate their own existence.
I don't know, Data. All I can think is that maybe Lieutenant Kwan felt like there was something... wrong in his life, something he felt powerless to fix.
I believe I understand. I have been in a similar situation.
Really?
The first months following my activation were a difficult period for me... there were many problems associated with my becoming sentient.
Because your neural net was still forming.
As I acquired new skills, neural pathways would form and take the place of other, less complex pathways. It was very... disorienting.
Sure sounds like it.

As my systems grew in complexity, it became increasingly difficult to integrate new pathways into my existing neural net. The probability of cascade failure grew with each added pathway. I came to the conclusion that it would be easier and safer to shut myself down and start again.
But if you did that, you wouldn't have remembered any of the things that had happened to you.
In a way, it would have been like... committing suicide.
So what did you do?
I decided against the procedure. I chose instead to treat the problems I was having with my systems as... challenges to be overcome, instead of obstacles to be avoided.
That's a great way of looking at it. It's too bad Lieutenant Kwan wasn't able to look at his problems the same way.
I've gone over Kwan's personnel records -- he had an exceptionally stable psychological profile.
When we were in the control room, it seemed as if he were trying to... explain something he'd done... something terrible.
He'd been on the Enterprise over two years. No one has ever reported an altercation with him.
These were his quarters.
This is a Napean design...
His mother is Napean; his father's human.
Everything looks so... normal. For some reason I was half expecting to find the place a mess.
Yes... it is strange to think that someone could be considering ending his life and yet not give any outward sign of it.
Right before he jumped, he seemed almost... calm.
He must have been in a lot of pain to do what he did. It could be that the prospect of ending that pain felt like a great relief.
This is Ensign... Calloway, isn't it?
She is a medical technician in Sickbay.
It's always hard to lose someone you care about... but to lose them like this...
We should start going over his logs...
This is his last entry; he made it before going on duty this morning.
Personal log, Stardate 47622.1. We finally finished the nacelle tube refit last night. After pulling two double shifts in a row, I'm really looking forward to spending some time with Maddy.
Ensign Calloway...
That doesn't sound like a man planning on ending his life.
No... it does not...
I can't believe he's really gone... I keep thinking he's going to show up and tell me there's been some terrible misunderstanding...
I thought you might like to know that in his personal logs, Dan talked about you a great deal. He loved you very much.
If that's true... then how could he... leave me like this?
That's what I'm trying to find out. I know it's hard to talk about right now... but it would be very helpful if you could tell me a few things about him.
When was the last time you saw him?
Two nights ago... we were planning our next shore leave together.
Did he mention anything that happened recently... anything that might have upset him?
No, not really... he did say something about work, about Lieutenant Nara, but it wasn't anything serious.
Nara... she's his superior officer in the nacelle tube.
Yes. Dan sensed that she... well, that she felt threatened by him -- that she thought he was after her position.
Was he prone to mood swings, or depression?
No... but he was very sensitive to other people's moods.
What do you mean?
Sometimes he would just... look at me, and know what I was feeling -- I always loved that about him.
Napeans are partially empathic -- he may have inherited some of his mother's abilities.
He used to tease me that when I met her, I wouldn't be able to get away with anything.
Dan and I knew each other for over two years, but we didn't really get together until a few months ago. We took it slow...
We thought we had all the time in the world...
Something must've happened to him, Counselor. Something terrible Because it's not like Dan to take his own life. Please... find out what it was.
I'm sorry --
I didn't see you there...
You're Lieutenant Nara, aren't you?
Can I do something for you, Counselor?
I'm investigating Lieutenant Kwan's death. I just wanted to take a look around.
It's such a shame. He was a good man.
Did you notice any change in his behavior recently?
No... I've been going over the last few days in my mind, trying to see if I missed any... warning signs. It's as if something in him just... snapped.
How was his job performance?
Excellent. He knew this ship better than most people -- probably because he helped build it back at Utopia Planitia.
Did he get along with his coworkers?
He was... ambitious. He came in here with all sorts of new ideas about how to do things -- some of them very good ideas.
But not all?
No. But once he settled in, we got along fine.
Excuse me for a minute. Feel free to look around.
Where was Lieutenant Kwan's station?
Right down there.
Are you all right?
I... don't know...
I don't know how to describe it... I was suddenly overwhelmed by a flood of emotions -- fear, rage, panic.
Whose emotions? I thought you said you were alone.
I was. The sensations didn't seem to be coming from any one person -- they were just there, in the room.
I scanned the area -- I picked up no anomalous readings.
How could you be getting an empathic impression from an empty room?
I don't know...
Could the fact that Kwan was partially empathic have something to do with it?
What do you mean?
I'm not sure... but the feelings Troi described certainly seem consistent with suicide.
Could his death have left some sort of... empathic echo?
I suppose it's a possibility... but I don't see how.
If I went back to the nacelle tube, I might be able to get a better sense of what I experienced.
I'm not sure that's a good idea -- you're showing elevated levels of psilosynine.
Psilosynine?
A neuro-transmitter involved in telepathy. The experience overwhelmed you the first time. I don't think you should go back until the levels return to normal.
How long?
Three, maybe four hours.
Next time I want someone with you.
I will accompany you, Counselor.
Captain's Log, Stardate 47623.2. We've arrived at Starbase Three-twenty-eight on schedule. After taking aboard medical supplies, we will depart for Barson Two.
-- I ran into Maddy yesterday. We stood in the corridor and talked for almost an hour... The more I get to know her, the more I realize what a remarkable woman she is...
Come in.
Hello, Worf.
Counselor...
Have you found anything in Lieutenant Kwan's logs?
Everything I've seen indicates he was well-adjusted and optimistic. Were you able to talk with Ensign Trake?
Yes... I interviewed all of Kwan's co-workers.
From what I've read, Trake was his best friend.
He observed nothing that indicated Kwan was contemplating ending his life. Nor did any of the others.
It just doesn't make any sense...
Can I get you anything?
No, thank you.
Yridian tea...
I've been thinking about what happened to me in the nacelle tube... whether it was an empathic echo left by Kwan's death...
In the past, have your empathic experiences always involved the physical presence of another person?
All the ones I'm sure of, yes.
What do you mean, sure of?
Well... when I was a young girl, my Grandfather used to tell me stories by the fire... I would close my eyes and listen to his mind for hours on end...
He told you these stories telepathically... ?
My grandfather rarely spoke out loud... He said that was for off-worlders who didn't know any better.
The only time I can remember his stories is when I go home... and sit by the fireplace. Sometimes when I'm there, alone... it's almost as if I can hear his voice in my head.
Yes... I have sought visions in fire.
I can't explain it, but it felt very real to me. Just like what happened in the nacelle tube.
There are things we do not understand, yet they exist nonetheless.
I keep thinking about Ensign Calloway... she needs to know what happened to Kwan -- it's the only way she'll ever be able to put his death behind her.
This must be a very difficult time for her.
Do you know what she regrets most? That she and Kwan didn't take full advantage of the time they had together... they knew each other for a long time, but they didn't get together until recently.
She wishes they had acted on their feelings sooner... ?
Perhaps I should let you rest.
It's all right --
If you will excuse me, Counselor.
Worf...
Commander...
Two Til'amin froths, please.
Lieutenant Corell seems to be enjoying your company.
I'd like to think so.
Are you... involved with her?
I'm not sure yet.
Why do you ask? Are you interested in her?
No...
But if I were, I would of course discuss the situation with you before proceeding further.
I appreciate the thought, but you really wouldn't have to do that.
I would never want to come between you and anyone you were involved with... or had ever been involved with.
Is there... someone in particular you're talking about?
No. Is there... someone in particular you would prefer I not become involved with?
Worf... you sound like a man asking a friend if he can start dating his sister.
No, I am merely... never mind. Excuse me, sir.
Could you open this door for me?
Yes, but only for a short time. After ninety seconds the plasma venting system will engage to prevent degradation of the forcefield.
I just want to take a quick look...
May I ask what you are looking for?
I'm... not sure...
Warning -- plasma venting system will engage in ninety seconds.
No... please... don't...
Plasma venting system will engage in... eighty seconds.
Worf... ?
Worf, where are you?
Counselor... are you all right --
Get me out of here...
Do you remember anything else?
I saw a tool crate on the floor... it was labeled Utopia Planitia.
The shipyard where the Enterprise was built.
Clearly this was much more than an empathic echo. It seems that you were actually seeing something that happened in the control room eight years ago.
Everyone was looking directly at me. It's almost as if... I were seeing through someone else's eyes.
Lieutenant Kwan was partially empathic...
Maybe you were seeing through his eyes?
It's a possibility... but I don't understand how it could have happened.
Let's put that question aside for a moment and assume that by some unexplained phenomenon, you witnessed an event that may have involved Lieutenant Kwan. The faces you saw -- did you recognize them?

I don't think I've ever seen the woman before, or the man who was with her. But there was someone else there. A man... he was staring at me in the most peculiar way. I think he had... reddish hair. He seemed familiar to me... but it's all so hazy, like trying to remember a dream.
The woman seemed terrified of something... then you saw her again, laughing -- presumably at Lieutenant Kwan.
What could it all mean?
I don't know. But something terrible happened in that room. I felt it.
Counselor... I want you to look over the personnel files from Utopia Planitia and see if you can identify the faces you saw.
If only there were some way I could go back to the control room and not be overwhelmed by the experience -- it might help me remember some detail that could be relevant.
I could give you an inhibitor that would slow your brain's production of psilosynine. That would probably suppress your empathic abilities enough to make the experience manageable.
I'd like to try.
Very well, Counselor.
It'll take about sixteen hours to synthesize the inhibitor.
I apologize for being late. The viral medicines we are transporting to Barson Two require special security measures to insure they are properly contained.
Have you found anything?
No... there were literally thousands of people involved in building the Enterprise.
Perhaps if you found a way to narrow the search parameters.

I think I have. The man who seemed familiar to me may have been on board the Enterprise during the last seven years. I've asked the computer to limit its search to personnel who've served at Utopia Planitia and on the ship.
Ensign Salvatore... he transferred off the Enterprise last year.
Lieutenant Ziff... she's in quantum mechanics.
That's him.
Lieutenant Walter Pierce...
I remember now... he came aboard about six months ago. I think he's in Engineering.
You were Lieutenant Kwan's supervisor at Utopia Planitia.
That's right. I was sorry to hear what happened...
Did you spend time in the nacelle control room while it was under construction?
I worked all over the ship. In fact, I remember running a power conduit right behind that wall there.
Were you ever in the nacelle room at the same time as Lieutenant Kwan?
It was a long time ago... people were working all over the place.
So you do not remember?
I'm sorry, I don't.
Do you recall if anything... unusual happened there?
How do you mean?
An altercation, perhaps. Possibly involving Lieutenant Kwan.
No... nothing like that. The way I remember it, things went pretty smoothly.
What's this all about? If you don't mind my asking.
Not at all. You see, when I went into the nacelle room, I had an... empathic experience.
We believe she may have been seeing some event that occurred there eight years ago.
And -- I saw you there.
Do you have any idea why that might be?
I'm afraid I don't.
Lieutenant... you're probably aware that I can sense whether someone's telling the truth.
I've heard that.
I'm sure, then, that if you were to... remember anything that might be relevant to our investigation, you'd contact me.
Of course.
Thank you, Lieutenant.
Counselor...
The strange thing is I couldn't read him at all.
But you implied that you could...
We have played poker together many times. I have never known you to bluff.
Well... it wouldn't be much of a bluff if you knew, would it?
The fact that I couldn't read him suggests that he has at least some telepathic ability...
But Pierce is human.
That's what I don't understand...
Even though I couldn't read his emotions, it did seem to me that he was... holding something back.
Yes. I thought so as well.
Maybe we should try to access the Engineering Logs from Utopia Planitia. We might find out more about him.
There might be something in them about Lieutenant Kwan, as well.
It looks like it'll take about half an hour for the transmission to be completed.
Perhaps we should continue in the morning... ?
It is late.
Yes, you must be tired.
A little...
Well. I will say good night.
Good night.
We should get an early start tomorrow.
Yes. We should.
See you in the morning...
Yes...
Deanna...
scene: 45   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - THE NEXT MORNING

quote: Hello...
scene: 45   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - THE NEXT MORNING

quote: Breakfast is ready...
scene: 45   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - THE NEXT MORNING

quote: Mmm... that sounds good...
scene: 45   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - THE NEXT MORNING

quote: But it can wait...
scene: 45   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - THE NEXT MORNING

quote: Why didn't we do this a long time ago... ?
scene: 45   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - THE NEXT MORNING

quote: Crusher to Counselor Troi.
scene: 45   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - THE NEXT MORNING

quote: Yes, Doctor.
scene: 45   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - THE NEXT MORNING

quote: I've synthesized the inhibitor; you can come to Sickbay whenever you're ready.
scene: 45   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - THE NEXT MORNING

quote: Acknowledged.
scene: 45   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - THE NEXT MORNING

quote: Crusher to Lieutenant Worf.
scene: 45   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - THE NEXT MORNING

quote: Worf, here.
scene: 45   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - THE NEXT MORNING

quote: The medical supplies are ready to be taken to the cargo bay for transport.
scene: 45   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - THE NEXT MORNING

quote: I will be there shortly.
scene: 45   INT. TROI'S QUARTERS - THE NEXT MORNING

quote: There... you should start feeling the effect immediately.
How completely will it suppress my empathic abilities?
It's hard to say for sure... I can raise the dosage if you find it's not enough.
-- the cargo bay will be off-limits to all but medical personnel.
Thanks for your help, sir.
Good morning.
Counselor...
Data and Geordi are already in the nacelle room. Are you ready?
Excuse me, sir. About the quarantine field in the cargo bay...
Yes.
It looks like we're going to need a second field generator.
I am needed here. I will join you as soon as I can.
All right...
Counselor, you okay?
I'm fine. The inhibitor seems to be working. Have you found anything?
Nothing unusual.
I don't remember seeing this console during my empathic experience. Has it been here since the ship was built?
No, we installed it about two years ago.
I remember seeing some sort of power conduit...
Right there.
The main ODN line runs right behind that panel... it lifts out so you can get to it.
Kwan was working on that conduit the day before he died.
Can you open it?
Sure... it'll just take a minute.
Lieutenant... the work Lieutenant Kwan was doing, was it unusual in any way?
He was refitting a field coil. But it was probably the first time that particular panel's been opened since the ship was built.
Let's set it down right here...
Counselor?
Are you all right?
Something happened... when you took off the panel...
There must be something there...
I am picking up readings that indicate there is organic material imbedded in the wall...
Organic material?
You're right... let me reconfigure the emitter beam. We might be able to see what it is...
There...
This dosage should prevent any further empathic flashes.
The bone fragments are definitely human... I sequenced a DNA sample; I'll see if I can match it to Starfleet records.
I'd say these fragments had been in the wall about seven or eight years.
You said something happened when the panel was opened...
Yes...
I wonder if the fragments themselves could've somehow triggered your experience. I'll run a resonance scan, see if anything turns up.
Sir, I think we've found a match...
Apparently the remains are those of an Ensign Marla Finn --
I'm trying to find a picture of her in the records...
That's her. That's the woman I saw.
She was reported missing from Utopia Planitia on Stardate 40987.2. Eight years ago...
How could her body have ended up embedded inside a bulkhead... ?
Maybe there was some kind of... accident.
Or she was killed. And the murderer hid her remains.
Something's not right... pull up Lieutenant Kwan's service record.
I thought so... he didn't arrive at the shipyard until six months after Finn's death. I couldn't have been seeing through his eyes...
Then whose... ?
It had to have been someone who was at least partially telepathic.
Pierce... ?
But you saw him there.
Yes, but not as clearly as I saw everything else... his face looked...
Like that.
A reflection...
I was seeing through his eyes.
And Finn was trying to get away from him; she was afraid of him...
I think it is time we had another... conversation with Lieutenant Pierce.
Ensign Calloway...
Thank you for your help.
Deck ten.
Worf... I want to ask you something...
Do you regret what happened last night?
No... of course not.
Are you sure? Because I don't want anything to jeopardize our friendship.
Deanna... I do not regret being with you.
Is something wrong?
I just... don't feel myself. Maybe it's the inhibitor -- I'm so used to sensing what people are feeling... now I can't.
Perhaps I should talk to Lieutenant Pierce alone.
That might be a good idea...
I will meet you in your quarters.
I'll be waiting for you...
Deck eight.
Come in.
Security to Counselor Troi's quarters.
Acknowledged.
I don't understand... Lieutenant Worf said you wanted to talk to me about something.
Where is he?
He said he had to go somewhere.
Troi to Worf.
Computer...
Where is Lieutenant Worf?
Lieutenant Worf is in Ensign Calloway's quarters.
Take Lieutenant Pierce to his quarters and hold him there.
Security override, authorization Troi Delta-two-nine.
Worf...
Stop it --
Stop it --
He's dead... you killed him...
No... no...
You know what you have to do...
I know... what I have to do...
Plasma venting system will engage in... seventy seconds.
What were you doing?
You're alive... you're all right...
-- I opened the maintenance door at Counselor Troi's request, then turned and saw that she had moved too close to the force-field.
It all seemed so real to me. It's hard to imagine that everything I experienced happened in just those few seconds...
It appears that you were correct, Counselor. Lieutenant Pierce was partially telepathic -- his maternal grandmother was from Betazed.
What else have you found?
According to Starfleet records, Pierce and the other two persons Counselor Troi identified were killed in an accidental plasma discharge eight years ago. Their bodies were never found.
I don't believe it was an accident. I think that Pierce found out that the other two were having an affair. He lost control... and killed them both.
Afterwards, he probably activated the plasma stream, then threw himself into it.
The plasma discharge would have obliterated any evidence that it was murder.
I scanned behind the panel Counselor Troi asked me to look at. I didn't find any bone fragments... but I did find traces of cellular residue. It's showing some kind of... empathic signature.
It may be that when Lieutenant Pierce was struck by the plasma stream, the subspace energy present there imprinted his empathic pattern into the residue.
Kind of like a... psychic photograph.
That's what triggered my hallucination... My mind must have taken elements from my own life and created a situation that in many ways paralleled what happened to Pierce.
If you hadn't been there, I would have jumped... just like he did...
Counselor...
Yes?
When I pulled you away from the plasma stream, you seemed... surprised that I was alive.
Well... actually, in my hallucination... you were killed.
May I ask by whom?
You know what they say, Worf... Hell hath no fury like a woman scorned...
I don't know why they have to do this every year. In fact, I thought last year the teachers agreed not to do this anymore.
Captain Picard Day is one of the children's favorite school activities. They look forward to it all year.
Why does it have to be me?
You're the Captain... children look up to you... you're a role model for them.
Their perception of me is a little... exaggerated.
(using doll and imitating voice) "I don't know... I think this bears a certain resemblance. Wouldn't you agree, Number One?"
Don't you have something else to do?
I'll be on the Bridge.
The finalists will be here in half an hour. You have to pick first, second and third place and four honorable mentions.
Worf to Captain. Incoming transmission from Admiral Blackwell. It is coded priority one.
Put it through. Excuse me, Counselor.
Admiral.
Captain. What is your status?
We're conducting an energy output study of the Mekoria Quasar. All systems normal, the ship is fully operational.

Good. I'm postponing the quasar study for the moment. The Enterprise is to rendezvous with the starship Crazy Horse in sector one-six-zero-seven immediately. You're authorized to exceed warp speed limitations for the duration of this assignment.
I understand. What is our assignment?
I'd prefer not to discuss it over subspace channels. The Crazy Horse will be carrying someone from Starfleet Intelligence... he'll brief you when he arrives.
Very well.
"Captain Picard Day?"
Oh... yes. It's for the children... I'm a... role model.
I'm sure you are. Starfleet out.
So who won the contest?
Paul Menegay -- seven years old. He did an interesting clay sculpture of my head.
Is that the lumpy one with the orange skin?
Yes. Oh, you'll be interested to know that I've arranged for a Commander Riker day next month. I'm even considering making an entry myself.
Great.
Energize.
Wil. Bet you never thought you'd see me again.
It's... good to see you, sir.
Sure it is. You look like you're about to faint.
No... it's just been so long and...
I'm sorry. Captain Jean-Luc Picard, Admiral Erik Pressman.
Pressman? Oh, of course. You were Wil's first commanding officer... on the Pegasus.
That's right. As a matter of fact, it's the Pegasus which has brought me here.
Sir?
The Pegasus is still out there, Wil. The Romulans found her.
As some of you may know, the starship Pegasus was lost in this sector twelve years ago along with most of its crew. I was the captain and Commander Riker here was my helmsman.
I remember reading about it. The ship was destroyed by a... warp core breach as I recall.
That's right. The Captain and I, along with seven others managed to get to an escape pod before the breach became critical.
From space, we saw what appeared to be a matter/anti-matter explosion which vaporized the ship.
No wreckage was ever found, so Starfleet officially listed the ship as destroyed.

However, all that changed three days ago. Starfleet Intelligence has an operative in the Romulan High Command. He sent us a message that a Romulan warbird had located a piece of debris in the Devolin system which was positively identified as being from the Pegasus. The Warbird was then ordered to locate the rest of the ship, if possible, and retrieve it.
Why would the Romulans try to salvage pieces of a twelve year-old starship?

The Pegasus was a prototype... experimental engine... new weapon systems... some of our designs were even used in constructing the Enterprise. There're a lot of things on board the Romulans would love to get their hands on.
What are our orders?
We have to find the ship before the Romulans do... salvage it if possible... destroy it if necessary. You'll command the Enterprise while I remain in overall command of the mission.
We'll need metallurgical and chromographic specs on the Pegasus in order to set up the proper search parameters.
I'll make the appropriate information available to you.
Very well. Set course for the Devolin system.
Aye, sir.
We are approaching the Devolin system, Captain.
Any sign of the Romulans?
No, sir.
Oh, they're out there... they're just waiting to see what you're going to do.
Mister La Forge?
There's an awful lot of ionizing radiation in this system, Captain. That, combined with the sheer amount of rock is going to slow down our search.
How slow?
Well, I'd say at least--
Sir. Romulan Warbird decloaking directly ahead.
They're powering weapons.
Red alert. Raise shields. Standby phasers.
Sir... they are hailing us.
On screen.
I am Commander Sirol of the Romulan vessel Terix. To whom do I have the honor of speaking?
I am Captain Jean-Luc Picard of the Federation starship Enterprise.
Captain Picard... I've heard so much about you. It's a pleasure to make your acquaintance. I hope our sudden appearance didn't startle you.
Not at all. But an... unannounced appearance like this could have unfortunate consequences. It would be a shame if your ship were damaged during such a... misunderstanding.
I am touched by your concern for my ship. But I doubt we were ever in any danger. May I ask what you are doing in this system?
I could ask you the same question.
We are conducting a survey of gaseous anomalies.
How interesting. So are we. Perhaps we could combine our efforts and share our findings.
I doubt our objectives are... compatible.
You are probably right.
This has been a most pleasant conversation... but we must return to our research.
Then I won't keep you.
They are moving off... resuming their tachyon scans of the system.
Stand down from Red Alert, but continue to track their movements, Lieutenant.
Aye, sir.
Commander, how long will it take to search the system?
At least seven days, sir.
And the Romulans have a two day head start.
Then we better get to it. Mister Data?
Initiating sensor sweep of grid zero one.
How long have you had the beard?
About four years. I think I just got tired of hearing how "young" I looked.
What was it that Lieutenant Boylen used to call you?
Ensign Babyface.
You never did have much sense of humor.
I like to think I've loosened up in my old age.
Really?
I've been known to tell a joke or two.
It's about time. You were always so serious on the Pegasus.
We went through some... serious times.
Do you really think we'll find the Pegasus?
I wouldn't have come all the way out here if I didn't.
And what about our... experiment? Do you think we'll find that too?
Maybe.
You know... I still think about what happened... about that last day.
So do I. It's not the kind of thing you just forget about.
Do you ever... wonder whether we did the right thing?
Never. It was a tragedy, yes. But it wasn't your fault and it wasn't mine. What we were doing was for the good of the Federation. We can't blame ourselves because the others couldn't see that.
I know... but maybe we went about it the wrong way.
Well, this time we may have a chance to do it the right way. If this mission is successful... if we do find the Pegasus and our "experiment"... we can finish what we started twelve years ago.
You want to try again?
It's not just me. (glances around, then sotto) The Chief of Starfleet Security has personally assured me of her complete support.
Admiral Raner... ? How many other people know about this?

Not many. And it's up to us to make sure it stays that way. Raner gave me written orders for you... you'll find them coded in the Enterprise computer. You've been instructed not to reveal the true nature of our mission to anyone, not even Captain Picard.
Don't worry... it won't be like it was twelve years ago. This time, no one's going to stop us.
... as a matter of fact, I never met Wil before he reported aboard at Farpoint Station.
You chose your first officer without ever meeting him?

I was looking through the records of about fifty candidates... Wil's was much like all the others... filled with the usual dry statistics and glowing letters of recommendation that tell you nothing. I was about to put it aside and go on to the next file, when something caught my eye.

There had been an incident on Altair Three when Wil was First Officer of the Hood. He refused to let Captain DeSoto beam down during a crisis. He disobeyed a direct order and risked a general court martial because he thought he was right. When I read that... I knew I'd found my Number One.
You wanted someone with a history of disobedience?

I wanted someone who would stand up to me... someone who was more concerned with the safety of the ship and accomplishing the mission than with how something looked on his record. To me, that's one of the marks of a good officer.

Frankly, I've always felt it was more important for an officer to trust his captain's judgment. In a crisis, there's no time for explanations... orders have to be obeyed without question or lives may be lost.
I am aware of that, Admiral.

Of course you are. I guess this mission has brought up some... old ghosts for me. You know what it's like to lose a ship... you're always wondering if there was something else you should have done... something you missed.
Admiral... the records regarding the loss of the Pegasus are a bit... vague about what happened just before you abandoned ship. Can you add anything to the... official account?

I'm afraid not. But I can tell you this: Twelve years ago, I needed an officer I could count on in a crisis... someone who would support and obey my decisions without question... someone willing to trust my judgment... that someone was Wil Riker... and without his loyalty, none of us would have survived.
What's wrong?
I think I busted a rib.
What were you doing?
I was practicing Bat'leth moves with Worf. I jabbed when I should've blocked. He caught me right in the side. I'm glad we were using sticks instead of real blades.
It's broken all right. Give him ten cc's of terakine for the pain.
I can't believe how stupid I was.
You both got a little carried away, that's all...
No. It was my fault. I lost focus... I let myself get distracted at a crucial moment.
It happens to everyone.
I knew what I was supposed to do... but I didn't do it. If we'd had real Bat'leths I might be dead right now.
Wil... it's all right. You made a mistake... no harm done. You'll do better next time.
Yeah... maybe.
Scan of grid one five seven is complete. Moving to grid one five eight.
The Romulan ship is still searching grid two seven zero.
They're sure taking their time over there. I wonder if they--
Whoa... I think we might have just struck paydirt.
There's a subspace resonance signature coming from this asteroid. And from the frequency variances, it looks like the pattern from a Federation warp core.
Captain Picard to the Bridge, please.
Bring us to within ten kilometers of asteroid gamma six zero one. Geordi's found something.
There's a subspace resonance signature coming from that asteroid, sir. It could be the warp core of the Pegasus.
I think he's right... I recognize some of the variance patterns.
Put the asteroid on the main viewer.
I have confirmed Geordi's readings, sir. The resonance signature is originating from somewhere beneath the asteroid's surface.
Beneath the surface? How's that possible?

This asteroid contains several deep chasms large enough for a starship to enter. It is possible the Pegasus drifted into the asteroid's gravitational field and was pulled down into one of the fissures.
Sir, the Romulan warbird has altered course again... they are heading toward our position.
They probably want to see what we're so interested in over here.
Mister Data, how long will it take to determine the exact location of the Pegasus?
At least another six hours, Captain.
That's too long. If the Romulans start searching the asteroid, they could find the ship before we do.
I recommend we destroy the asteroid. It would take almost all our photon torpedoes, but it would preclude any possibility of the Pegasus falling into Romulan hands.
Our top priority is to salvage the ship, Commander. I'll consider destroying it only as a last resort.
Yes, sir.
Can you give me a third alternative?
Mister Data, is it possible to saturate the asteroid with verteron particles? That could mask the resonance signature from the Romulans... prevent them from detecting it.
In order for the deception to succeed, it would have to appear to be a natural phenomenon. Verteron particles are artificial in nature.
Wait a minute... we could blanket the asteroid with high levels of ionizing radiation. There's so much of it in this system already, the Romulans won't know the difference.
Data?
Theoretically, it should work..
If we're going to do it, we have to do it fast... the Romulans will be in sensor range in about a minute.
Make it so, Mister Data.
Aye, sir. Initiating an ionization field pulse.
After he's finished, we'll have to move off... make it look like we scanned the asteroid, but didn't find anything.
Lay in a course to the next search grid and stand-by to engage.
If this works, the Romulans won't find anything and we can return later. But if it doesn't...
If it doesn't... we'll have handed them the Pegasus.
Ionization pulse complete.
Helm, one quarter impulse. Engage.
The Romulans are initiating a tachyon scan of the asteroid... They have switched to their lateral sensor array... beginning another scan.
They're certainly being thorough.
The Warbird has completed its sensor sweep.
If they found the resonance signature, they should be sending away teams any second now...
They are moving off.
Mister Data, we have to convince the Romulans that we're still looking for the Pegasus. I want you to continue scanning this system.
Yes, sir.
I want to be back at this asteroid at zero eight hundred hours tomorrow. Plot our search pattern accordingly.
Aye, sir.
Admiral, if you'd care to join me for a late dinner... ?
Thank you, no. I think I'm going to turn in early.
Very well. Number One, you have the Bridge. Oh, and will you bring the scan analysis to my quarters when you go off watch?
Aye, sir.
Initiate search of grid one six three.
Beginning sensor sweeps...
Commander, I want to see you in the Captain's Ready Room.
Mister Data, you have the Bridge.
Aye, sir.
What the hell's the matter with you? Destroy the Pegasus? Before we've even taken a look at it?
I thought it was more important to keep the Romulans from--
Well, you were wrong. We have a chance here to change the balance of power in this quadrant. But we can't do that if we destroy the Pegasus, now can we?
No, sir.
It hasn't been easy I'm sure... keeping your Captain and friends in the dark like this...
I haven't enjoyed it if that's what you mean.
I hope you understand that it's necessary.
I understand that you think it's necessary.
(studies him, then more personal) You have changed.
Changed... ?
Just something the Captain and I were talking about...

To be honest... I'm glad to see this kind of change in you, Wil. Strong... forceful... unafraid to state your opinions and stand by them... a far cry from the young man who used to sit at my helm and worry about pressing the wrong button.
A lot of things can change in twelve years, Admiral.
Yes, they can. But it's important that a man changes the right things in his life... not his sense of duty... his sense of loyalty...
I'd like to think that I... haven't changed those things, sir.
I'd like to think so too. Because those things say more about a man than the rank on his collar or the uniform he wears... they define him.

Twelve years ago, a lot of older and more seasoned officers turned away from their duty, but you stood up for what was right. I know what kind of man you are, Wil... and I know I can count on you again.
Come.
The scan analysis you asked for.
Thank you. Can I interest you in some sashimi?
No, thanks.
Is there anything else, sir?
Yes, there is.
"Judge Advocate General's Report. Stardate xxxxx. Subject: Inquiry into Mutiny Aboard USS Pegasus."

"Based on testimony from Captain Pressman and other surviving officers, the Judge Advocate believes there is sufficient evidence to conclude that certain members of the crew did mutiny against the captain just prior to the destruction of the Pegasus."
Mutiny... on a Federation starship. It's shocking -- no, it's unthinkable. And yet you've never mentioned it.
No, sir.
It wasn't easy getting this record. I had to call in a few favors at Starfleet just to get a look at it. It seems the file was sealed by Starfleet Intelligence.
So... not only was the Pegasus carrying "sensitive" equipment that can't be allowed to fall into Romulan hands...

... not only was there a mysterious explosion which appeared to destroy the ship, but didn't... but now it turns out there was a mutiny on board. I've read the official report of the mutiny. But I'd like to hear your version of what happened.

I was on the Bridge. The ship was at yellow alert... we were running some... tests on the engines. Something went wrong... there was an explosion in Engineering... heavy casualties. In the middle of the crisis, the First Officer, the Chief Engineer, almost the entire Bridge crew mutinied against Captain Pressman.
Why?
They... felt the Captain was jeopardizing the ship.
And you?
I was seven months out of the Academy... my head was still ringing with words like duty and honor.

When they moved against him, I thought they were a group of self-serving, disloyal officers. So I grabbed a phaser and defended my captain. Two or three others joined in on our side, but it was clear the mutineers had most of the crew behind them... we felt we had to get off the ship. There was a... running firefight all the way to the escape pod. About five minutes after we left the ship... there was an explosion...

"The Judge Advocate also believes that the surviving officers are deliberately withholding vital information from this inquiry. Further investigation is recommended." But there was no further investigation... the file was classified and quietly buried. Why?
Sir... maybe you should take this up with the Admiral.

I'm taking it up with you. The Judge Advocate thought you were participating in a conspiracy to cover-up the truth. That you were lying about what really happened on the Pegasus. Now, I want you to tell me that's not true.
Wil, what the hell's going on here? Why did your crew mutiny? And why is Pressman so determined to find your ship twelve years later?
I've told you all I can. I am under the direct orders of Admiral Pressman... not to discuss this. Sir.

Very well. He's an admiral, I'm a captain -- I can't force you to disobey him. I will tell you this... I need to place a great deal of trust in the person who serves as my first officer. You've had that trust... until now. But something is wrong here... and you're part of it. And when this mission is over... I may have to re-evaluate the command structure of this ship.
Dismissed.
Captain, Starfleet places the highest priority on the success of this mission. Your request for a delay is denied.
Margaret... something's very wrong here. Do you know what's going on?
I know that the Chief of Starfleet Intelligence herself is watching this one, Jean-Luc. So you would be well-advised to follow Pressman's orders and leave it at that. Starfleet out.
Worf to Captain Picard. We are approaching asteroid gamma six zero one, sir.
On my way.
Mister Worf, where are the Romulans?
They are out of sensor range on the far side of the system.
Bring us to within fifteen kilometers and hold position.

For the past several hours, I have been scanning the area where we detected the resonance signature of the Pegasus. From the strength and polarity of the signature, it would appear that most of the warp core is still intact.
If we're lucky, the entire engineering section could be down there.
So how do we get to it? I wouldn't want to try to transport through that much solid rock.
Agreed. What about a shuttle? We could send it down through one of these fissures.
I would recommend against that, sir. There may be gravimetric or magnetic fluctuations inside the asteroid which would overpower the engines on a shuttlecraft.
Sounds like the best solution is to take the Enterprise in.
You mean into the asteroid?
That's right. (points to graphic, then to Data) Put this fissure on the main viewer.
This chasm is large enough for us to maneuver in. Besides, if there's any hope of salvaging the Pegasus, we'll need a starship to do it.
Mister Data?
It is theoretically possible, Captain. But I am unaware of any prior situation where a starship was taken so deeply inside a planetary body. There may be unforeseen difficulties.
Admiral... I don't think we can risk--
I've made my decision. Prepare to take the Enterprise in, Captain. That's an order.
Mister Data, please note in the ship's log that this action is being taken over my explicit objections.
It is so noted.
Yellow Alert.
Shields up, inertial dampers to maximum.
Mister Data, plot a course into the chasm... maneuvering thrusters only.
Course plotted.
Take us in.
We are now two kilometers beneath the surface.
We are encountering shifts in magnetic field density.
Admiral, if the passage narrows to less than five hundred meters, I'm going to abort the mission.
You can charge me with insubordination if you wish, but I won't risk the Enterprise for a salvage operation.
Sir... I am reading a large resonance signature directly ahead.
On screen.
Pegasus...
What the hell happened?
Sensors show that the ship is still intact... but approximately sixty-five percent of it is contained within the asteroid.
As if half the ship had materialized inside solid rock.
Yes, sir. I do not know how this could have happened.
Let's keep the speculation to a minimum. We have to begin the salvage operation. The equipment we need was in main engineering. Can you scan that section of the Pegasus?
The starboard bulkhead of Main Engineering is contained within the rock face... but most of the compartment is still intact.
There is a hull breach in that section.
If we begin a power transfer, can you restore life support to that compartment?
I believe so. The breach can be temporarily sealed by extending our shields.
See to it. Once you've restored life support, Commander Riker and I will beam directly into Engineering.
Admiral, I'd like to send a complete Away Team to --
There's some very sensitive equipment over there. I don't want anyone else near it.
Yes, sir.
This room was open to space for twelve years...
The vacuum preserved everything...
I wonder how many of the crew are back there...
We're not here for a memorial service.
It should be in here.
It's still intact.
What's wrong? Don't you understand? We found it.
I know. I just kept hoping it wasn't going to be here... that it would've been destroyed or buried back there in the rock...
What the hell's that supposed to mean?

It means I can't put this off any longer. Right up until this moment, I had the... luxury of time. Now I have to make a choice. And Admiral... I'm afraid the only choice I can make... is to put a stop to this. I can't let you start these experiments all over again. It was wrong twelve years ago, and it's still wrong today.
You'd better reconsider that position, Commander. We have a mission to accomplish and you're going to carry it out.
That's all that matters to you, isn't it -- starting your experiment again. Look around... we're standing in a room filled with bodies... people who died because of that thing.
Keep your self-righteous comments to yourself. I knew most of these people a lot longer than you did... it was tragic. But it was their own fault.
You don't know that. Neither of us knows what happened after we left.
It's not hard to guess. They tried to shut down an experiment they didn't understand. Something went wrong. And it killed them.
No... we killed them.
That doesn't sound like the young Conn Officer who grabbed a phaser and defended his captain twelve years ago.
Yeah, well I've had twelve years to think about it. And if I had to do it over again... I'd point that phaser at you instead of them.
So on reflection... you'd rather be a traitor than a hero.

I wasn't a hero and neither were you. What you were doing was wrong and I was wrong to support you... I was just too young and stupid to realize it at the time. You were the captain, I was the ensign... and I followed orders.
And if you hadn't, you'd be dead right now along with all the rest. Dead because you listened to a bunch of mutinous cowards who were too blinded by fear to see what I was trying to do.
They were brave enough to risk their lives to stop you from violating a treaty the Federation signed in good faith.
That treaty has bound our hands and given the Romulans a tactical advantage for sixty years. I was simply trying to level the playing field.
And now you're going to try again. How many people will die this time? Fifty? A hundred? A thousand?

You don't want to help me... fine. But you're still under my direct orders not to talk about what you know... and I expect you to follow those orders to the letter. I made you... and I can break you just as easily.
Picard to Away Team. Prepare to return to the ship immediately.
Stand-by, Enterprise.
Pressman to Enterprise. Two people, one piece of equipment to beam up.
Report.
The Romulans fired on the entrance to the chasm with their disruptors... they've sealed us in.
Sir... there is an incoming message... it is from the Warbird.
On screen.
Captain... you seem to be in a very... unfortunate circumstance. How can we help?
Are you responsible for this?

I'm not sure. We were conducting some... geological experiments on the surface of the asteroid. It's possible that we... accidently sealed you in. If only we had known you were beneath the surface... if you had shared your plans with us, this might have been avoided.
What is it you want, Sirol?
I don't want anything, Captain. But I will offer to help you.
How?
By transporting your crew aboard my ship. We'll take you back to Romulus... where after a short stay as our guests, you will be returned to the Federation.
Thank you for your... generous offer. I will... take it under advisement.
As you wish. We'll be continuing our... research in this system for a while longer. I await your decision.
We can't do it. If we abandon the Enterprise they'll come back here and get their hands on both ships.
Agreed. Options?
We could use the phasers to cut our way out.
The asteroid's internal structure is highly unstable. Any attempt to cut through the rock could cause the entire chasm to collapse.
Captain... I have a suggestion. There's a piece of equipment under guard in Admiral Pressman's quarters which could get us out of here. It's a prototype for a Federation cloaking device.
You just ended your career, Wil.
That's what this is all about? A cloaking device? In the Treaty of Algeron the Federation specifically agreed not to develop cloaking technology.
And that treaty is the biggest mistake we ever made. It's kept us from exploiting a vital area of defense that--
That treaty has kept the peace for sixty years. And as a Starfleet officer, you are sworn to uphold it.
That's enough. I'm taking command of this vessel. Mister Worf, escort the Captain to his quarters.
I don't think anyone's going to come to your defense this time.
How can we use the cloak to escape the asteroid?
It's more than just a cloak. It changes the structure of matter... in theory, a ship using this device would be able to pass through normal matter.
That's why you were so eager to find it...
Can't you see the potential here? The phasing cloak could be the greatest breakthrough in weapons research in the last fifty years.
Except it's illegal... it's a violation of an agreement the Federation signed in good faith.
Captain... we might be able to adapt the cloak for the Enterprise engines and use it to escape the asteroid.
Mister Data?
It is theoretically possible, sir. But it will take several hours to study the device and determine how to link it to our systems.
Make it so.
Captain's Log: Stardate 47457.1. We have been trapped inside the asteroid for over eight hours. Mister Data and Commander La Forge inform me that they are nearly ready to engage the cloak.
Commander, I've routed the impulse engines through the warp plasma conduits... but you'll have to watch the intercooler levels... if they go too high, we'll blow out the entire relay system.

Understood. I think that's what happened twelve years ago. The cloak blew out the plasma relays on the Pegasus after we left the ship... the plasma ignited in space, and it looked like the ship had been destroyed.
So the ship drifted into this system... still in a phased state... and when it passed through this asteroid...
The cloak failed. And half the ship materialized in solid rock.
La Forge to Bridge. The cloak is on-line and ready to begin phase sequencing.
Proceed, Number One.
Aye, sir. Activating power systems...
Report.
The cloak appears to be functioning normally. The ship's matter/energy phasing rate should be sufficient to pass through the asteroid.
Take us out. Maneuvering thrusters only.
We will reach the rock face in... five seconds.
We have passed through two kilometers of the asteroid... now within one kilometer of the surface.
We're approaching the surface...
We have cleared the asteroid, Captain. (reacts to something on console) The Warbird is off the port bow.
They're still waiting for us to make up our minds.
Disengage the cloaking device, Commander.
What? You can't do that. If the Romulans see us decloak, they'll know that we have --
They'll know the truth, Admiral. Which is what everyone is going to know very shortly. Carry out my orders.
Mister Worf, send a message to the Warbird... inform them that their government will be contacted shortly regarding this incident.
Aye, sir.
Admiral, I hereby charge you with violation of the Treaty of Algeron. As Captain of the Enterprise, I'm placing you under arrest. Mister Worf?
Admiral, if you will come with me...
I have a lot of friends at Starfleet Command, Captain.
You're going to need them.
Lieutenant. I'll have to be placed under arrest as well.

I've spoken to Fleet Admiral Shanthi. There will be a full inquiry once we reach Starbase two-four-seven... and it will probably lead to a general court martial of Admiral Pressman and several others at Starfleet Intelligence.
Your... involvement in this affair will be thoroughly investigated, Wil... there will be some hard questions for you to answer...
I understand.

You made a mistake twelve years ago... but your service since that time has earned you a great deal of respect... from me and from a great many others. This incident may cost you some of that respect...
I can't help feeling that I should have come forward a long time ago...
When the moment came to make the decision... you made the right one...
No matter what that choice may have cost you... and no matter how much Pressman may have meant to you... you chose to tell the truth and face the consequences.
As long as you can do that... you'll still deserve to wear that uniform... and I'll still be proud to have you as my first officer.
Captain's log, Stardate 41263.1. We have rendezvoused with the USS Fearless from which...
scene: 1    EXT. SPACE - THE ENTERPRISE AND THE FEARLESS (OPTICAL)
location: SPACE - THE ENTERPRISE AND THE FEARLESS

quote: ... a Starfleet propulsion expert and his assistant are beaming over to conduct tests on the Enterprise's warp drive engines.
I don't understand your concern, Number One. They're not authorized to make any alterations in our engines.
(glancing at command viewer) According to Starfleet's message, they will simply test different ways of entering warp speed and different intermix formulas. What's the harm in that?
It's the specs that Kosinski sent us. In my opinion, sir, they're gibberish.
Gibberish?
Mister Data, will you explain?
Sir, we put Mister Kosinski's specs into the computer and ran a controlled test on them. There was no improvement in engine performance.
Then explain Starfleet's report how the same tests on the USS Ajax... ... and then on the Fearless over there, resulted in a measurable increase in propulsion.
Our engines are new, sir, top condition. The tests on those older ships may have simply straightened out some engine inefficiency.
Bridge from Transporter Chief. Two from USS Fearless are ready to beam over.
Stand by for Commander Riker, Chief. He's on his way. Obviously, something does worry you about these tests.
Yes, sir. And if you don't mind... ... I'll ask Counselor Troi to look these visitors over.
Welcome aboard, Mister Kosinski. I'm the first officer, Commander William Riker. This is...
Where is the captain, please?
He is engaged in other duties, sir...
A ship's engines should be a concern of the ship's captain...

They are, sir. Which is why they make their first officers directly responsible for engine condition and performance. Guided, of course, by one of our chief engineers, Lieutenant Commander Argyle in this case.
A pleasure, sir. I appreciated receiving the advance specs...
On which you have no end of questions?
Aye, I have.
And you, sir, are listed as...as...
As Mister Kosinski's assistant. My actual name is unpronounceable by humans...
From Tau Alpha C. That's very distant...
... All approved and described in the Starfleet communications. Now... ... I'd like to set up in the Engine Room immediately...
Our chief engineer will show you to his Engine Room.
No need -- I know my way around starships...
One thing Kosinski isn't hiding. A bad disposition.
Agreed... Also, he's arrogant, overbearing, self-important. And very sure of himself and his ability.
And the other one -- his assistant?

He's the puzzle. (takes a minute to phrase it) With most life forms I feel something. I may not be able to interpret or understand it, but I feel something, if only a presence. With him -- nothing. Empty space. It was as though he isn't even here. ... Something about this concerns me. I don't know what, I can't point out a reason... yet.
Stay concerned. Please! The safety of the Enterprise may be entrusted to those two!
Inform the bridge I shall begin the first test in precisely fifty minutes. Why is that child here?
He's working on a school project. (that's not what's on his mind) Before you continue, there are some questions. First, tell us...
... To save myself time, let me ask those questions for you.

You received the information which Starfleet provided -- you fed it into your computer -- being as precise as humanly possible -- then you ran a controlled test. And, then, to your astonishment -- nothing happened.
So you said - "What's going on? This doesn't work. Kosinski's a fraud."
You see, I have had this discussion on other Starfleet vessels. They didn't understand it; why should you?
You are surely not saying it's unexplainable?
I'm saying I'm not a teacher, and don't want to become one. I have neither the inclination nor time.
You have all the time you need.
I don't think you understand. This has already been approved by Starfleet Command.
But it hasn't been approved by the chief engineer... or by me.
I didn't know that was necessary.
Now you do.
Perhaps I should talk with Captain Picard.
If you like, but it won't change anything.
How basic shall I be?
I leave that to you.
We can save a little time this way. My assistant is laying in my base formulas a bit more rapidly than a human can do it... ... even myself.
Here is, in the simplest possible terms, what I do. This warp drive system was tuned only in the grossest sense, at least to my standard anyway. What I do is specific.
How should I say this? Aah... sufficient to say for now, these symbols and their relationships have greater meaning to me than to you...
... although you can in time learn them. Then, those of you sufficiently gifted, can duplicate my results.
But the three percent efficiency increase of the other vessels could still have been caused by other things such as simply working more carefully, better station coordination...
And you mention "gifted." In what way? Whatever any of us can learn to do on a computer, another computer can eventually perform faster, more precisely...
Wrong! What the computer can't do is create. Only the mind... ... is capable of true, original thought.
But what we're dealing with is mechanics. However complex it may be, it has to do with an engine.
And that is exactly where you go wrong. Warp drive has become so complex that it is...
... as filled with mysteries as nature itself. If you'll view the screen with me and consider the following.
Is this merely "mechanics" or is it nature that we deal with in this? What else than nature are elementals like space and time?
Boy, don't play with that.
Main Engineering is ready to proceed, Captain.
Engineering, this is the bridge. It's your call.
Do this one just like the others. Nothing changes.
Commander -- I will make my preliminary adjustments at warp one-point-five, and complete them as we achieve warp six.
Engineering to bridge, did you copy that?
Affirmative, Number One. Are you ready?
We are.
La Forge, set in warp one-point-five.
Warp one-point-five.
Engage!
All right, here we go.
Passing warp five.
What are you doing... ?
What is our velocity?
It is off the scale, sir...
Reverse engines!
Captain, no one has ever reversed engines at this velocity.
That's because no one has ever gone this fast. REVERSE ENGINES!
All stop!
Position.
Calculating it, sir. Data, what do you read there?
(reading his own viewer; puzzled) A malfunction... I trust.
Position please, Lieutenant La Forge.
According to these readings, sir, we have not only left our own galaxy, but have passed through two others, stopping on the far side of Triangulum -- the Galaxy known as M-Thirty-Three.
That's not possible. Data, what is our distance traveled?
Two million -- seven hundred thousand light years.
(more to himself than anyone else) I can't accept that.
You must, sir. Our comparisons show it to be completely accurate.
And I calculate that at maximum warp, sir... ... it would take over three hundred years to get home.
Captain's log, stardate 41263.2. This will be a rather unusual log entry, assuming Starfleet ever receives it. As I have already informed my crew...

... a phenomenal surge of power during a warp speed experiment has sent our starship hurtling out of our own galaxy, past another, taking us over two million, seven-hundred thousand light years in a few minutes.
Message on this has been transmitted to Starfleet, sir.
Which, traveling subspace, they should receive in fifty-one years, ten months...
(interrupting; irritated) Mister Data... !
Sir?
Captain Picard, I presume?
We're still trying to determine what happened, sir.
The truth is, Captain, I made a mistake. A wonderful, incredible mistake.
Just explain what brought us here!
As the power built, I applied the energy asymtotically. I anticipated some tiling, but it didn't occur. That was my error -- using Bessel functions from the beginning.
What is he saying, Number One?
Well... if you want the truth, sir, it sounds to me like nonsense. But considering...
But considering where we are, we must assume it isn't.
I can call my mother. She's a doctor...
scene: 41   INT. MAIN ENGINEERING - WESLEY AND ASSISTANT

quote: No, there's nothing she can do. I need to rest. I've been away too long.
scene: 41   INT. MAIN ENGINEERING - WESLEY AND ASSISTANT

quote: Whatever happened to you... was it part of what happened to the ship?
scene: 41   INT. MAIN ENGINEERING - WESLEY AND ASSISTANT

quote: Please believe I mean no harm to this vessel... or those in it...
scene: 41   INT. MAIN ENGINEERING - WESLEY AND ASSISTANT

quote: Is Mister Kosinski like he sounds? A joke?
scene: 41   INT. MAIN ENGINEERING - WESLEY AND ASSISTANT

quote: No, that's too cruel. He has sensed some small part of this...
scene: 41   INT. MAIN ENGINEERING - WESLEY AND ASSISTANT

quote: ... that space and time and thought aren't... well, aren't the separate things they seem to be?
scene: 41   INT. MAIN ENGINEERING - WESLEY AND ASSISTANT

quote: I... I just thought the formula you were using said something like that...
scene: 41   INT. MAIN ENGINEERING - WESLEY AND ASSISTANT

quote: Boy, don't you ever say that again. At least, not at your age in a world that's not ready for such... ... such dangerous nonsense.
scene: 41   INT. MAIN ENGINEERING - WESLEY AND ASSISTANT

quote: I've always suspected this rate of speed was possible, of course, but, at this level -- never. We are going to need new definitions. New parameters.
scene: 42   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - AT THE COMMAND AREA

quote: Perhaps you could call it the Kosinski scale.
scene: 42   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - AT THE COMMAND AREA

quote: Why not? Since I'm the one who has made the so-called "warp barrier" meaningless. And, Captain, this must be a special thrill for you.
scene: 42   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - AT THE COMMAND AREA

quote: "Thrill?"
scene: 42   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - AT THE COMMAND AREA

quote: As an explorer. In three centuries of space flight, we have charted just eleven percent of our galaxy. Then... ... voila, we accomplish this.
scene: 42   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - AT THE COMMAND AREA

quote: Yes... but isn't the real point, can you do it again? Can you get us home?
scene: 42   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - AT THE COMMAND AREA

quote: Of course I can. I'll just do what I did before. (moves for turbolift; looks back) Coming, Riker?
scene: 42   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - AT THE COMMAND AREA

quote: Commander Riker will join you in a moment.
scene: 42   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - AT THE COMMAND AREA

quote: Comment is invited. Counselor?
scene: 42   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - AT THE COMMAND AREA

quote: He's convinced he's right -- I have no doubt of that.
scene: 42   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - AT THE COMMAND AREA

quote: Can you allow a man who has made one mistake back into a position where he may make another?
scene: 42   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - AT THE COMMAND AREA

quote: What are the options? If he doesn't do it, who will?
scene: 42   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - AT THE COMMAND AREA

quote: Captain, we are here. Why not avail ourselves of this opportunity for study? There is a giant protostar here in the process of forming. No vessel has been out this far.
scene: 42   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - AT THE COMMAND AREA

quote: Spoken like a true Starfleet graduate. It is tempting, eh Number One?
scene: 42   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - AT THE COMMAND AREA

quote: Aye, sir, it is. As they say, sir... you're the captain.
scene: 42   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - AT THE COMMAND AREA

quote: Yes, that's the problem. I know that if Kosinski can get us home, Starfleet could use his technique to send back a pure science vessel to do even more. Number One -- have Mister Kosinski prepare to get us out of here.
scene: 42   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - AT THE COMMAND AREA

quote: Aye, sir.
scene: 42   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - AT THE COMMAND AREA

quote: Do you realize that many great advancements of mankind have been tied to speed? This is a moment in history -- right now. Right here. And your names will be linked forever with mine.
Excuse me, Commander Riker. I don't think he did it... I think it was...
Not now, Wes.
But, when this all happened, I was watching his assistant and...
I'm sure it was fascinating, Wesley, and I look forward to hearing about it. But not right now!
Standing by, Number One.
Aye, sir.
Come on.
He's too tired. (with a little challenge) Why don't you do it by yourself?
Yes, why not?
No, I will help.
As you wish.
I've laid in a reciprocal course back, Captain.
You may tell the captain I am ready, First Officer.
Ready for you to engage, Captain.
Warp one-point-five.
Warp one-point-five.
It's not working...
ALL STOP!

quote: Answering all stop.
scene: 59   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - INCLUDING MAIN VIEWER (OPTICAAL)

quote: Captain, according to the instruments, our speed never exceeded warp one-point-five.
scene: 59   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - INCLUDING MAIN VIEWER (OPTICAAL)

quote: All stopped, Captain.
scene: 59   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - INCLUDING MAIN VIEWER (OPTICAAL)

quote: Yes, but where is this place?
scene: 59   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - INCLUDING MAIN VIEWER (OPTICAAL)

quote: Where none have gone before.
scene: 59   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - INCLUDING MAIN VIEWER (OPTICAAL)

... the Enterprise has gone forward to a place in the universe which is uncharted and unknown. Our ship's instruments...

quote: From home, my pet... ... but when I was a child!

quote: Yes, I suppose that's what you...

quote: You darling, what are you doing here?
