I'd like to stay here with her... I'm going to try to contact her telepathically.
All right.
Mother... can you hear me... ?
Please come back to me... please...
Help me...
Mother... ?
Help me...
How? How can I help you?
Tell me, Mother. Please.
Computer, lights!
What are you doing?
What were you doing in Sickbay, Maques?
Helping... trying to help Lwaxana...
How... what were you trying to do?
I was... she is...
You, Deanna. Maybe you --
I don't understand.
You must... how can I explain...
Tell me, telepathically.
Maques believes my Mother's psyche has... collapsed in on itself -- that for some reason, she's retreated into her meta-conscious mind.
Was he trying to contact her telepathically?
Yes. He was able to access images being generated by her meta-conscious mind. But he couldn't make any sense of them...
I did not... understand...
He saw faces he didn't recognize, events he couldn't interpret.
If we could decipher those images, it might help us determine whether or not your Mother's condition was induced by some traumatic event.
Maques believes he can provide a... telepathic "bridge" that will allow me to access her meta-conscious. If he can, I might be able to find out what happened to her.
If you succeed, would you be able to use that information to help your Mother?
I'm not sure. But I do know that some part of her wants to be helped. When I tried to contact her telepathically, I heard a voice calling out to me.
If her psyche has... "collapsed in on itself," could accessing her mind pose any danger to you?
There's no way to know.
Sir, I'd like to try...
I'll be monitoring her through the whole procedure. If anything goes wrong, Maques can break the telepathic link.
Your Mother -- part of her is... very frightened. She may... resist you.
I understand.
Help me...
Mother... ?
Help me...
Counselor... can you hear me... ?
Captain... ?
Deanna... Doctor Crusher is concerned that your para-cortical readings have become erratic.
Are you... talking to me from Sickbay?
Yes. I want you to sever your connection to your Mother.
Why don't you ask Maques to do it?
I'm asking you.
That's an order, Counselor.
You're not Captain Picard.
Leave me alone... please...
This isn't real... none of this is real...
Daddy... ?
Deanna...
Look at you... you've become a beautiful woman...
Don't do this...
I'm sorry I had to go away when you were so little... I didn't want to...
You're not my father... you're a part of Mother's mind...
What is this place?
It's our house near Lake El'nar, on Betazed. We used to live here. Deanna -- let's not waste this chance. I want to hear everything that's happened to you...
Did I live here?
For a while... when you were a baby. You were such a beautiful baby... Your mother and I loved you so much...
I don't remember these toys...
I'll bet you don't remember me singing you to sleep at night, either... but I did.
I do remember... I always felt safe when you sang to me...
There was one song you always asked me to sing... you couldn't fall asleep unless you heard it....
Down in the valley...
Valley so low... hang your head over.... hear the wind blow --
No... no... you're trying to keep me here... keep me from finding something...
Your Mother doesn't want to see you, Deanna.
I have to help her...
If you want to help her... leave. Let her have peace.
But... she called out to me.... she does want my help.
Stay with me... just a little while... it's been so long -- we'll never have this chance again.
Goodbye, daddy.
Hedril... ?
Mother...
Get away from here!
No!
I asked your Father to bring you here because I wanted to talk to you about something. You know that Lwaxana is sick, don't you?
Yes.
Is it my fault?
No... not at all. But... I believe my Mother has been thinking about you. Do you know why?
I make her sad.
Why do you say that?
Because it's true.
Do you have any idea why Hedril would make my Mother sad?
No.
Thank you for coming to talk to us. I'll see you later, all right?
I hope your mother gets better.
Thank you, Hedril. So do I.
I just don't understand how she fits in to all this...
I still haven't been able to find a physiological cause for what's happened to your Mother. That makes me think that Maques was right, that her condition was precipitated by some traumatic event.
Could this event have involved Hedril?
I don't think so. My Mother never mentioned her.
Does your mother make personal logs... or keep a journal?
Yes, she does. I'll contact Mister Homn on Betazed and ask him to transmit a copy as soon as possible. Maybe there's a clue there...
Perhaps we are being too literal. In my recent study of dream analysis, I learned that people who appear in a dream can sometimes represent different aspects of the person who is dreaming.
That's right... a child might represent vulnerability. Maybe Hedril depicts some fragile part of my mother.
A part that she's protecting... ... you said everything you encountered when you were in her mind was a barrier of one kind or another...
Yes... you, the wolf, my father... as though she were summoning all her defenses to keep me away.
But away from what? What is she protecting?
Come in.
Counselor...
Hello, Captain.
I've just been in Sickbay. Doctor Crusher feels your mother's condition is deteriorating... her neural functions are getting weaker.
Have you had any luck here?
No, nothing. I've gone through her belongings... and read her journal from the last five years... ... and other than the fact that I'm not married yet, nothing bad seems to have happened to her.
Is this your Father?
Yes...
He had a kind face...

I remember when he died, my Mother had to go through all his things and pack them away... I was seven... and I remember thinking that he'd be mad when he came home and saw what she'd done. I didn't understand that he wasn't coming back...
Deanna... your Mother might still come out of this.
If we can't figure out what's wrong with her -- I don't think she will.

But I don't know what to do. I've talked with Mister Homn, who's known her for years. I've checked her medical records. I've made enquiries to the government on Betazed and I've contacted several of her close friends. If she suffered some kind of psychic trauma, there's just no evidence of it.
You said you'd reviewed her journals for the past five years. Perhaps we should go further back.
There's a lot to review. My mother's kept a journal since she was first married...
Well, let's start at the beginning.
The first entry seems to be Stardate 30620.1.
That's the year they were married.
This is odd... there's a seven year gap.
It starts about a year after my parents were married...
And if I'm not mistaken, it ends a few months after your birth.
My Mother has always been so diligent about her journal -- why would she have stopped making entries for so long?
She didn't. The files were deleted.
By your Mother... almost thirty years ago.
I don't understand any of this...
Captain, I have to go back in to my mother's mind. That's the only way we're ever going to get any answers.
Deanna... you understand that if your para-cortical readings go too high again, I'll have to tell Maques to sever the connection.
I know.
Hedril, be careful...
Who is Hedril?
Wait! I want to talk to you --
Help me...
Help me...
Mother... ?
Go away.
No... I want to help you.
Why did you delete parts of your journal?
Did something happen to you -- something you don't want me to know about?
Leave me alone... please...
Who is Hedril, Mother? Why is she here?
Is Hedril me -- when I was a little girl?
No -- I would never let anything happen to you... never.
Did you let something happen to someone... ?
Was it here, at El'nar?
You were just a baby...
Tell me; whatever it is we can face it together.
I can't...
You can... we can.
Help me...
Help me, papa...
Please... don't make me go through this again...
Here...
Now hold on to him, don't let him run off.
I won't...
Mommy, can we go play by the water?
No, Kestra... stay here with us...
Please?
Kestra, you woke your sister.
Kestra... ?
Don't cry, Deanna... mommy's here..
Please, mommy?
No, Kestra... we're going to eat in just a few minutes...
What's wrong, little one... what's wrong... ?
She's teething, Ian... where's her ring... ?
In your bag, I think...
Mommy's going to make it all better...
I can't find it -- are you sure it's in here?
No, I don't want to see this again -- I can't --
What happened, Mother. What happened next?
I don't remember --
You have to. You can't hold it back -- it's killing you.
The dog got away... she ran after him... we didn't notice... until it was too late...
The current was too strong...
Kestra...
Why did I look away... why wasn't I paying attention... ?
You have to forgive yourself, Mother... you have to let go...
How can I? I let her die...
It was a terrible tragedy -- the worst thing that can happen to any parent... I know you feel responsible... but it was an accident...
And what you're doing isn't fair to Kestra...
I saw a little girl who was sweet and happy... she must have brought a great deal of joy into your lives...
She woke up every morning with a smile...
Then isn't it better to remember her like that? I've just found out I had a sister I never knew... I'd like to remember what was good and joyous about her... to celebrate her life, not mourn it...
But when she died... the pain was so awful...
I know. And you shut it away inside you all these years. But hiding it didn't make it go away. It's still there, hurting you... and it will stay there unless you can forgive yourself and move on.
How? How can I do that?
Kestra was here, a few moments ago. Talk to her...
No --
Do it. Tell her how you feel. I'm here with you. I'll help you.
Mommy...
Kestra...
Oh, Kestra... my precious one... I'm so sorry...
I have to go now...
I know...
Kestra always wanted to help take care of you... she was never the slightest bit jealous of all the attention you got.
She sounds very sweet...
I made your father promise never to speak of her... it was a terrible thing to ask... but he went along with it.
If it hadn't been for your work with the Cairn, the strain of the telepathic contact, you might have been able to repress the memory forever.
And if it hadn't been for you -- I might have died trying to keep that dreadful secret.
I contacted Mister Homn and told him you were all right. He asked me to give you something.
I remember the day I took this...
Mister Homn said he saved it... in case someday you wanted to remember her...
I wish you could have known her, Deanna. I wish you two could have grown up together...
Tell me about her.. I want to know everything.
Fletcher has more experience with propulsion systems --
But Carstairs is better with people. Considering this is a supervisory position, I'd go with her.
You're probably right...
Didn't we just finish a Crew Evaluation Report?
That was three months ago.
Feels like three weeks. Maybe we should just give everyone a promotion and call it a night. What do you say... Commander?
Fine with me... Captain.
Why do they keep laughing? What's so funny about Crew Evaluations?
Don't worry about it, Sam.
Let's just try and have a good time.
How can I have a good time when my career's being decided across the room?
Think promotion... promotion... promotion...
You can't really believe this will influence the outcome of your evaluation?
It's a time-honored strategy, Taurik.
The Vedeks of the Janalan order maintain a round-the-clock chant for the well-being of the Bajoran people.
Considering the history of your planet, that doesn't exactly validate what he's doing.
Promote me, please -- so I can make Lieutenant and have my own room.
If you aren't happy sharing quarters with me, then you should put in for a new room assignment. Just in case you're not promoted.
I've been thinking about who to promote to Ops --
The new night duty officer?
Lavelle's an obvious candidate, but I'm considering Ensign Sito as well.
You sure about dessert?
Yes. Don't tempt me.
Are they working on the crew evaluations?
Yep.
Who were they talking about?
It's not my place to say...
Come on, Ben.
Please.
All right, but I'm not sure you're going to like it...
Apparently... you're both up for the same job...
Lock phasers on target --
Phasers locked --
The enemy vessel is firing.
Helm, hard to starboard!
Hard starboard --
Fire phasers!
Firing --
Target is destroyed.
End simulation sequence and secure from drill.
Alpha shift, your response time was seven percent slower than gamma shift --
I'd like all departments to submit drill evaluation reports by oh nine hundred hours --
Ensign, you'll write that report.
Yes, sir.
Let's see if we can find a way to close that gap.
What happened back there, Ensign?
I'm sorry, sir. When we changed course I had to re-lock the phasers before I could fire.
Next time try letting the locking relay float until the actual order to fire is given.
They may not teach that trick at the Academy, but it works.
Thank you, sir.
Lavelle...
Sir?
Resume previous course and speed.
Aye, aye sir.
One "aye" is sufficient acknowledgment, Ensign.
Helm, change course for the Argaya system -- maximum warp.
Aye, sir.
What about our rendezvous with the Clement?
I've just received new orders from Starfleet. We'll discuss it in the Observation Lounge.
Ensign Sito, you'll fill in at Ops.
Yes, sir.
The Argaya system is close to the Cardassian border; I wonder why we're going there.
How would you like to be a spider under that table?
What?
(gesturing back toward the Observation lounge) A spider under the table --
Is that like a fly on the wall?
I guess so.
You did really well during the drill.
Apparently Commander Riker didn't think so. I swear he's got it in for me.
You're imagining things.
Oh, yeah? Then how come you're sitting in that chair instead of me?
Maybe he figured I need more practice than you do.
Excuse me, sir... do you have a minute?
Sure. What is it?
I'd like you to take a look at something.
Have you been improvising again, Ensign?
In a manner of speaking. I'm running a computer simulation to test a new warp-field configuration.
You've got a problem right here... the plasma flow in the nacelles is out of sync.
Actually, sir, that was done deliberately.
As you can see, this configuration has increased overall warp-field integrity by seven percent.
You're right...
Doctor Nils Diaz has been experimenting with this technique at the Tanaline Propulsion Laboratory.
I know his work, but I never heard anything about this...
His findings have not been released yet. I was able to review a preliminary report when I was at the Academy.
I'll look forward to reading about it...
I predict that when these findings are made public, they will become a new model for warp field operation.
Sounds interesting.
With your permission, I would like to begin tests to see if the technique can be adapted to our warp drive.
I don't know... There could be variables you didn't account for.
I was quite thorough.
I'm sure you were... but I'd like to look over your simulation before I authorize any tests.
As you wish.
If you have any other ideas for improving efficiency, feel free to run them by me.
As a matter of fact, sir, I do -- when would be a good time to discuss them?
I'll get back to you on that...
If you're wondering about your evaluation, it couldn't be better.
Actually, I just wanted to tell you that Ensign Reilly's condition is showing improvement... but thank you.
In fact, I'm recommending you for a promotion. How does Lieutenant Alyssa Ogawa sound to you?
It sounds wonderful.
I'll talk to Commander Riker... I expect it'll be official as soon as the current crew evaluation is over.
Alyssa... I've been meaning to ask you -- how are things going with you and Lieutenant Powell?
Fine... I think.
You think?
I'm sure it's nothing... but he seems... preoccupied lately. Last night he had to cancel our date.
I see...
I know he's been putting together a research proposal... he's been really busy with it...
I can understand that. Sometimes I get so absorbed in my research I forget to eat.
I just wonder...
What?
I've never met anyone like Andrew. It's as though we've known each other forever...
You do seem well-suited.
But... I know that in the beginning of a romance... it's possible to be... a little blind.
I'm not sure exactly what you mean...
Well... cancelling a date like that... the way he's been so distant lately... Doctor... do you think those could be warning signs? That he's losing interest?
Alyssa... I think you may be overreacting.
Maybe so...
If I felt as strongly about someone as you do about Andrew -- he'd have to do a lot more than cancel one date before I became suspicious.
You're right...
As soon as this research project is over... I'm sure things will be just like they were.
Except, of course, that he'll have to deal with Lieutenant Ogawa.
I only filled in at Ops for half an hour, but I had to degauss the main deflector dish, recalibrate the navigation grid, and use the internal sensors to find a lost puppy.
Ops is a very different challenge from Tactical.
I can't figure out why I'm even being considered for the assignment... I'm a security officer.
I recommended you.
I'll try not to let you down, sir.
What could they be talking about?
Have you ever considered learning to lip read?
Do you think Worf's chewing her out?
No, he always looks like that.
Maybe he's giving her pointers on how to land the Ops position.
Hi, Wil.
Ben...
You call him Wil?
Why not?
He's second in command of this ship, that's why not.
I'm not Starfleet; I'm a civilian. And when he's in here, he wants to be treated like a civilian.
Riker? I bet he sleeps in his uniform.
You only think that because he's your C.O. If you got to know him --
Right.
He's convinced that Commander Riker doesn't "like" him.
Why? Did you crash the ship into something?
No. He just doesn't like me.
He doesn't even know you.
That's right. You should go talk to him.
About what?
Perhaps something you have in common?
He likes Jazz... poker... he's Canadian --
Yeah? My grandfather was from Canada.
There you go.
Hi --
Here...
I've got to go talk to somebody.
Good evening, sir...
Lavelle...
Can I do something for you?
No, sir. I... just came to get myself another drink.
Something wrong with that one?
Actually, I...
What are you having?
Trakian Ale.
Good choice. I'll have one, too.
My Grandfather was Canadian, you know.
Really...
Aren't you one, too?
A grandfather?
Canadian, sir. Canadian.
No. I grew up in Alaska.
Oh. Well... they both... get a lot of snow.
Good talking to you, sir.
We're holding position in the Argaya System.
Anything?
No, sir. I detect no vessels in the vicinity.
How close are we to the Cardassian border?
Less than five thousand kilometers.
Sir... I am detecting an object... five meters in length. It appears to be an escape pod.
They must have been forced to abandon ship.
How far inside Cardassian space is it?
Over fifty thousand kilometers.
How the hell are we going to get it out of there... ?
Sir, the pod's life-support system is failing.
Notify Doctor Crusher --
Can we get within Transporter range without crossing into Cardassian territory?
We would need to boost the gain on the confinement beam by at least seven percent.
Mister La Forge?
I'm on it, sir.
Try it now...
The pod is still too far away...
I'm going to try augmenting the frequency spread...
Bio-readings indicate that the passenger is humanoid... Attempting life-form identification --
No one asked you to do that, Ensign. Let's just get him aboard safely.
There, that should do it...
Confinement beam is at one hundred nine percent of normal.
Transporter room -- you should be able to get a lock now.
Aye, sir --
Doctor, are you ready?
Stand by.
Alyssa, I'm afraid I'm going to have to ask you to leave.
All right, Doctor.
Transporter room. go ahead.
What are you doing here?
I'm not supposed to let anyone but the senior officers inside Sickbay.
Do you have any idea what's going on?
No. Do you?
I better go.
Ensign...
Twelve hundred hours -- alpha shift is relieved...
Excuse me, sir.
If it's all right with you, I'd like to stay on for another shift. I could use the training.
Now's not the best time.
Yes, sir.
Ensign, you're with me.
Bridge.
You're a certified pilot, aren't you?
Yes, sir.
How long have you served on the Enterprise?
Seven months, sir.
I see... I understand you've been recommended for the Ops position. Do you think you're up to it?
I do, sir.
I'm not so sure. Your record concerns me.
Sir?
The incident you were involved in at the Academy.
With all due respect... that was three years ago. My record since then --
I'm not certain it matters how long it's been. What I need to know is whether you would ever do something like that again.
I can assure you, sir, I would never, never jeopardize lives by participating in --
A dare-devil stunt? I should hope not. What concerns me more is that you participated in a coverup that impeded an official investigation into the death of a cadet.
Sir, I know I should have told the truth right from the start --
But you didn't. You went along with the others and pretended that what happened was nothing more than an accident. What do you suppose that tells me about your character?

Sir, if you had any idea what it was like after that incident -- I didn't have any friends, anyone to talk to. I had to take my flighttest with the instructor because no one else would be my partner. In a lot of ways it would have been easier to just walk away. But I didn't. I stuck with it. Doesn't that say something about my character, too... ?

I'm very sorry you didn't enjoy your time at the Academy, Ensign. But as far as I'm concerned, you should have been expelled for what you did. Quite frankly, I don't know how you made it onto my ship.
You're dismissed...
Two more seconds... That's enough.
Sir, I'm a little puzzled. Why are we intentionally damaging this shuttlecraft?
We're evaluating hull resiliency. Starfleet requires periodic testing.
I see. I don't believe I'm familiar with that requirement.
Probably because you're not a senior officer.
If you wish, I can reconfigure the phaser to fire a low-intensity burst that would not harm the shuttle's hull. The test procedure would not be affected.
It's fine the way it is. Just give me a four second burst right about here.
Should I fire from this position?
Actually... Make it over there.
That would be consistent...
Consistent with what?
With making it appear that this shuttle fled an attack.
What makes you think that's what we're doing?
The pattern of fire you have asked for is similar to what might result if the shuttle were fleeing an attacker while engaging in evasive maneuvers.
That's quite a coincidence...
Yes, sir. It is indeed. Shall we proceed with the testing?
Yes, Ensign. Thank you.
Alyssa... thanks for coming so quickly.
We need to prepare for surgery. We have a comatose patient with a subdeural hematoma.
Yes, sir.
I want to make it clear that you are not to discuss what you see here with anyone.
I understand.
We'll need to synthesize at least a liter of Cardassian blood...
What I can't figure out is why we're just sitting here so close to the Cardassian border.
It must have something to do with that escape pod we picked up. Don't you think?
Maybe...
I wonder who was in it... ?
You know what I heard... ?
It was Ambassador Spock.
That is unlikely.
That's what I was told...
By whom?
I can't say.
They beamed whoever was in it right to Sickbay. Did you see anything when you went down there?
No... Doctor Crusher just wanted me to help her with the lab schedule.
I thought Lieutenant Powell was going to join us tonight?
He had to do a double shift.
That's too bad... He's the worst poker player I've ever met...
It's your bet, Sam.
Twenty.
-- the thing is, I saw Powell in Ten Forward with another woman... the way they were talking made me wonder...
He should tell Alyssa if he's seeing someone else. Even if it hurts her, it'll be better in the long run.
I've been meaning to tell you something, Worf... I don't think Ensign Sito is ready for the Ops position.
I must say that I disagree, sir.
I'm listening...
The bet is fifty --
It would be illogical for the Captain to deny you a promotion because of something you did as a cadet.
He said it shows I don't have character.
What did you say?
What could I say? Maybe he's right...
You're a damn fine officer and you deserve that post as much as anyone.
One thing's for sure -- I won't be getting it. Not if it's up to Riker.
It is your decision, sir -- but if you give her a chance to prove herself, I feel certain that Ensign Sito will not disappoint you.
All right, Worf. I'll keep her under consideration. Besides, I have my doubts about Lavelle.
Really? Why?
He's too... eager to please. He keeps trying to ingratiate himself to me.
Why assume he's doing it just to get the job?
I'll see your fifty and raise you a hundred.
I don't know... It seems to me that you and Lavelle have a lot in common.
What? We're not at all alike.
You're bluffing.
Think so?
Yes, and I'm not gonna let you get away with it.
You know, Sam, maybe you shouldn't try so hard with Riker. It doesn't matter whether he likes you... as long as he respects you.
And he must... otherwise he wouldn't be considering you for the Ops position.
You're probably right... maybe I'm just telling myself he hates me so if I don't get promoted I'll have an excuse.
Well? You in or not?
At this juncture, the odds of my winning this hand are less than thirty-nine to one. I fold.
Looks like it's just you and me, buddy. You in for another fifty?
Give me a minute. I'm thinking.
Didn't you tell me you took up poker so you could get into the officer's game on the Potemkin?
I happen to like poker.
But your senior officers might have thought you were trying to ingratiate yourself -- I guess they realized you were just young and inexperienced and decided not to hold it against you.
Maybe I am being too hard on Lavelle...
I do not believe he is bluffing.
I do. What've you got?
I can't believe this.
(as he takes in the chips) I'm your worst nightmare...
I knew it!
How could you tell I was bluffing?
You don't really expect me to answer that, do you... ?
Well... it's getting pretty late. Maybe we should all get some sleep.
One more hand --
Come on, Geordi. You're not going to quit just because I'm unbeatable?
There's something I need to do down in Engineering.
I'll get you next time.
I'll be waiting...
Good night, everybody.
Good night.
What I find curious is that when Commander La Forge saw that the technique I was proposing was more efficient, he seemed... annoyed.
Of course he was.
He didn't like the fact that you knew something he didn't.
Do you think I have irreparably damaged my relationship with him?
It depends on what kind of guy he is.
Ante up, gentlemen.
Come in.
Commander --
Don't get up. I just dropped by to see Taurik.
What can I do for you, sir?
I'm headed for Engineering to run those tests on the nacelles. Since you've already put in some work on the technique... I thought you might like to give me a hand.
I would be pleased to, sir.
Great. Let's go.
How about some blackjack?
I've got to get some sleep so I can be sharp tomorrow.
Why? So you can get promoted, have more responsibility, and have to get to sleep even earlier?
Good night...
Come in.
Ben --
I just cleaned out some junior officers and I thought I'd do the same here.
You're welcome to give it a try.
Pull up a chair.
Thanks --
Ensign Sito --
I also teach an advanced class -- I believe you may be ready to participate.
Before you can join the group, however, you must pass the... gik'tal.
Gik'tal?
It is a very ancient Klingon ritual. It tests your knowledge of the forms of the mok'bara.
I should practice first...
No. No practice. That is part of the ritual -- the test must be... unannounced.
Come.
Can you see?
No...
Ow!
You did not anticipate.
How am I supposed to defend myself when I can't see a thing?
Stop making excuses! Replace the blindfold.
No, this isn't a fair test.
Very good, Ensign. You have passed the challenge.
What? By taking off the blindfold?
It takes courage to say the test is not fair.
There's one thing I don't understand. Doesn't gik'tal mean "to the death"?
You... speak Klingon?
Sir... is there really such a thing as the gik'tal challenge?
No... there is not.
But perhaps the next time you are judged unfairly, you will not have to suffer so many bruises before you protest.

-- all I've ever wanted is to make a career for myself in Starfleet. I can't change what happened at the Academy. No one can. All I can do is work hard and try to earn the respect of the people I serve with.
If you're not going to give me that chance, then I respectfully request that you transfer me to another ship.
If you're looking for a more lenient commander, I don't think you'll find one.
Permission to speak freely, sir?
Please do.
If you didn't want me on your ship you should have said so when I was assigned to it.
It's not your place to punish me for what I did at the Academy.
I've worked hard here. My record is exemplary. If you're going to judge me, judge me for what I am now.
All right, Ensign. I will...
It took a lot of courage to come here and face me after what I said to you the other day.
You see... I didn't call you in here then to assess your qualifications for the Ops position.
I... don't understand.
I was harsh with you because I was assessing you for a very important mission. A mission that could involve a situation far more... unnerving than being dressed down by your commanding officer.
May I ask what this mission --
Join the senior staff in the Observation Lounge at oh-nine hundred hours. We'll discuss it then.
Yes, sir.
And Ensign... I do know how you ended up on the Enterprise. I asked for you.
I wanted to make sure you got a fair chance to redeem yourself.
You wanted to see me, Doctor?
Yes...
Alyssa, I think you know how much I've come to depend on you. I've recommended your promotion because your performance here has been exemplary.
Thank you, Doctor... I appreciate that.
But more than that, I've come to think of you as a friend. Someone I care about...
That's nice of you to say. I feel the same way.
So... I was wondering about you and Andrew Powell...
Someone told you!
Told me... ?
We were going to keep it a secret until the promotions are announced.
Secret... ?
He asked me to marry him.
Alyssa -- that's wonderful!
I'm so relieved...
I mean -- happy.
Have a seat, Ensign.
This is Joret Dal... he was in the escape pod we retrieved.
Joret is a member of the Cardassian military... he is also a Federation operative.

He risked his life to come here and give us invaluable information about Cardassia's strategic intentions -- information that could very well enhance the security of Bajor, as well as other planets in this sector. It is imperative that we get him safely back to Cardassian space.
It will not be easy. The border is heavily guarded.
Since his ship was destroyed he's going to have to take one of our shuttlecraft.
If a patrol stops me, I will claim to have stolen it.
We have distressed the shuttle so that it appears to have been fired on.
Joret's going to have to try and talk his way past the patrol.
If I were alone, the chances of my succeeding would be slim. But if I had a prisoner with me... a Bajoran terrorist...
I would appear to be a bounty hunter. Border crossings of that nature are not uncommon... for a price, the patrol can be convinced to look the other way.
Once the shuttle is safely past the patrol, Joret will put you in an escape pod and send you back across the border.
Since the pod is so small, it shouldn't be detectable.
We'll be waiting here to pick you up.
I understand, sir.
This is obviously a very dangerous mission. I'm not ordering you to take part in it.
Then I'll volunteer, sir.
Be certain you understand the risk you are taking. If you are captured --
I'm Bajoran. No one knows better than I do what the Cardassians do to their prisoners.
I've made my decision.
Very well, Ensign. Report to Sickbay. Doctor Crusher will explain.
I'd also ask you not to discuss this mission with anyone...
Yes, sir.
I didn't realize she would be so... young...
The Captain asked Doctor Crusher to make it look like Joret had mistreated me...
We're all set...
Sir... I want you to know that I really appreciate the fact that you've always had confidence in me.
Good luck...
I'll see you soon...
We are approaching the border... it won't be long before we're detected by the patrol ships.
When they stop us... do you want me to say anything?
No. It should seem that I've broken your will. If you're asked any questions, look at me... as though you're afraid to answer.
Can I ask you something... ? Why are you doing this -- risking your life to help Starfleet?
I don't consider myself a traitor, if that's what you're asking.

I've served in the military all my life... once it was an institution dedicated to the security of Cardassia, now it's little more than... a platform for ambitious Guls hoping to make their reputations in battle.
If the information I provide helps Starfleet deter even one pointless border skirmish, I'll have served my purpose. I'm sick of war. My people need peace.
I never thought I'd hear a Cardassian say something like that...
And I never thought a Bajoran would risk her life to help a Cardassian get home...
A patrol ship is closing in on our position...
We don't have much time...
She must have left on that shuttle, there's no other explanation.
Do you have any idea where it went?
Toward Cardassian space -- that's what I'm worried about.
There's another thing, I noticed the shuttle was damaged --
Sam, can we talk about something else?
Don't you care what's happened to her?
Of course --
But we have to accept the fact that we're not always told about everything that happens aboard ship.
We can at least tell each other what we know.
Do you two know something?
Sam, please...
I can't believe this. We're friends.
We're also Starfleet Officers.
I'm not allowed to talk about it...
Okay... I understand.
I better get going... I'm on duty in half an hour...
Report.
We've completed a long-range scan of the area, sir. The escape pod doesn't seem to be out there.
It is possible that at this distance we are simply unable to distinguish the pod from the inorganic matter normally present in space.
Try narrowing the scan field -- see if you can pick up any biosigns.
Sir... it would help if I knew what kind of life-signs to look for.
You're scanning for Bajoran lifesigns, Ensign.
Yes, sir.
Nothing yet, sir. The pod's thirty-two hours overdue.
Sir, I recommend we launch a probe to increase the range of our sensor sweeps.
Sending a probe into Cardassian space would be a treaty violation.
Prepare a probe and launch when ready.
Aye, sir.
It will be several minutes before we begin to receive the probe's telemetry.
Sir... I am detecting signs of debris two hundred thousand kilometers inside Cardassian space...
(continuing, off console) Its mass and composition indicate that it could be the remains of a Federation escape pod...

Captain's Log, supplemental. We have intercepted a Cardassian report stating that a Bajoran prisoner escaped her captor... and was killed in an evacuation pod as she tried to leave Cardassian space...
To all personnel with security clearance J-one and higher... this is the Captain. It is my sad duty to inform you --
-- that a member of the crew... Ensign Sito Jaxa...
Has been lost in the line of duty...
She was the finest example of a Starfleet officer... a young woman of remarkable courage... and strength of character.
Her absense will be deeply felt by all who knew her...
You okay... ?
Hi...
I just got promoted...
Congratulations...
Thanks...
I just don't feel right about it... for all I know, she was going to get the promotion instead of me.
You shouldn't feel that way, Sam.
She would have been happy for you.
The best way to remember her... would be to excel in your new position.
We're proud of you, Sam.
Excuse me, sir... but I need to move this table.
What?
There's an empty seat over there.
I appreciate what you are trying to do, but it is not... appropriate. You were her friends. I was only her commanding officer...
Sir... I happen to know that she considered you a friend.

-- as time passes, a boy inevitably becomes a man. What is not inevitable, is that a man become a warrior. A warrior must be forged like a sword, tempered by... -- by experience. The path of the warrior begins --
Alexander --
Come in.
No, wait --
Sorry. I didn't mean to hit you.
What is the meaning of this?
I'm sorry. We made Fullerenes in chemistry class and filled them with water --
I asked you to meet me here after school. I have been waiting for you.
I forgot.
You forgot because you allowed yourself to be distracted by foolishness.
I'm sorry.
There is something important I want to discuss with you.
As time passes, a boy inevitably becomes a man. What is not inevitable, is that a man become a sword --
What?
I meant warrior...
The path of the warrior begins with the First Rite of Ascension.
Is that where they hit you with pain sticks?
No, that is the Second Rite.
Oh...
You are approaching the age of ascension... it is time for you to prepare for the ceremony.
What do I have to do?
Your fighting skills will be tested... and your knowledge of the teachings of Kahless. It is very challenging, but I will help you prepare.
This is a kor'tova candle... it represents the fire that burns in a warrior's heart.
When you light yours, you will be declaring your intention to become a warrior.
Go ahead.
What if... I don't want to?
If you do not participate in the rite before you are thirteen years of age, you will never be able to become a true Klingon warrior.
I don't care about that...
You may not care now, but someday you might.
Mother always said that I didn't have to do any of this Klingon stuff if I didn't want to.
It is your decision... but --
Good, then I'm not going to do it.
Alexander --
You just said it was up to me. And I don't want to be a warrior.
As a result, the Kearsarge won't be able to rendezvous with us for another four days.
Will we be holding position here until it arrives?
Yes. And, as it looks as though we'll have a few days of relative quiet, I'm going to take advantage of the time by visiting the Hatarian System. There are ancient ruins there just being excavated.
The delay will also make it possible for Stellar Dynamics to complete their study of the Vodrey Nebula.
I'll let them know they can have more access to the lateral sensor grid.
This might be a good time to recalibrate the weapon targeting array.
Mister Worf?
Yes, sir. I will begin the procedure immediately.
Very good. Dismissed.
Lieutenant... could I have a word with you?
Several times during the briefing you seemed a bit... distracted.
I apologize. In the future, I will make sure my personal affairs do not interfere with my duties.
Is everything all right?
I... am having problems with Alexander. He has made it clear that he does not wish to participate in the First Rite of Ascension.
I see...
I have tried to tell him that it is an important part of a young Klington's life, but he does not understand...
He's had so little opportunity to spend time among Klingons... I doubt if he fully appreciates what a rich cultural heritage he comes from.

The festival of Kot'baval begins tomorrow. If he could take part in it, he would see that there is much more to Klingon life than what I have been able to show him... if only we were nearer the homeworld.
What about the Klingon outpost on Maranga Four... I'm sure they'll celebrate the festival there.
Yes... but the outpost is on the far side of the Vodrey Nebula, it is three days away by shuttle...
The Enterprise could be there in a fraction of that time, and still be back here for our rendezvous.
Sir, I could not ask you to --
I'm willing to bet Stellar Dynamics would like nothing better than to make a trip around the Nebula; it'll give them the chance to study it that much more thoroughly.
Bok'ta ku'mo.
Who's that?
That is the tyrant Molor. He was so strong that no one could stand against him.
Nok'tar be'got, hosh'ar te'not... ?
What's he saying?
He is asking if anyone else will have the courage to stand up to Molor...
Nok'tar be'got... ?
Ki'rok Molor, ki'rok!
Ni'tokor bak'to!
Ba'jak tu'mo!
O'tak tu'ro!
Nok'tar be'got?
Hosh'ar te'not?
Ki'rok Molor, ki'rok!
What's this... ?
Jik'ta! You have wounded me!
You fought well.
What happens now?
Only one man can stand against Molor.
It's Kahless!
Nok'til Kahless. Molor gik'tal!
Kahless would rather die than live under Molor's tyranny...
Ni'lot Kahless!
Father --
Where have you been?
We were watching the fire dancers.
We?
K'Nor and Bar'el -- they live here on the outpost. I need some money.
What for?
There's a man over there who's got Molor's head in a box -- the real Molor.
That is impossible. Molor died centuries ago.
I know -- it's mummified. He said he'd show it to us for fifty darseks.
He is trying to take your money.
Please, Father. He's waiting.
No. It is late. We should go home.
But --
Alexander.
Come, it is time to go.
I have to say goodbye.
You can see your friends again tomorrow.
We're coming back?
If you want to.
Alexander, run --
Ni'tokor bak'to!
K'pla, Worf. They were no match for us.
I've seen you somewhere before. Who are you?
A friend...
Are you... K'mtar?
Your brother sent me here to protect you...
He is gin'tak to the house of Mogh...
Gin'tak?
An advisor so trusted that he is made part of a family.
Do you have any idea who was behind the attack?
It is a Klingon matter. Not your concern.
One of my officers was almost killed. That makes it my concern.
Recently rumors began to circulate on the homeworld that an assassination attempt was going to be made against the family of Mogh. Kurn sent me to make sure nothing happened to Worf.
Why didn't you warn him before the attack was made?
I tried to contact him by subspace, but was told Worf wasn't aboard. I decided to beam directly to the surface.
One of the attackers dropped this dagger. The design... represents the house of Duras.
We have other evidence that indicates the Duras sisters, Lursa and B'Etor, were behind the attack.
What do you think they're after?
Kurn's seat on the council, of course.
We can not allow their attack on our house to go unanswered.
First we have to find them... and they've been elusive.
At one point they were at Deep Space Nine, trying to sell bilitrium explosives.
That was months ago. No one knows where they went from there.
Maybe we can find out. We've arranged quarters for you, if you'd like to stay aboard.
I would. Worf and I have much to discuss.
I'll send Kurn a message telling him what happened, but it will be days before he receives it -- he's gone to the Hitora colony as Gowron's representative.
K'mtar, why did you treat Commander Riker so disrespectfully?
You were... rude.
I may have been rude by human standards, but I meant no disrespect.
What's the matter Worf, have you been living among humans so long that you've forgotten how Klingons behave?
I have not forgotten... I am merely pointing out that their ways our different from ours.
I trust you've made your son aware of that fact, as well?
Of course I have.
Good. Because someday Alexander may be called upon to lead the house of Mogh. Kurn has no male heir, and he wants to be sure that Alexander is preparing himself.
Does my brother doubt my ability to raise my son as a Klingon?
No. But you are alone among humans. It cannot be easy to keep our ways.
No... it has not been easy.
How are his fighting skills? Can he handle a Bat'leth?
He is learning... he could be better.
He must be. He's not far from the age of ascension.
Actually... Alexander has not committed himself to undergoing the rite.
What?
I have tried to make him see how important it is, but he will not listen to me.
Perhaps together, you and I can find a way to spark the boy's interest in his heritage.
I would be grateful for any help you could give.
Tomorrow, then.
May I say goodnight to him?
Of course.
Is this your mother?
She died when I was little.
You miss her a great deal, don't you... ?
It must be hard for you... being the only Klingon your age on board this ship.
Sometimes...
Have you ever been to the homeworld?
No...
I think you'd like it there. At your uncle's house there is a lake where you can swim. The water is so clear you can see to the bottom.
Really?
And you have cousins there. They want to meet you.
I don't know...
I understand. You're afraid... you don't know if the Home World is safe.
Yes...
What happened today... on the planet... was frightening. You're still troubled...
I thought they were going to kill my father.
You must have wanted to help us fight them off.
I didn't know what to do...

Someday, if you work hard, you'll be a warrior... a Klingon warrior, and you'll always feel safe because you'll know how to defend yourself. And do you know what else? If anyone ever tries to hurt your father again, you'll be able to fight at his side and make sure nothing happens to him. What do you think of that?
Good night, Alexander. Dream well.
Good night, K'mtar.
Any luck?
Starfleet records contain no mention of the Duras sisters after their departure from Deep Space Nine.
Didn't I tell you as much?
Have you been able to make contact with Deep Space Nine?
I am being patched through now, sir...
On screen.
Quark...
I see you remember me.
How could I forget the only man ever to win triple down dabo at one of my tables... ?
And how could I forget that you didn't have enough latinum to cover my winnings?
I thought I explained that my brother had misplaced the key to the safe. Besides, those vouchers I gave you are every bit as good as latinum.
Not exactly. You can spend latinum just about anywhere. Those vouchers are only good at your bar.
I look forward to seeing you upon your return... Is that what this is about... you're on your way and you're calling to reserve a Holosuite program... ?
Actually, I was hoping you could help me with something else.
What would that be... ?
I'm looking for some Klingon friends of mine... the Duras sisters -- Lursa and B'Etor?
Oh, yes... Lursa and B'Etor... Big talk... small tips.
I thought you might know where they went.
Me? What makes you think I'd know... ?
Commander Sisko said if anyone would know, you would...
He flatters me. Well... I did hear a rumor, actually...
What kind of rumor?
I don't know... I'm sure it was told to me in confidence...
And how much is your "confidence" worth?
How many vouchers do you have, again?
Enough for twelve bars of latinum.
I'll be glad to return them.
Ah. I believe the rumor was... that the sisters were trying to buy some second-hand mining equipment.
What for?
They learned of a magnesite deposit in the Kalla system... it belongs to the Pakleds, but those fools don't even know it's there. Your friends were trying to get at it.
All right. I'll send you those vouchers...
Don't bother... I voided them while we've been talking.
So long, Quark...
How long would it take us to reach the Kalla system?
Approximately sixteen hours.
Couldn't he have been lying?
Why would he? I'd just end up knocking on his door again in a few days -- and I wouldn't be in as good a mood.
I congratulate you, Commander. I didn't think it would be possible to find the sisters.
Take us out of orbit.
Today we will work on the Koh'manara block... it is a combination of the koh'bala pivot and the pak'ara thrust -- the forms I taught you last week.
Yes, Father...
Alexander, have I not taught you to treat your sword with respect?
You're not looking forward to training, are you?
Not really...
It can be boring repeating the same moves over and over again.
You must master the forms before you can apply them.
That's true, but I was thinking we might try something different today.
I took the liberty of creating a Holodeck program.
What kind of program?
I'll show you...
Computer... run program K'mtar alpha-one.
Program initiated. Enter when ready.
Why did you want to recreate this?
You said you wished you'd been able to help your father fight, but you didn't know how...
You've probably thought about the attack over and over again.
Yes...
Then let's see what happens this time.
Computer, give us two Klingon warriors.
How can I fight somebody that big?
It is not size that matters. Cunning... skill... and observation are the most important weapons.
(continuing, a battle cry) Ni'tokor bak'to!
Freeze program.
Look what this ko'tal is doing. See his legs, they give a clue to what his next move will be.
His weight is all on his right foot.
Yes, he's going to have to shift it to regain his balance.
Stand ready. Computer, resume program.
Po'tajg!
Finish him.
Freeze program.
You should have killed him when you had the chance.
Why didn't you?
I... I don't know...
Look at him! He didn't care that you showed him mercy. He was going to kill you.
K'mtar... enough.
If this were real he'd be dead now.
Alexander --
We are approaching Kalla Three.
Assume a standard orbit. Any evidence of a mining operation?
A shaft has been cut through the outer crust... there is evidence of machinery, but it does not appear to be in use.
Life signs?
It is difficult to say. The magnesite is interfering with bioreadings.
Assemble an Away Team.
Who are you?
Gorta... I'm Gorta...
What are you doing on this planet?
I... crashed here.
Then you are denying involvement in illegal mining activities.
(as if he's realizing only now) Mining? So that's what all this equipment is for...
I suspect that you are feigning ignorance.
What a thing to say.
We are looking for two Klingon women, sisters --
Lursa! B'Etor? Do you know where they are?
Actually we were hoping you did.
Maybe I do...
Would you be willing to share your information with us?
My personal code of conduct prohibits sharing. But I'd consider a trade...
Does your personal code of conduct tell you that when you're stranded on a planet with no way off, you shouldn't try to cut deals?
You have a point.
We could certainly provide you with passage off this planet in exchange for information.
Could you perhaps... fail to tell the Pakleds that we were mining their ore?
Don't push your luck. But if you can get us to the Duras sisters, I'll see what I can do.
The Duras sisters... they are magnificent, aren't they?
Where are they now?
Selling the ore, I imagine. They took everything, the ore, the ship... Such treachery... I can't help but adore them.
What kind of ship do they have?
A Bird of Prey. With a working cloaking device. Who knows how they got hold of that...
And where have they gone?
We were going to sell the ore to a Yridian trader. We were supposed to meet him in the Ufandi system.
Gather your belongings. It is time to leave.
Like I said... they took everything.
Worf...
I'm sorry about what happened. I shouldn't have gotten so angry. It's just that... I'm worried about Alexander.
As am I.
Kurn told me that his mother actively discouraged him from exploring his Klingon heritage...
When he came to live with me, he knew nothing of our ways. He often reminds me of things his mother said to him... I try not to disregard her wishes, I want him to honor her memory...
Someday... I'm sure he'll appreciate you. And be grateful for all you've given him.
Still, compared to other boys his age, Alexander's fighting skills are years behind.
I know. He has not put in the time he needs to learn the skills.
I think you should consider sending him to the training Academy on Ogat. Your brother is an influential man; he could see to it that Alexander was admitted.
Send him... to Ogat?
I'm only thinking of what's best for him. At the Academy he'd learn our ways, he'd live like a Klingon.
I want him to learn our ways, but... this is his home.
How can you expect him to lead our house someday when all he's known is life aboard a Federation starship?
He is my son; he belongs with me.
The boy is more human than Klingon. If he stays here, he'll never be a warrior. He'll never be able to defend our family against its enemies.
Enough... the decision is mine.
Not necessarily. It would be within my rights to invoke ya'nora kor.
You would challenge my fitness to raise my own son?
For the good of our house, yes.
Worf... I beg you... stop thinking of yourself. It's Alexander we must consider. Look into your heart... and do what's best for him.
-- if K'mtar invoked ya'nora kor, your vote would cancel his, and it would be up to your brother to decide who would get custody of Alexander.
I am confident my brother would not vote against me.
You don't sound confident...
Perhaps I should let Alexander know what is at stake... it might induce him to spend more time training.
I'm not sure that's a good idea... it might scare him.
I should have tried harder... I should have taken him to visit the homeworld...
Worf... Alexander is part human, and that part of him is every bit as important as his Klingon side. I think you've done a wonderful job of exposing him to both sides of his heritage.
But by doing that, I may have made it impossible for him to be accepted as a true Klingon.
There are those who'd say you're not a true Klingon, just because you wear that uniform.
The truth is you've found a balance within yourself, a balance that feels right to you. You have to trust that Alexander will be able to find his own balance. Just as you did.
Part of me wants to give him that freedom... but what if he turns away from his Klingon heritage? What will happen to my father's house? Who will lead it?

-- Kahless was determined to teach his brother a lesson for having told a lie, but Morath refused to fight his brother, and instead ran away. Kahless pursued him across valleys and over mountains, all the way to the edge of the sea. And there on the shore, they fought for --
Twelve days and twelve nights. I know, I've heard this story before.
Alexander, it is important to tell these stories, even if we already know them.
Why was Kahless so mad about the lie his brother told?
Because it made him look like a coward.
If Kahless had just let him explain what happened, maybe they wouldn't have had to fight about it.
You are missing the point --
And I don't see what's so wrong with running away -- maybe Morath didn't want to fight his brother because he didn't want to have to kill him.
He ran because he was a coward --
How do you know that's why?
No more questions! These are our stories. A warrior must learn how to interpret them properly.
I'm trying to --
No, your head is full of foolish human notions about the way things are. You are Klingon. You must begin to act like one.
I'm part human, too.
Listen to me, Alexander... when a human looks at you, he doesn't see himself, he sees a Klingon.
It doesn't matter what I look like.
It does. You're different from everyone aboard this ship. And no matter how much people pretend otherwise, they'll always see you as different.
That's not true...
It is. The only way you'll ever feel like you really belong, is if you leave here and go live with your own kind.
I know a Klingon school you could go to; you'd be welcome there. They'd teach you how to be a warrior -- prepare you for the Rite of Ascension.
I don't know if I want to do that...
After you've been there a while... you'll find you won't want to do anything else.
But I don't want to leave the Enterprise --
You must! Everything depends on it.
I thought you were different. I thought you understood me. But you don't. You're just like my Father. All you care about is me becoming a warrior. Why don't you just leave me alone!
First Officer's Log, stardate 47779.4. We've entered the Ufandi system, where we believe the Duras sisters might have come to sell the ore they mined on Kalla Three.
I am detecting a vessel holding position near the third planet... It is a Yridian freighter.
Put it on screen.
Scan for magnesite in its hold.
The resonance signature indicates that there is magnesite ore present...
Then we're too late. The sisters have already been here.
Somehow I doubt the Yridians are going to be very forthcoming about where they might have gone...
Sir, readings indicate that there are only five hundred kilograms of ore in the Yridian's hold...
There should be over ten thousand kilograms...
That's odd... Hail them.
I'm Commander Riker of the Federation Starship Enterprise.
I am Yog... why are we speaking?
Our sensors indicate you're carrying magnesite ore...
Magnesite, yes.
Where did you get it?
From a Corvallen. For a good price.
Where's this... Corvallen now? I have orders to acquire some magnesite.
He is gone... Where? I don't know.
Wouldn't you be interested in selling me the ore you're carrying?
No, I have a buyer.
You haven't heard my offer.
Half a gram of Anjoran bio-mimetic gel.
Done.
Once we've verified the ore's purity, we'll beam over the gel.
You're up to something...
Have the Transporter Room beam the ore to these coordinates.
Sir, that would place the ore directly off the ship's starboard bow.
I know.
Transport complete.
Lock phasers on the ore and fire.
Firing.
A Bird of Prey...
Put a tractor beam on it.
How did you know?
The Yridians had only part of the shipment in their hold -- I realized we must've arrived before they had the chance to transfer the rest.
Sir, the Klingon ship is hailing us.
On screen.
Release our vessel at once!
I don't think so.
We've done nothing wrong. We were engaging in a simple business transaction.
We know you're dealing in stolen ore.
But what I really want to talk about is the assassination attempt on Lieutenant Worf.
What assassination attempt? This is the first I've heard of it.
Did it succeed?
We have evidence that you were behind it.
That is outrageous.
What is this evidence?
Beam over and we'll show you.
We will be there shortly.
This was dropped by one of the assassins...
It bears the crest of your house.
Ge'ko... kaf'la. (It's true. How can this be?)
Someone must have given it to the assassins -- to implicate us.
Why would someone do that?
In order to tarnish our good name.
You can't tarnish a rusted blade...
Ji'ko to'val!
Gir'nak tovo'sor!
Mister Worf --
You said you had other evidence they were involved.
Yes... on the homeworld.
Then we'll set a course there. I want this cleared up.
I will send a message to Kurn... he may wish to return to the homeworld as well.
Bet'ala nog'tor.
Impossible...
What is it?
These markings represent the members of our house... This symbol represents our father... Myself, my sister... and this... represents her son.
I was not aware you had a son.
I do not... But I am with child...
She found out only a few days ago... and she's told no one but me.
How can this marking be here? Where did this come from... ?
I will talk to K'mtar.
No further.
K'mtar... why are you doing this?
Step away from the door.
You will have to kill me.
I won't do that. But I can stun you -- then kill the boy.
What?
I... am Alexander.
What... are you saying?
I... am your son... Alexander... I have come to this time from forty years in the future.
P'tak! Tell me the truth or I will kill you.
Look at me!
You said when you first met me that I looked familiar.
I could have seen you on the Homeworld...
No. Look closely. I am your son.
If you are Alexander... you will remember the final words your mother said as she died.

I was three years old. She was dying when we found her. She barely managed to whisper my name... and she took my hand... and placed it in yours. Then she died. You howled with rage... and then you told me to look at her... to look at death... and always to remember. And I always have.
How... have you done this? Come to this time?
Forty years from now the ways are well known. But few are willing to risk the dangers. I decided I must take the risk.
And you did it... in order to end your own life?
I was hoping I wouldn't have to... that I could change things, change myself. But I couldn't. Everything's going to turn out the way it did before. And I can't let that happen.
Why? What is going to happen that is so terrible?
You will be killed. Because I was naive... too weak... to be able to protect you.
I don't believe that...
I was there! I saw you murdered... and I was to blame.
You mustn't blame yourself.
You don't understand -- I never became a warrior! I became a diplomat... a "peacemaker."

When the time came for me to lead our family -- I thought I could single-handedly put an end to the fighting between the great houses... I declared publicly that the house of Mogh would take the first step to end the feuding. There would be no more retribution, no more revenge.

You tried to warn me... you tried to tell me that I mustn't show weakness... but I thought you were a foolish old man. I told you that you were a relic of an earlier time, and that a new era of peace was at hand.
But you were right. My enemies saw my weakness... and they moved against me.
Unless I stop it all now... -- that boy will see his father killed on the floor of the Council Chamber.
That's why you wanted to take Alexander away. To turn him into a warrior, not a peacemaker.
I staged the assassination attempt to frighten him... make him realize he must learn the ways of a warrior.
If I had listened to you... if I had become the warrior you wanted... you would not have died in my arms.
Who is to say what the future will be now, after you have disrupted time? I may die tomorrow... or I may outlive you.
But when I die... I would like an honorable death. And the only way that is possible -- is for you accept yourself, as you are, and stay true to what you believe.
The cause of peace is a worthy one... go back, and continue to work for it. Your struggle must continue.
But it is a futile struggle...
No... you've already changed things more than you realize.
The boy I was has not changed...
I'm talking about myself.
You have given me a glimpse into my son's future. I see now that he has his own destiny... and I believe it will be a great one...
I love you, Father...
And I you, Alexander...
I've been waiting -- where's K'mtar?
He had to leave... he was called away...
He never said goodbye.
He asked me to say goodbye for him.
He wanted me to tell you that no matter what happens, no matter what you decide to do with your life, he'll always care about you a great deal.
When will I see him again?
It may be a long time...
We should start practice...
Alexander... there will be plenty of time for training. Why don't we... just spend some time together?
Come in.
Excellent. Exactly what I need.
Well, Doctor, and bearing gifts?
Ale from Ennan Six... your omelets deserve no less.
This is not an efficient method for the preparation of sustenance.

You're right, Data. The ship's computer is much more efficient, but it lacks the subtlety needed for great cooking. It mixes the ingredients to precise measurements. There's no flair, no individuality, and Data, as we both know... inspiration and flair are the difference between artistry and mere competence.

For much of the history of mankind, the breaking of bread was a sign of friendship and community. Something we have gotten away from in the twenty-fourth century. (re: Riker and the whisk) You have a practiced hand, Commander.
I have my father to thank for that.
Oh, your father liked to cook?
No, he hated it. It was a chore left to me.
It is my understanding that in most human families, the woman shares in the cooking.
There were only the two of us. I never knew my mother. She died when I was very young.
Where did you get the eggs?
During our last stop.
At Starbase seventy-three?
Yes.
What kind of eggs did you say these are?
'Owon.
A cook's only as good as his ingredients.
Delicious.
Commander Riker...
Yes, Captain.
Would you join me on the bridge?
On my way.
We have picked up an automated signal from a Federation shuttlecraft.
A shuttle? Out here?! How is that possible? We're the first manned Federation vessel to enter this area.
Apparently not.
So what's a shuttle doing out this far? And where's the mother ship?
I don't know.
Sensors indicate there is at least one life-form on board the shuttle. Humanoid.
Perhaps someone to answer your questions, Number One. Open hailing frequencies.
Captain, the shuttle is without power. Communication is not possible.
Set course to intercept.
Estimate intercept in three minutes.

Captain's log, stardate 42679.2. While traversing an unexplored section of the galaxy en route to the Endicor system, a Federation shuttlecraft has quite suddenly appeared -- virtually out of nowhere. There are no other ships in the vicinity -- and no indications whence it came nor how it got out here.
We are closing on shuttlecraft.
On screen.
Magnify.
Prepare to lock tractor beam.
Target vehicle -- we will be within tractor beam range in two zero seconds.
Set automatic locking device. Alert Shuttle Bay Two.
Locking tractor beam.
The tractor beam has been locked.
Number One.
Worf -- you're with me.
Doctor Pulaski, you are needed in Shuttle Bay Two.
I have been monitoring. I am on my way.
Well, it's a Federation shuttle all right.
Yet, there are no Federation vessels or bases in this area.
NCC one-seven-zero-one-D -- USS Enterprise, shuttle number five.
NCC one-seven-zero-one-D -- USS Enterprise shuttle number five.
How is this possible?
Commander! Come here!
(he touches his communicator) Captain?
What is it, Number One?
Captain, are you on the bridge?
Where else would I be?
Right now, I think you had better be in Shuttle Bay Two.
Why? What is it?
This you had better see for yourself and, Captain, bring Commander Data.
We have been in a lot of bizarre situations, but nothing like this.
What's his condition?
The life signs are confusing. I get a strong heartbeat, but the rhythm is off.
Has he been injured?
No signs of trauma.
Then why is he unconscious? What happened to him?
I can't say.
The readings from his brain waves are very... strange.
Strange? In what way? Non-human? Artificial?
No -- neither. They are just out of phase.
Can you revive him?
I won't attempt it until he's in Sickbay. (she holds the look for a beat, then:) Let's get him there.
Counselor.

I have never felt anything quite like this so it is difficult to put into words. (she pauses to gather her thoughts) That person is you. What I mean, the person we are looking at is as much Jean-Luc Picard as the person I am standing next to; beyond that there's very little of which I am sure. I will have to wait until he is conscious before knowing more.
Data, we have to know what is on the shuttle's logs.
Yes, sir.
Both primary and reserve power has been drained from the shuttle. I am going to have to connect to the Enterprise in order to activate the shuttle's systems.
Lieutenant La Forge -- report to Shuttle Bay Two.
I'm on my way.
Number One, I'll be in Sickbay. Keep me informed.
(indicating an unusual burn on the skin of the shuttle) Did you see this, Captain?
It looks like the kind of damage caused by an antimatter explosion.
Yes, the shuttle must have been just out of range.
Data, I need those logs. Counselor.
We'll be on the bridge.
Resume course and speed. Scanners at maximum range.
Maximum range.
You should have power now.
What happened?
The polarity was not compatible.
Not possible, the connection is idiot proof.
The power requirements of the shuttle do not match the Enterprise. We are going to need a variable phase inverter, to align the power from the Enterprise to the circuits of the shuttle.
Data, what do you think is going on? I don't just mean about the shuttle, I mean about all of this?
I do not have enough information.
The captain here, the captain there. This shuttle -- that shuttle. Commander Riker is right -- this is very strange.
This smells like a set-up.
A trap?
If it is me, me from where? And why in a shuttle? There is nothing about this which is random or happenstance. Look beneath the boards, Counselor; I expect something foul and familiar to crawl out.

We have just started doing a complete work-up. The vital signs are distorted. Some of the indicators are totally depressed, others are fluctuating wildly. I can't explain any of it. But he is alive, and I don't think he's in any immediate danger.
The restraints are for his own protection.
Have you been able to determine why he is still unconscious?
I have been able to rule out head injury -- otherwise there is no apparent cause.
Wake him.
What happened?
Apparently a normal stimulant had the opposite effect. I'll have to try something else.
There... that should give you something. Making this power adjustment is very tricky. By all rights, this connection should overload all the shuttle's circuits.
Perhaps you had better step back out of the way.
Remember you're not indestructible yourself.
Increase the power.
Adjust the invert two percent positive.
That's the correct decision, but it's having the opposite effect.
Yes.
There is nothing I can think of which could cause such a radical change in this circuit.
Adjust the invert two percent negative.
Got it. It shouldn't work, but it does.
(continuing; stunned) Data, take a look at the stardate.
Four-two-six-seven-nine-point-five. (he touches his communicator) Captain.
Go ahead.
Captain, we have been able to activate the shuttle; the on-board clock indicates that the shuttle is six hours ahead of us.
Captain, did you read me? If the shuttle is from six hours into the future, so is the other Captain Picard.

Captain's log, supplemental. Part of the mystery has been solved. The reason there are two NCC one-seven-zero-one-D-five shuttlecrafts is because one of them is from the future... six hours to be exact. And, so presumably is the facsimile of me.
Try to wake him, again.
No!
It's a only a sedative.
I know what it is... don't sedate him. Let him be! (then, changing his tone) Please... allow him to remain conscious.
I have never seen anything like this.
Captain, you had better sit down.
I'm fine, Doctor... Save your ministrations for the patient. I want a staff meeting in five minutes. Doctor, I assume you will want to remain here.
I will monitor the conference from here.
Keep me informed, Doctor -- of any change no matter how small.
Captain, we have retrieved all we are going to get from the shuttle logs, including the last visual records. Everything before this is just a jumble.
Proceed.
The distortion is because we had to use a phase inverter to retrieve the logs. It will improve slightly.
According to the shuttle log, the Enterprise was destroyed three hours, nineteen minutes from now.
Captain, we have a portion of your last log entry.
Proceed.
It's audio only.
Captain's personal log, supplemental. For the record... I have just witnessed the total destruction of the USS Enterprise with a loss of all hands, save one. Me.
That last sound apparently occurred when the shuttle was thrown back in time.
All attempts to obtain additional information from the shuttle's logs have failed.
At least now we have something to go on.
I can't understand how you could end up in a shuttlecraft while the Enterprise is being destroyed.
Nor I, the last thing you would do is leave the bridge of the Enterprise during an emergency.

Yes, but let's proceed on the premise that what we have just seen is factual and that somehow, in less than four hours, the Enterprise will be destroyed and somehow -- although this is unfathomable -- I, and I alone escaped. Discussion.

Our destination is the Endicor system. We are not due to arrive for three days. The charts indicate nothing of consequence, certainly nothing which could threaten the Enterprise, between here and there.
Sensors indicated no other vessels -- Federation or otherwise -- in this area.
Data?
I have nothing to offer. There is not enough information upon which I can base a hypothesis.
Well, the shuttle apparently came from somewhere up ahead. Rather than continuing on this course, perhaps we should stop here and let whatever is out there come and find us.
I think it's already too late for that.
Are you saying that stopping, turning left, or right, or even reversing course, is pointless?
When we brought the shuttle and the other Picard on board, we committed ourselves to a sequence of events which may be unalterable.
Yes, this isn't a rock in the road which once seen can be avoided. It's much more complex.
There is the theory of the moebius, a twist in the fabric of space where time becomes a loop from which there is no escape.

So, when we reach that moment -- whatever happened will happen again... The Enterprise will be destroyed, the "other Picard" sent back to meet with us and do it all over again. That sounds like someone's definition of hell.
I know this much -- we can't avoid the future.

Agreed. So let's continue on course. Everyone return to your duty stations. Somewhere out there something will happen... a decision will be made which will cause me to become separated from the Enterprise -- at the time that decision will seem correct, but it won't be. We have to anticipate and not make the same mistake once. Something is waiting for us out there -- let's determine what it is as quickly as possible.
Data -- I think the molecular structure of the shuttle has changed!
Your assessment is accurate.
Why now?
Perhaps it always was unstable and it was only by leaving and coming back that you were able to see the change.
Doctor?

I am beginning to realize just how much of the body is held together by its own internal clock. You -- he was thrown out of time, which caused the body systems to change their rhythms. Slowly, as we move closer to the time he left, the internal body clocks are realigning.
You're saying, when our time intersects with the time he left, at that instant he will be functioning normally. And there will be two of us.
Right now, that would be my guess.
I don't believe that is possible.
Captain, I am able to feel more from him now. Much of his emotions are still a jumble, but...
What did you feel?
Only that he wants desperately to leave this ship.
Captain's log, supplemental. We continue on course to Endicor. We are now less than two hours away from our rendezvous with ourselves.
Worf.
All sensors are on maximum scan. There is nothing unusual to report.
If the timetable is correct, we should get an indication of something very soon.
Bridge, this is Sickbay.
Yes, Doctor.
Captain, my patient is more coherent.
I'll be right there.
Number One, you have the bridge.
How is he?
His vital signs are more normal -- which is to say, more like ours. He is calmer.
He is now aware of me.
In some fashion.
(sotto, almost to himself) But, does he know where he is, and who's here with him?
I doubt it.
What went wrong?
You know... don't you?
What did you do? What happened? Why did you leave the ship?
Don't turn away. Look at me.
Picard!
LOOK AT ME!
He doesn't understand you.
He knows I'm here.

Yes, as part of a nightmare of disjointed images, half-heard voices. He is in another dimension -- seeing us across a great chasm -- and he's filled with remorse at what he has witnessed, and he's afraid.
What is he afraid of?
(continuing; back to P2) Damn you -- help me! Why did you leave the ship?
It's no use, Captain. He can't answer.
As we get closer to the time he left, he may be able to.
Are you still convinced he is me?
Yes -- but you're not.
Not in the slightest. Except for his features there is nothing about him which I find familiar.
I want you to stay with him. He will be able to communicate with you before any of the rest of us.
I don't know how long anyone can take this kind of schizophrenia. There has to be a breaking point.
He is handling it very well.
He has a lot of anger.
Yes. Because of what... ... he represents.
And what is that?
Doubt. Seeing him here and knowing what happened to the Enterprise could make him timid or, worse, cause him to hesitate.
When he said -- that there is nothing familiar about him... ... except his features. It sounded like a form of denial.
It's his accurate feelings.
Part of my job is to anticipate problems. I have a duty to the captain, but first to the ship and its crew.
Doctor, the captain is fully capable of command decisions.

Yes... for now. But... this situation has put enormous pressure -- of a unique and very personal nature -- on Captain Picard. And we both know that pressure is going to increase. You said he already has doubt.
Yes, which is necessary and healthy.
But could potentially paralyze. If we begin to see signs that he is acting in an irrational manner, then I have the authority and the duty to relieve him.
I do not think that will be necessary.
I hope you're right.
What force or phenomenon could cause a shuttle to be thrown back in time?
None that we have ever encountered. In theory, accelerating beyond warp ten.
Using the gravitational pull of a star to "slingshot" back in time. Is that what happened here?
The shuttle doesn't have warp capability.
No. Some external force was needed.
We have never encountered any natural force that powerful. And why only six hours? Why not a day? A year?
Are you suggesting there is a conscious mind at work here?
There is no evidence either way.
The Traveler moved through time with the power of his mind.
I don't think that's the case here.
No -- and Manheim's experiments with gravity and time were rudimentary, and uncontrollable.
Captain, this is one instant where you must suppress your natural tendencies.
Explain.

(then more as a friend than a subordinate, or even a fellow officer) Your strength, Jean-Luc, is your ability to evaluate the dynamics of a situation, step in and make the definitive, preemptive move. You take charge. You're frustrated now because, not only can't you see the solution... you can't even define the problem.
Go on.
This is not place or person we are facing... at least not yet... it's time.
Are you telling me to just sit down -- shut up and wait.
I wouldn't have used those exact words... but, yes.
I don't do that well.
It's your Persian Flaw.
Yes -- perhaps it is.
Captain to the bridge.
Report.
This energy vortex appeared out of nowhere. There was no warning.
Well, now at least the waiting is over.
Captain's log, supplemental. The waiting is over. We have apparently intersected with... something.
It is similar to our tractor beam, only much more powerful.
Bridge, this is Engineering.
This is the bridge.
The pull on the Enterprise is steady. I am having to hold the warp engines at thirty percent, in order to maintain this position.
Transfer engine control to the bridge.
Aye, sir.
There is a consciousness here, Captain. Not thought -- it is more like instinct.
What do you make of it, Number One?
I would say we're being probed.
The beam is coming directly from the center of the vortex. Sensors show only massive amounts of energy.
What is it trying to learn?
I think it is trying to determine if we are a life force.
We should stay and investigate.
Agreed.
But, was that the mistake?
... staying too long.
Possibly.
We should go now.
Well...
It's the prudent move.
I never thought I would hear myself say something like that.
Under the circumstances -- I think you may be right.
But you'd rather stay and find out what it is? What is its intent?
Engineering, transfer to bridge.
Lieutenant La Forge.
Yes, sir.
See if you can get us out of here, Mister La Forge. Maximum warp.
Aye, sir.
I have set velocity to warp nine.
Engage.
The warp engines are at ninety-one percent.
Put it to the wall.
Aye, sir.
I can't hold it.
Captain! The engines can't take this strain.
All stop.
Status.
All decks have reported... no damage -- no injuries.
The pull on the Enterprise is steady, but much stronger than before. I am at warp seven just to hold this position.
Everything we do tightens its grip. Let's see what we can learn. Launch a Class One probe.
Aye, sir.
That was personal.
Captain -- the power drain needed to hold this position is enormous.
How long can you maintain it?
A few minutes, then we are going to have to shut down again.
