quote: But remember, you now have all Yareena's lands and wealth, Lutan.
scene: 83   INT. CENTERPLACE - EMPHASIZING PICARD AND LUTAN

quote: (with a wry smile at Hagon) At least, all has not been lost.
scene: 83   INT. CENTERPLACE - EMPHASIZING PICARD AND LUTAN

quote: Picard here.
scene: 83   INT. CENTERPLACE - EMPHASIZING PICARD AND LUTAN

quote: Since you've fulfilled your agreement, Captain, can we now beam the vaccine aboard?
scene: 83   INT. CENTERPLACE - EMPHASIZING PICARD AND LUTAN

quote: Ah, yes... of course.
scene: 83   INT. CENTERPLACE - EMPHASIZING PICARD AND LUTAN

quote: No problem, Number One. Send down someone from medical.
scene: 83   INT. CENTERPLACE - EMPHASIZING PICARD AND LUTAN

quote: And to complete our business here, we are locked onto you.
scene: 83   INT. CENTERPLACE - EMPHASIZING PICARD AND LUTAN

quote: Five to beam up. Energize.
scene: 83   INT. CENTERPLACE - EMPHASIZING PICARD AND LUTAN

quote: First Officer's log, Stardate 41235.6. I am returning the conn to Captain Picard...
... as we begin loading the vaccine supply aboard. Shortly, we hope to signal "mission complete."
Welcome back, Captain, and you're wanted in the lounge.
This way, gentlemen.
She is not dead! There was no death combat; you have violated our agreement. There will be no treaty, no vaccine... !
scene: 86   INT. LOUNGE - ANGLE ON SIDE OF DOORS

quote: The challenge was carried out. She died, Lutan.
scene: 86   INT. LOUNGE - ANGLE ON SIDE OF DOORS

quote: There was no challenge! She is alive.
scene: 86   INT. LOUNGE - ANGLE ON SIDE OF DOORS

quote: I am a physician and saw her die. If you doubt this poison, why not test it on yourself?
scene: 86   INT. LOUNGE - ANGLE ON SIDE OF DOORS

quote: Lutan, we can provide you with the medical records to prove her death and how Doctor Crusher brought her back.
scene: 86   INT. LOUNGE - ANGLE ON SIDE OF DOORS

quote: And at the instant of death, Lutan, a mating agreement dissolves.
scene: 86   INT. LOUNGE - ANGLE ON SIDE OF DOORS

quote: But this is witchcraft, Yareena. To discard a mate in that manner...
scene: 86   INT. LOUNGE - ANGLE ON SIDE OF DOORS

quote: ... is less painful than the one you selected for me.
scene: 86   INT. LOUNGE - ANGLE ON SIDE OF DOORS

quote: No, Yareena...
scene: 86   INT. LOUNGE - ANGLE ON SIDE OF DOORS

quote: Even as I battled, Hagon, I heard you calling out for me.
scene: 86   INT. LOUNGE - ANGLE ON SIDE OF DOORS

quote: Be my First One, Yareena.
scene: 86   INT. LOUNGE - ANGLE ON SIDE OF DOORS

quote: All my land, all my goods, all I have... is yours to rule.
scene: 86   INT. LOUNGE - ANGLE ON SIDE OF DOORS

quote: That's so beautiful. And so sad for you. You've lost everything.
scene: 86   INT. LOUNGE - ANGLE ON SIDE OF DOORS

quote: I have my honor.
scene: 86   INT. LOUNGE - ANGLE ON SIDE OF DOORS

quote: It's such a... a waste!
scene: 86   INT. LOUNGE - ANGLE ON SIDE OF DOORS

quote: Do you want him?
scene: 86   INT. LOUNGE - ANGLE ON SIDE OF DOORS

quote: No, there would be... complications.
scene: 86   INT. LOUNGE - ANGLE ON SIDE OF DOORS

quote: Then I will have you as my Number Two. Take your place accordingly.
scene: 86   INT. LOUNGE - ANGLE ON SIDE OF DOORS

quote: As you see, Captain, you may excel in technology... but not in civilized behavior.
scene: 86   INT. LOUNGE - ANGLE ON SIDE OF DOORS

quote: What the... ! Ah yes, Wesley.
Wesley! He'd been manning that station for me. I forgot.
Well! Thank you again for manning one of our bridge stations. We'll see you get another chance.
Yes sir!
What's the delay, Number One? Why aren't we warping out of here?
Set course for Styris IV, Warp three.
Course laid in for Styris IV, sir.
Engage!
Captain's log, stardate 41723.9. In response to a Starfleet order we are in the Xendi Sabu star system having rendezvoused with a Ferengi vessel which has requested a meeting. Although...
scene: 1    EXT. SPACE - ENTERPRISE AND FERENGI VESSEL (OPTICAL)

quote: ... we arrived here and made appropriate signals to the Ferengi three days ago, they have so far responded only with the message: "Stand by, Enterprise."
scene: 1    EXT. SPACE - ENTERPRISE AND FERENGI VESSEL (OPTICAL)

quote: Come!
You called for me?
Yes, Doctor. I've been feeling... odd, lately. Fatigued. And now I've got a headache.
A what?
Certainly you know what a "headache" is, Doctor.
Of course. But I don't often encounter one.
The reason for it seems fairly obvious. What are these Ferengi up to? "Stand by, Enterprise." Stand by for what?
I can't find a thing wrong.
I can't either. But they could be baiting some kind of trap...
With your head. I see nothing physically wrong, but I want to run additional scans in Sickbay.
Doctor, all I've got is...
... is an order to report to Sickbay. From the one person aboard who can give you an order.
Captain from first officer. They're finally sending a message.
On my way, Number One. Sorry, Doctor. Duty calls.
They're prepared to talk, sir.
Have they given any hint what they've been waiting for?
Negative on that, Captain. But they have identified their Captain as "Bok," DaiMon Bok.
If it's Bok I'm sensing, he seems anxious to meet you, sir.
Me? Why me? I've never heard of him.
You'll be able to see him now, sir. They're willing to communicate on visual.
A reminder of something we learned the only other time we dealt with Ferengi, sir -- their hearing is very sensitive.
Yes, they could pick up even a whisper being transmitted.
Consider ourselves reminded. Open hailing frequencies.
Hailing frequencies open, sir.
Ferengi vessel! This is Captain Jean-Luc Picard of the Enterprise. We are transmitting visually.
Is this THE Captain Picard?
Do we know each other?
I know you, Picard.
I'm afraid you have the advantage. Is this... Bok?
I am Bok, DaiMon of the Ferengi. I have asked you here to discuss a mutual problem, Captain.
What problem is that, DaiMon Bok?
I insist on speaking of that matter in person. Shall we meet on your vessel or mine?
Hailing frequencies closed.
Captain, I sense considerable deception on Bok's part. And danger!
Then definitely, sir, you should meet with him here. Keep him under our control.
Now open, sir.
I appreciate your offer, DaiMon Bok, and ask you to be our guests.
As you wish, Picard. Perhaps this will begin a new era of cooperation for both our peoples. In one Earth hour, then?
One hour, Bok. End transmission.
I can't believe they're coming here!
They agreed a bit too easily.
Then, in one hour we'll know why.
Are you accustomed to always getting your way, Doctor?
When my way makes sense, Captain. There are still forty minutes before the Ferengi beam over; I'll have these scans done in ten.
A lot of effort for something as simple as a headache.
"As simple?" It is my job to know your condition intimately. You should not have a headache unless something is wrong.

It may be true that headaches were once quite common... but this was in the days before the brain was charted... (very puzzled; a new setting) ... before we understood the nature of pain... when we were suffering from such things as the common cold.
And so why do I have a headache, Doctor?
I haven't the slightest damned idea!
What's that?
Something doctors use when they feel foolish over being proven wrong. Feel better?
The pain's gone.
Medical fakery -- the pain's actually still there, just cloaked. I'll want further exams when this Ferengi matter is settled.
Sir! You'll soon be getting an intruder alert!
What? Wesley, if you've something to report...
If you'll scan heading four-four mark one-six-three, Lieutenant, you'll find...
Intruder alert, sir...
I've got something, sir... very distant.
It's an old style starship, Constitution Class, heading this way under impulse power, sir.
Says who?
Carry on. Answer the first officer's question.
Uh... says the long distance sensors, sir. I was in Engineering, playing around with boosting sensor output...
Very interesting. Boosting it how? (seeing Picard's look; to Wesley) We will discuss it later.
I read it now, sir, as... a Constitution Class starship... coming this way under impulse power.
Sir? What's wrong?
Nothing, just... a mild headache. The correct procedure, Ensign, would have been to signal your finding to the bridge immediately.
Yes, sir.
Bringing it here personally... ... perhaps with the idea of being on hand for the Ferengi beam over... might have imperiled our ship had something hostile been approaching.
Yes, sir.
We are receiving no signal at all from the approaching starship, sir.
Time, sir.
Time? Oh, for the Ferengi to beam over. Do you see any problems connected with this old starship coming in?
Suggest we'll be safer, sir, with the Ferengi over here whatever is happening.
Concur. Stand by! Let's bring them on visually.
Hailing frequencies open, sir.
Enterprise to Ferengi vessel. We are standing by to receive you.
Ready to transfer ourselves over, my dear Captain Picard.
Question... where shall we receive you?
On your own bridge, of course. Ferengi efficiency!
Data? What do you read?
Nothing, sir.
It could take a few moments, Captain. If they build up their beaming energy through capacitors as seems likely...
We welcome you in peace to the Enterprise, DaiMon Bok.
It is our pleasure, Captain Picard. Might I introduce my first officer, Kazago, and my second, Rata?
This is my first officer, Commander Riker... And Counselor Troi. Second Officer Data; Lieutenant La Forge; security officers, Lieutenant Yar and Lieutenant Worf; Ensign Crusher.
Yes, we have heard you use females... Clothed females. Most interesting.
They are that, sir.
And the android was mentioned too. What is its price? We should like to purchase it.
It... he is not for sale. Commander Data is...is...
You wouldn't want him, Kazago. He's second-hand merchandise.
Second-hand, sir? (then sees Riker's smile) Oh, of course! A human joke...
Excuse, Captain, but the unidentified starship is continuing in, still no signal at all...
Think nothing of it.. It is under our control.
One of our starships under your control?
Do not be alarmed. It is a gift from us. With which we honor the "Hero of Maxia."
Who?
Why you, Picard, of course! Don't you remember the Battle of Maxia?
I'm sorry, I'm afraid I do not. Data?
Captain, he may refer to an incident which occurred seven years ago in the Maxia Zeta star system, where an unidentified starship...
Unidentified?! That fine vessel was Ferengi!
Which you destroyed, sir.
My sincere regrets, Bok, but that ship did not identify itself. It simply attacked; we defended ourselves...
Such mistakes happen in space.
Hardly a "mistake," sir. Your report showed it deliberately attacked...
Do you want the arriving vessel on Main Viewer, sir? It is only a thousand kilometers away now...
Put it on your viewer.
Main Viewer.
We have set its controls to automatically take station in space next to your Enterprise.
There is no one aboard it.
When, with your permission, its log will be downloaded into this ship's records. At a price...
No price!
No price?
For what purpose? What is this all...
I felt something too, Captain. What is it?
Sir... ?
Perhaps it is... his conscience?
Why do you say that?!
Bridge to Sickbay...
No... no, I'm fine...
It seemed as if... as if it were... something from your past?
I'm all right now; I'm fine. (to Bok; indicating viewer) What is this all about?
It is about the battle I mentioned, Captain. A gift in honor of that occasion. Look at that ship closely.
Enlarge please, La Forge.
It... it is the Stargazer. My old ship, but how... where did you find it?
It was a derelict, adrift in space on the far side of this star system. How it got there... ... is none of my business, Captain. But now that vessel is yours, if you wish to have it.
We are not selling it to him?
Call it an act of friendship.
At no cost!? Ugly. Very ugly!

Captain's log, stardate 41724.1. Bok and his officers have returned to their vessel, inviting us now to officially take possession of the Stargazer. They will stand by while completing the downloading of its log to us.
Like before?
Perhaps... it hit with more impact.
"Hit?" Sorry, but anything could be important.
You say you "felt" something yourself?
I... believe so. Like... well, a thought... But rather... "mechanical" in nature.

Are you sure it wasn't one of my thoughts? At that moment, I was remembering being at the helm of the Stargazer, a maneuver being made. We were hit... Something's burning... I smell smoke! Don't you smell it?
There's nothing burning, Jean-Luc.
Ah... no, of course. It was... the memory I was calling up. (finds a smile for Beverly) Sorry.
Memory or... "nightmare?"
Well, it was strong, whatever it was. Ready, Number One.
Staff's waiting if Doctor Crusher approves.
I'll do better than that -- I'll go along.
But if they don't know what the Ferengi are up to, what good is it to sit there guessing?
Well... sometimes it determines exactly what you don't know.
Dead on target, my friend. Would you like to go up and listen to them?
Some day. Right now I'm happy to be here.
We were traveling at warp two through the Maxia Zeta star system when an unidentified starship suddenly appeared and fired on us! From close range.
Where did it come from?
It must've been lying in a deep moon crater nearby. The first attack damaged our shields, and in the confusion it hit us a second time.
No clue who they were?
No name, no reason... Can you identify them, Vigo? Our shields are failing; if they come in again... ?
Sir? Who's Vigo?
Ah... my weapons officer on the Stargazer. I was getting caught up in this.
Then, with your shields failing, sir...
I improvised. With the other ship coming in for the kill... (describes with his hands) ... I ordered a sensor bearing, and when it went into its return arc...
... you performed what Starfleet textbooks now call "The Picard Maneuver."
What any good helmsman could have done. I dropped into high warp... ... then stopped right off the target vessel's bow... ... and fired everything I had.
By blowing into warp speed, you appeared for an instant to be in two places at once...
And our attacker fired on the wrong one.
As you say, "what any good helmsman could have done." But you did it first...

A "save our skins" maneuver. The Stargazer was on fire, finished. We had to abandon ship, and limp through space in shuttlecraft for weeks before being picked up. I haven't thought about it in years...
The Ferengi are standing by for us to take possession of the Stargazer, sir.
I want to go over to her.
I understand, sir. Once my people make certain she's safe.
USS Stargazer. Constitution Class. Starfleet Registry NCC 2893...
I activated the emergency power cells... Amazing they still work.
The rest of the ship is all clear of surprises, Lieutenant Yar.
When I read about this ship at the Academy, I never dreamed I'd ever be on her.
Yar to Enterprise. All clear, sir.
Thank you, Lieutenant. Captain?
Yes, Commander
Stargazer searched and secured, sir. Give her my best.
I will that, Number One. Energize!
Hello, old friend...
You'll find this intriguing, Captain.
What do you find, Data?
Last entry was dated seven years ago, sir. By you... "We are forced to abandon our starship. May she find her way without us." Apparently, she did.
How are you feeling, Captain?
Fine, Doctor. Lieutenant Yar, run a structural analysis on the Stargazer for impulse tow. Data, download all computers to the Enterprise and file... I'm going to my old cabin.
Try this, "Hero of Maxia."
scene: 24   INT. FERENGI STARSHIP - SCIENCE ROOM (INTERCUT AS

quote: DAMNNNN!
OHHHH!
Captain?
Another headache, sir?! That worries me. I want you back on the Enterprise.
Yes, but... my things here...
I'll see they're sent to your Enterprise quarters.
Enterprise now taking possession of Stargazer, Kazago.
Permission granted, Riker.
Actually it was quite a bargain, Kazago. I thought the Ferengi always made a profit on things.
Set sub-warp speed for towing, La Forge.
Starfleet has responded to our request, sir. A tug will rendezvous with us and tow the Stargazer back to Xendi Starbase Nine.
Very well, Data. How was it, Captain?
Strange, Number One. Like visiting the house you grew up in, but no one's home, except the phantoms of the past...
It has troubled you?
Not as much as this damn headache, Counselor. Take over, Number One.
Aye, sir.
What's wrong?
I wish I could say.
... shields weakening, Captain! Torpedoes armed! Where are they? Ohmygod, sir! Fire! Fire!!
What is it, Data? Why all the mystery?

It is the records of the Stargazer, sir. What the Ferengi call the "Battle of Maxia"... It seems the Captain's personal log contains a much different version of that conflict than the official historic account.
What are you saying?
It would appear that the starship which Captain Picard attacked, had in fact, been under a flag of truce...
What?!
And apparently, the captain destroyed the ship without notice or provocation.
Impossible. What about the fire aboard the Stargazer?
An accident in Engineering.
And the proof?
It is logged in his own voice. Would you care to hear it? Sir? Sir?
First officer's personal log, stardate 41724.2. An unexpected discovery made by Commander Data in the downloaded log of the Stargazer...
scene: 31   EXT. SPACE - ENTERPRISE, STARGAZER AND FERENGI VESSEL

quote: ... appears to indicate Captain Picard was guilty of falsifying the report he made to Starfleet concerning the Stargazer's last voyage.
scene: 31   EXT. SPACE - ENTERPRISE, STARGAZER AND FERENGI VESSEL

quote: What does this mean?
I don't know, sir. That sounds like your voice.
Don't you know it is, Number One?
No, sir, I don't. I refuse to believe you could have said that.
... and I admit I must have mistaken their subspace antenna for a weapons cluster. Unfortunately, I fired our main phasers...
... and our direct hit destroyed the unknown vessel instantly.
I recognize, of course, your voice has been simulated somehow. I've already put Data to work on it.
Thank you, Will. I never made that log entry, of course. But it still creates a duty for you to perform.
Yes, sir, I must report it to Starfleet. But at this distance, it will take at least a full day for subspace communications to reach there...
... and another full day for their answer to return. I'd like the truth on this by then.
Sir, you can't believe they'd relieve you from command...
Why shouldn't they? Better safe than sorry with the Ferengi now making friendship overtures.
And it's certain that the Ferengi are behind this faked log. No wonder they're still out there, waiting...
Headache back, sir?
Damn! I'll call the doctor again.
It's no wonder you have one, with all this going on, sir. Try to relax. I've got things in hand.
Once again...
This is a confession, given by me, Jean-Luc Picard, commanding USS Stargazer, in the hopes that my belated honesty will be taken into account by Starfleet when judging...
La Forge, open hailing frequencies.
Open, sir.
I'll take it in the Ready Room. A secure channel, Geordi.
Secure, Commander.
Starship Ferengi! This is Commander Riker here. I'd like to speak to First Officer Kazago.
A problem, Riker?
Is our channel secure on your end?
It is now.
Are you aware of the details of the Battle of Maxia?
Captain Bok has just made me aware of it, Riker. The infamy of your Picard is now fully known.
Infamy?!
I would call the wanton destruction of an unarmed vessel infamy.
And if I produce evidence that Captain Picard's log entry was falsified to indicate that... ?
What else would your decadent culture say to defend such disgrace?! But I can hardly imagine you contacted me to discuss an ancient battle. What do you want of me?
Just one question.
As you humans say, I'm all ears.
First officer to first officer, Kazago, if your Captain Bok knew of that, why this peaceful meeting to present us with the Stargazer?
We freely give YOU back your derelict warship and now you accuse US of crime, Riker?! I can bear NO more insults!
Who the hell is it?!
Not resting, Captain?
More like dying, Doctor. What's wrong with me?!
I wish to hell I knew, Captain. But something unusual has definitely happened to you.
Why do doctors always state the obvious like it's a revelation?
Why do captains always think they're immortal? Better now?
Aghhh! My head!

quote: Now that has to do it right?
scene: 41   INT. PICARD'S' QUARTERS - BACK TO SCENE

quote: No!
scene: 41   INT. PICARD'S' QUARTERS - BACK TO SCENE

quote: You didn't say it's been this bad!
scene: 41   INT. PICARD'S' QUARTERS - BACK TO SCENE

quote: It hasn't been! But it is getting worse, Doctor...
scene: 41   INT. PICARD'S' QUARTERS - BACK TO SCENE

quote: It has to be some kind of emotional pressure connected with the Stargazer...
scene: 43   INT. PICARD'S QUARTERS - BACK TO SCENE

quote: I got the damn headache before I even knew my old ship still existed... But maybe you're partly right...
scene: 43   INT. PICARD'S QUARTERS - BACK TO SCENE

quote: Want to talk to Counselor Troi about it?
scene: 43   INT. PICARD'S QUARTERS - BACK TO SCENE

quote: What I need now is a friend...
scene: 43   INT. PICARD'S QUARTERS - BACK TO SCENE

quote: I'm here.
scene: 43   INT. PICARD'S QUARTERS - BACK TO SCENE

quote: The Stargazer was an exploration vessel. The fight at Maxia was not my first action, but it was the first time I ever killed anyone.
scene: 43   INT. PICARD'S QUARTERS - BACK TO SCENE

quote: You had no choice...
scene: 43   INT. PICARD'S QUARTERS - BACK TO SCENE

quote: Didn't I? I don't know anymore... I just don't know.
scene: 43   INT. PICARD'S QUARTERS - BACK TO SCENE

quote: Commander Riker told me about the altered log, sir. If that's troubling you...
scene: 43   INT. PICARD'S QUARTERS - BACK TO SCENE

quote: The last three nights, I... hear voices. I'm standing on the bridge, fire all around me... the klaxons, smoke, and I give the order... And now the Stargazer is really here! And that log... Am I going crazy? How do I know if I was in my right mind at Maxia? How do I know if I'm in my right mind now?
scene: 43   INT. PICARD'S QUARTERS - BACK TO SCENE

quote: What was... that?
scene: 43   INT. PICARD'S QUARTERS - BACK TO SCENE

quote: Just something to let you sleep.
scene: 43   INT. PICARD'S QUARTERS - BACK TO SCENE

quote: Yes... sleep... I need sl...
scene: 43   INT. PICARD'S QUARTERS - BACK TO SCENE

quote: ... shields weakening, Captain! Torpedoes armed! Where are they?
And now, dear captain, you are ready to live the past!
Where did they... come from? Phasers, sir? Sir? SIR?
scene: 47   INT. PICARD'S QUARTERS - BACK TO SCENE

quote: What should we do, sir? Should we fire back?
scene: 47   INT. PICARD'S QUARTERS - BACK TO SCENE

quote: Fire, Captain, FIRE!
scene: 47   INT. PICARD'S QUARTERS - BACK TO SCENE

quote: You will injure yourself as once you injured me!

quote: SIR?!

quote: Damage report!
scene: 49   INT. PICARD'S QUARTERS - BACK TO SCENE

quote: Sensor bearing on hostile ship!
scene: 49   INT. PICARD'S QUARTERS - BACK TO SCENE

quote: Seven, seven mark nineteen, sir! Fire in Engineering...
scene: 49   INT. PICARD'S QUARTERS - BACK TO SCENE

scene: 49   INT. PICARD'S QUARTERS - BACK TO SCENE

quote: Fire!
scene: 49   INT. PICARD'S QUARTERS - BACK TO SCENE

quote: FIRE!!
scene: 49   INT. PICARD'S QUARTERS - BACK TO SCENE

quote: By comparing the main Stargazer computer log with Captain Picard's personal log, I have found "checksum" discrepancies, sir.
What does that mean?
All information is time-coded by entry, and the bits when totaled produce an aggregate amount which...
I don't want a lesson in computer science! Bottom line?
One of these two logs is a forgery.
Correction -- the log just found aboard the Stargazer is a forgery.
As I said. That is one of them, isn't it?
You're looking better, Captain.
A little sleep, thanks to the doctor, works wonders. Any report on the logs?
Yes, sir. Whoever tampered with your personal log was clever...
... but slightly clumsy. There's no doubt it is a fabrication.
Number One, we think you should see this brain scan graph which... What are you doing here?!
I thought I was captain of this starship, Doctor.
Of course you are, but I...
Thank you for your confirmation of that. But now, except for Commander Riker, I want you all back at your stations... Is that clear?
I have some business concerning your health, sir...
I mean you too, Doctor. I have business with Riker.
Under protest, Captain.
You have orders for me, sir?
Release the Stargazer from the tractor beam, Number One.
Sir?
The tractor beam.
Sir, are you abandoning...
No. Her inertia will carry the Stargazer along on this heading with us. Or did you sleep through the Academy lecture on conserving tractor beam power?
No, sir. I'll release her, or course.
Obviously, there is some thought process disorder here but I cannot find any physical reason for it. Anything?
I'm puzzled too. I keep sensing random thoughts... but two sets of them. As if they were his, but intermixed with his from another source.
I'm busy at the moment, Wesley...
I know you're busy, Mom, but when I went back to the main sensors in Engineering to try some more sensitivity experiments...
Wes! I'll be glad to hear about it when I'm through with...
But, Mom, this is important!
Does it have something to do with Captain Picard?
Yes, ma'am... ... if that's what you're talking about there. I don't know anything about brain scans but I glanced at these when you were studying them, Mom, and I noticed...
(pointing at scan graphs) ... these patterns here were like patterns of the low-intensity transmissions picked up from the Ferengi ship. I just went back and checked and they're exactly the same.
What kind of transmissions?
I don't know. Engineering has nothing like it on record.
Let's get to the captain...
No, they might be affecting the captain. To Riker!
You're welcome, ladies. Adults!
The captain, Commander?
Resting in his quarters... ... after ordering both of you to your duty stations.
This is more important!
Than the captain's orders?
Yes, when we have reason to believe his judgment is being affected.
Well then, why not let everyone in on it?
It affects them too. There have been some strange... Did he say "low intensity... ?" ... unusual low intensity transmissions from the Ferengi vessel...
Did who say?
My son!
... transmissions which exactly match certain anomalies found in the captain's brain scans. Something over there is affecting Captain Picard's thought patterns.
Computer, tell me Captain Picard's location!
Captain Picard is in Transporter Room Three.
What? Computer, emergency order to Transporter Room Three...
New information. Captain Picard is no longer aboard the Enterprise.
Welcome back, Captain.
What is happening?
Shields up, computer.
Shields in place.
What are you doing?
Collecting on an old debt...
AGHHH-H-H!!
Stargazer! Respond, Captain!
Shields up, sir. No way to beam over help.
I am reading something very strange. A low intensity beam of intermittent pulse inside this starship.
I have a fix on it... Inside Captain Picard's quarters.
You transferred some of his belongings from the Stargazer... ?
Including a fairly heavy chest... !
Go take a look, fast!
The Stargazer is powering up!
I have been waiting a long seven years for this, Picard!
I have no idea what you're talking about...
Do you not, hu-man? Can you not remember the crime you committed against my very blood? You murdered my only son!
Your son?
He was the commander of the ship you destroyed!) On his first voyage as DaiMon.
The ship... ? The... the Ferengi ship that attacked me... ... or is it about to attack me?
And I have spent these years searching... seeking... a proper blood revenge. And I found it!
OHHHHH... ! OHHHHH... !
From a distant world which hu-man evil has not yet reached. May you never secure these! I am rich, yet two of these cost me the profits of an entire life.
You cannot... control me like...
Die well, Picard.
First officer's log, stardate 41724.3. Captain Picard, without explanation, has beamed himself to the Stargazer which is now moving away from us...
... under its own power.
Hailing frequencies open, sir.
Enterprise to Stargazer, please respond.
Enterprise to Stargazer... to Captain Picard aboard Stargazer, please answer. Mister Data, what was Stargazer's condition?
Considerable fire damage to interior surface as reported, sir. But none of her main systems are crippled.
Armaments, Lieutenant Yar?
Six photon torpedoes short, sir, probably used when the Captain destroyed his Ferengi attacker seven years ago. Otherwise fully armed.
Where in the Captain's quarters was it, Mister Worf?
His chest from the Stargazer, sir. Just where I had left it -- he hadn't yet unpacked.
So, he may not have even known it was there. And if this is able to pick up or magnify a thought-altering transmission...
... it could have prepared him for whatever's happening now.
Let's find out... or try to. Contact the Ferengi vessel, Lieutenant.
Hailing frequencies open, sir.
Enterprise to Ferengi vessel, we transmit visually. Do you respond?
Why is our gift to you under power, hu-man?
I'll discuss that with your captain.
He is working in our ship's laboratory. Where is your captain?
He's beamed himself aboard the Stargazer, and I'm wondering... (brings sphere up into view) ... if this has anything to do with it?
How do you have possession of that?
It was found in our captain's belongings, brought over from the Stargazer.
It... is a forbidden device. A Thought Maker. If your captain is... criminal enough to own one...
Kazago, I ask again, first officer to first officer... what is going on? Something is happening that neither of us seems to know about.
It... is not seemly to question one's own DaiMon, Riker. I... am not prepared to do that...
Sir... I have the Stargazer.
Switch now!
Captain Picard, this is the Enterprise, sir...
Do not attack again! We are on a peaceful...
He's living a delusion, sir. He's seeing things we don't...
Give your identity! You force us to defend ourselves! Phasers full up! Arm torpedoes! Why aren't shields at full power... ?
We've lost him, sir...
When he put the shields up...
Damn, I said... ... put fusion generators on surge control. You're moving too slowly. Arm the torpedoes, man!

Fine, fine, Enterprise out!
But you should also know that DaiMon Bok no longer commands this vessel, Riker. His first officer has confined him for engaging in this unprofitable adventure. Good luck, First Officer Riker.

I have computed a possibility, Commander. Since even deep space contains trace gases, sir, a vessel in the Picard maneuver might seem to disappear, but our sensors could locate any sudden compression of those gases...
And use it as an aiming point? Blast our own captain to bits?
Aim our tractor beam at it, sir! Seize it! This class starship has enough power for that.
In our captain's words... make it so! Set sensors, tractor beam... I hope you're right, Data...
No question of it, sir...
Stand by!
Lock on tractor beam!
Ready phasers!
Captain Picard, listen to me!
Is that you, Vigo?
It's Commander Riker, sir!
Captain, hear me! Look around you, the Ferengi are using a thought device on you...
Stand by for warp... Who are you?!
It's Riker, sir. Your Number One. Look for a silver sphere...
(continuing; sees it too) There it is! Destroy it with your phaser, Captain!
Phaser... Yes, a sphere... Bok used it...
Destory it!
Phaser... destroy the sphere.
Captain! Are you all right?
Enterprise, lock on. Beam me home, Riker.
Ship's log, stardate 42625.4, First Officer Riker reporting. We have achieved orbit around Theta Eight...
... the planet furthest from its sun in this previously unmapped solar system. It is a world of ruthless realities: particularly harsh, barren, and inhospitable...
Our reason for being here -- a passing Klingon cruiser reported discovering pieces of a strange vessel in the upper atmosphere. We've come to investigate...
Nasty. Nitrogen... methane... liquid neon. Surface temperature minus two hundred and ninety-one degrees Fahrenheit. Winds up to three hundred and twelve meters per second.
Not exactly a vacation planet, eh?
Uh uh. Not unless you like ammonia tornadoes. Or orange lightning bolts for that matter.
Not my cup of tea. Found anything artificial in the atmosphere?
Nothing so far. We're just coming around to the night side now.
Keep me informed. The sooner we identify what the Klingons think they saw, the sooner we can get the hell out of here.
Sounds good to me.
Nasty.
Come.
Fermat's last theorem. Familiar with it?
No. I'm afraid I spent too many math classes daydreaming about being on a starship.

It's intriguing. When Fermat died they found scrawled in the margin of his notes that he had found a "remarkable proof." Unfortunately he never lived to write it down. And for the last eight hundred years people have been trying to rediscover it.
And that includes you?
I find the process relaxing.
We've detected debris of some sort in a loose orbit.
Can you identify?
I suggest we beam a section aboard for analysis.
Make it so, Number One.
Energize.
We've locked onto something with markings on it.
What sort of markings?
Uncertain, sir.
There's something here.
That symbol... Do you recognize it?
Yes sir. I -- I think I do.
Metallic analysis bears out that the object in question was terrestrial in origin. Most likely late twenty-first century.
But that's not possible. No ship of that time period could have come this far.
Nevertheless, that is what our tests indicate. And the markings we discovered are consistent with this hypothesis.
Any idea what destroyed it? An explosion of some sort?
Unknown.
The question is, how did it get here?
Captain. We've detected a large structure on the planet.
It is a building of some sort, situated on a plane of frozen methane, smack in the middle of a tremendous storm belt. It is incongruous; it simply should not be there!

American. Fifty-two stars -- that would date it between 2053 and 2079 A.D.
(continuing; reading name) Colonel S. Richey.

Picard to Riker.

We can't transport.

Colonel Stephen Richey was the commanding officer of the explorer ship Charybdis which had a terrestrial launch date of 7-23-2067. It was the first manned attempt to travel beyond the confines of the Euclidian solar system. Its telemetry system failed and it was never heard from again... Why is this of interest, Number One?
The frequency scramble remains unpredictable, sir...
Commander? Some curiosities...
scene: 57   INT. ROYALE - RICHEY'S SUITE - RIKER AND DATA

quote: Books... A novel... "The Royale Hotel"... Summarize.

quote: The story of a group of compulsive gamblers caught up in the web of crime, corruption and deceit spun by nefarious lothario Mikey D who appears only at the climax to be brought to his knees by a heartbroken bellboy. There is a subplot about an older man conspiring with a younger woman to murder her husband while squandering her inheritance. The writing is elementary, the plotting predictable, the characters one-dimensional. The only thing of interest, quite honestly, is the intriguing setting, that of a Las Vegas gambling casino-hotel --
scene: 57   INT. ROYALE - RICHEY'S SUITE - RIKER AND DATA

quote: This novel... and everyone in it you've just described... that's this hotel...
scene: 57   INT. ROYALE - RICHEY'S SUITE - RIKER AND DATA

quote: This... this appears to be a diary... but with only one entry... (reading from it with great interest now) "I write this in the hope that it will someday be read by human eyes... I can only surmise at this point, but apparently our exploratory shuttle was contaminated by an alien life-form which infected and killed all personnel except myself. I awakened to find myself here in The Royale Hotel... and for the last thirty-eight years I have survived here.
scene: 57   INT. ROYALE - RICHEY'S SUITE - RIKER AND DATA

quote: "I have come to understand that this place was created for me out of some sense of guilt, presuming that the novel we had on board was in fact a guide to our preferred lifestyle and social habits. Obviously, they thought this was the world from which I came. I hold no malice toward my benefactors... they could not possibly know the hell they have put me through, for it was such a badly written book, filled with endless cliche and shallow characters. I shall welcome death when it comes... "
scene: 57   INT. ROYALE - RICHEY'S SUITE - RIKER AND DATA

Yes...
That would mean the atmosphere of the planet would instantly rush in.

A minute -- maybe less.
But you could revive them.
Well, that would depend on how long they were exposed, how soon I got to them, but Captain realistically... I wouldn't give them much of a chance. I'm a doctor -- not a magician.
I understand the risk, but I will not warp off and leave them. Make your preparations.
Yes, sir.
Yes? (listens, frowns, turns to others) There is a female voice asking if we want... "room service."
I believe they are asking if we want the room cleaned.
Tell them no.
No.
What'd she say?
She said... "The kitchen's open twenty-four hours if we change our minds."
I'm going to explore the other floors; you two go down to the lobby, see if we've missed anything. Talk to the other "guests" -- try and find out who and what they are.
I suggest we separate and blend in with these beings. Casual queries offered in an inconspicuous manner might prove most fruitful.

Hit?

Could you take me there?
I'm losing my shirt here --
Now son, why would I wanna do that? Can't you see I'm tryin' to to help this little lady?
I do not believe you could go to your car, even if it truly exists. You are trapped inside the Royale, just as I am.

Sure does feel that way when you're losin', doesn't it? But right now we're tryin' to turn this lady's wagon and win back some lost change. Otherwise she's goin' to be in a desperate situation with nowhere to turn. Well, almost nowhere.
I stay, right?
I wouldn't.
The odds favor standing pat.
What do I do?
You want a card or what?
Too many.
That's everything I had. I've lost it all. What am I going to do?
There, there...
You were told.
It's not for you to make the call... it's for Rita.
She sent me to tell you.
Boys -- we can't afford to have any trouble here -- take it outside.
Yeah -- I like that... come on, baggage man... let's you and me take it outside.
Watch yourself.
Don't worry.
It's all part of the novel. Don't interfere.
You should have listened, kid no woman is worth dying for... killing for... but not dying for.
How can he leave?
It is on page 244.
The book... Then... how does it end?
A bad love affair ends in a bloody shoot-out, the hotel gets bought out and life goes on... such as it is --
The hotel gets bought? By whom?
It is not very specific. The acquiring party is simply referred to as "foreign investors." Sale price, twelve point five million.
That's how we're getting out. We're buying this place.

(sighs with frustration) Number One... If we don't take some action, make some attempt -- however dangerous it may be -- to rescue you, you may very well be lost to the confines of that conundrum for all eternity. That is certain death for you all... and that... ... that is unacceptable! We have set phaser focus with energy ratios sufficient to penetrate the structure --
Hold on that. There may be another way. I'll keep you informed.
It is a question of decimal percentages. Quite simple, really if one bets with any sequential consistency.
Can you do it?
Certainly.
C'mon, sugar, seven-come-eleven and we're on easy street --
Snake eyes.
I'm almost broke!
Baby, relax! It's only money --
But if I lose it all, I won't even have a place to sleep.
Don't worry your pretty little head. I'd never let that happen.
It's your roll, sir...
Go to work.
Maybe this turkey'll change our luck --
Six. The point is six --
Six! Hell, my blind grandmother can make a six! Let 'er rip, boy!
Seven. Seven and out...
So much for your new turkey --
These cubes are improperly balanced. I believe that their final resting position is adversely affected --
Loaded dice. Can you... "repair" them?
I believe so...
Seven! A winner!
Attaboy! Just do that a few more times and everybody's gonna get well --
Who has the dice?
Oh, Tex, darlin', you're brilliant!
Yeah. An' good lookin' too, huh?
Isn't that enough?
Almost. I don't want to be short, that's for sure... You are keeping count?
Eleven point three million. Perhaps I will bet it all --
No! Simply reach twelve million.
As you wish...
The man has the touch.
Now.
I would like to cash out, please.
I'm afraid you've broken the bank. That's over twelve million --
Twelve point five million to be exact. The purchase price of this hotel.
That's impossible --
Wrong. We're the "foreign Investors" on page 244. We're buying you out, lock, stock, and barrel. (slides the chips toward the pit boss) Consider it a "done deal."
Hey, y'know what? Y'all got style! I like that! Let me buy y'all a drink --
Enjoy the game, friend. And don't let 'em change the dice on you.
Wait! You can't leave!
Oh yeah? Watch us. (then, wagging a finger at him) Don't forget, we own the joint.
You're confident about this, Commander?
Focus. Concentrate. See only where we want to BE, not where we are.
Ancient philosophical overtones of thought process... "Zen", I believe --
We own the place... and we're walking through that door...
I think it's time to go home...
scene: 92   EXT. PLANET SURFACE - THE BLACK VOID

quote: Transporter Room, we have a fix on our away team. Beam them up... and please be quick about it!

Captain's Log: Stardate 47751.2. The Enterprise has arrived at Starbase Three One Zero for a meeting with Fleet Admiral Necheyev. This visit will also give us the opportunity to pick up a... member of the family.
Here you go... your very own quarters. And they're as far away from mine as possible, so you won't even have to see me if you don't want to.
Mom... you know that's not why I asked for my own quarters this --
No, no. You don't have to explain. There comes a time in a young man's life when he doesn't want to stay with his poor old mother... I understand.
I'll come visit you in the old Doctor's Home every Sunday.
Come in.
Is there a runaway cadet in here?
If so, we may have to call security.
Welcome back, Wes.
Thanks.
I was, of course, not serious about calling security. It was a joke.
I got it, Data.
So... how's life at the Academy?
Great... just great. But it's... good to have a break.
So do you plan on just lounging around while we have work to do?
I'm... sure I can find some time to help, sir.
Enjoy your time off, you've earned it.
Thanks.
Well... I think we better let him settle in.
Good idea. Don't sleep your whole vacation away, Wes.
Good-bye.
See you later.
It's really good to have you home, Wesley. Really.
Thanks, Mom.
Admiral Necheyev's just beamed aboard. Worf's escorting her up here now.
Good.
Earl Grey Tea... watercress sandwiches... Bularian canapes... Are you up for a promotion?
I'm trying to establish a new relationship with the Admiral. There's been a certain amount of... tension between us in the past.
Tension's not the word I would use...
I'd like to get things started on a better note this time. I want to make her feel at ease... that she's welcome aboard the Enterprise...
I don't know why she wouldn't feel welcome here.
We don't have to like her Wil, we simply have to follow her orders. However, maintaining an atmosphere of confrontation serves no purpose.
Admiral Necheyev, sir.
Admiral, welcome aboard the Enterprise.
Thank you. You two may leave.
Thank you, Admiral.
Captain...
Admiral, may I offer you some --
I'll come right to the point, Captain. A situation has developed on the Cardassian border that...
Are those... Bularian canapes?
Yes, as a matter of fact. I took the liberty of speaking to your aide, Commander Wrightwell... he said you were quite fond of them.
That was very... thoughtful, Captain. Thank you.
You were saying something about the Cardassians I believe...
Yes. The Federation has just completed a very long and difficult series of negotiations regarding the final status of our border with the Cardassians.

These will be the official boundaries... you'll notice that a demilitarized zone has also been created along the border. Neither side will be permitted to place military outposts, conduct fleet exercises, or station warships anywhere in the demilitarized area.
This border will put several Federation colonies in Cardassian territory... and some Cardassian colonies in ours.

The agreement is by no means perfect... neither side got everything they wanted... but everyone got something. And as someone once said, diplomacy is the art of the possible. Those colonies finding themselves on the wrong side of the border will have to be moved.
The colonists are not going to be very happy about that... some of them have been there for decades.
It won't be easy... but it is a reasonable price to pay for peace. Your mission is to evacuate the colony on Dorvan Five.
Dorvan Five... that's where the group of North American Indians has settled, isn't it?
Yes. They've been there for about twenty years... they've established a village in a small valley on the southern continent.
Is there something wrong?

Admiral... centuries ago, the North American Indians were forcibly displaced from their ancestral lands. This group on Dorvan Five originally left Earth two hundred years ago because they wanted to preserve their cultural identities.
I am aware of that Captain...
There are certain... disturbing historical parallels here. Once again, these people are being asked to leave their homes because of political decisions made by a distant government.
An Indian representative was included in the deliberations of the Federation Council. His objections were noted, discussed... but ultimately rejected.

Captain, the Indians colonized Dorvan only twenty years ago... and at that time they were warned the planet was hotly disputed by the Cardassians. The bottom line is... they never should have settled there in the first place.
Then perhaps we should not have allowed them to settle the planet originally. But to go to them twenty years later and ask them to leave what is now their home...
I made the same argument to the Federation Council. But it took three years to negotiate this treaty... some concessions had to be made... and this is one of them.
What if the Indians should... refuse to evacuate?
Then your orders are to remove them... by any means necessary.
I understand your... moral objections, Captain. If you wish... I can find someone else to command the Enterprise for this mission.
No. That won't be necessary.
I don't envy you this task... but I do believe it is for the greater good.
I understand.
And... thank you for... (beat, looks down at the food & tea) ... making me feel welcome.
You are always welcome on this ship, Admiral.
Come in.
Oh. I'm sorry to disturb you, Mister Crusher. I assumed you would be up at this hour. I could come back later.
No... no, sir. I... must have overslept. Come in.
(continuing, to replicator) Coffee, black.
Oh. Uh, can I get something for you, sir?
No, that's quite all right. This was my first chance to welcome you back.
Thank you. I appreciate that.
So... how's Boothby?
Fine, I guess.
You guess?
I haven't seen him in a while. To be honest, sir... Boothby was starting to get on my nerves a little bit.
He always seemed to have an opinion about everything. (then tries to backtrack) I mean, I know he's a very... insightful... intelligent man...
But you'd had enough of his insights.
That's not quite what I meant, sir.
Well, as I said, welcome back, Mister Crusher. I hope you enjoy your vacation. That's really all I came here to say.
Wes -- there you are. You've got to take a look at this.
Remember how we always talked about improving the quantum efficiency by creating a new plasma-dyne relay? Well, feast your eyes on this.
You've only got one micro-fusion inter-relay in here... the converter interface will never hold up.
Hey, I ran the diagnostics myself. This little baby will withstand over five hundred Cochranes of warp field stress.
I don't think so. You better put a secondary phase inverter in there. (beat, pokes around in panel) In fact, this entire subprocessor matrix needs an overhaul.
Well, I guess we can't have all the fancy new equipment they give you kids at the Academy. We have to make do with what we've got.
Read the latest paper by Doctor Vassbinder... he has some brilliant new theories on warp propulsion inter-relays. A lot of this stuff is almost obsolete.
What's wrong with you?
Do you want my help or not?
I was doing this for you... I thought you'd be interested in this.
Well, I'm not.
Captain's Log: Supplemental. The Enterprise has arrived at Dorvan Five and I have spoken to the Leader of the Tribal Council. He has agreed to meet with us this afternoon to discuss the situation.
Anthwara... I am afraid there is very little I can do. The decision regarding this planet was made at the highest levels of the Federation.
A decision that was made over our explicit objections.
I must point out that when you first came to this world, you were warned that it was the subject of a dispute between the Federation and the Cardassians. You were asked not to settle here.
Do you know how long we have searched for a home? Almost two hundred years. Then we found this world... Can you blame us for not wanting to give it up?
I understand and respect the long journey of your people. But I believe we can help you find a new home.
As you can see, there are three other planets in this sector that have environmental conditions similar to those here on Dorvan Five. They are all uninhabited... and could be colonized immediately.
And if those worlds don't meet with your approval, then we'll find you other choices.

You don't understand... the choice of this world was not limited to... "environmental conditions." There were other... more intangible concerns as well. My people have always had an... intimate bond with nature. We think of ourselves as being a part of it... and it being a part of us. One of the reasons our ancestors left Earth two hundred years ago was because that bond had been severed.
They began to control the weather.

We believe -- very strongly -- that nature should not be "fixed" or controlled. Droughts and floods... tornadoes and hurricanes... these are natural events. By putting man above nature... an imbalance was created. We could no longer live in harmony with our environment.
I can assure you that we will not impose a weather control system or anything else on your people. Whatever world you choose to colonize will be completely yours to do with as you please.

Captain, once the bond between us and Earth had been broken, we had to find a planet where we could establish a new bond... a planet that would welcome us. When I came here twenty years ago, I was welcomed by the mountains... the rivers... the sky.
(to Anthwara, re: Picard) He's laughing at you, Anthwara. He thinks you're talking about old superstition and nonsense.
That's not true. I have a great deal of respect for your beliefs and the meaning they hold for your people.

Then you should respect the fact that this planet holds a deeply spiritual significance for us. It took us two centuries to find a place where the mountains gave us permission to use their stone for our houses... where the rivers let us drink from their waters... and where the wind sang to us at night. We don't want to spend another two hundred years searching for what we already have.
Captain, may I suggest that we adjourn for now... allow us all time to think about what's been said.
Agreed. We will reconvene tomorrow.
In the meantime, I would like to invite you all to the Enterprise this evening as our guests.
Thank you, Captain. We look forward to it.
Ever since you came aboard you've been moody, sullen and rude. I want to know what's going on.
Nothing's going on, Mom. I just want to be left alone.
No, that's not good enough. Your behavior in Engineering was inexcusable.
Well, then that's my business isn't it? I don't need you telling me how to behave.
I shouldn't have to -- you're a fourth year Starfleet cadet. You're expected to have a certain level of maturity.
Maybe I'm sick of living up to other people's expectations... maybe I'm sick of following rules and regulations... did you ever think about that?

... so I've been trying to familiarize myself with the history and traditions of your people. I was quite interested to learn that it was your grandfather -- Katowa -- who led the group of Indians who initially left Earth two centuries ago.

He was a... great man. When I was a little boy, I was so proud to know that he was my grandfather. In fact, I think I was a little too proud of it... I remember the other children getting tired of hearing me talk about him.

It must have been a very difficult decision for your grandfather to make... uprooting your people... leading them into the unknown for an undetermined amount of time... not even knowing if you ever would find a new home.
There was great deal of opposition. Even my own father was against it... but when Katowa made his decision -- that was it. My father never said another word.
It's never easy to leave one's home... to give up the safe and familiar. But there are times when the greater good demands that sacrifices be made... I'm sure your grandfather knew that.
His grandson does too. But there are also times when a people have sacrificed too much... when they must hold on to what they have... even if it means standing up against overwhelming opposition.
What do you know about your family, Captain?
A great deal actually. My father was a strong believer in passing along the family history and traditions.

Tell me about your family. We have very strong ties to our ancestors... we believe their actions guide us even now. Knowing more about your family might help me to better understand you. Besides, it's always a good idea to understand your opponent in any negotiation.
I hope that by the end of this matter, you won't look at me as your opponent. My family. Well... our roots in Western Europe go back to the time of Charlemagne.
Sorry I'm late.
We'll talk about that later.
Wesley Crusher?
Yes?
I am Lakanta.
I'm... glad to meet you... can I get you a drink or --
I have been waiting for you.
For... me?
I have known you would come to us for the past two years.
I'm... not sure what you mean.
Two years ago, I went into the Habak and began a vision quest. While I was there, I saw many things... talked to many animals and spirits... and I saw you.
There're many things you don't understand yet... but you will.
I don't mean to be rude, but I wish you'd stop talking about me in the future tense.
I know your spirit's troubled, Wesley. That's why you've come to us. We can help you find the answers you seek.
I just don't know what to do, Jean-Luc. It's as if someone took my son away and left this stranger in his place.
In a sense, that's exactly what's happened. Wesley left here three years ago as a boy... but now he's a young man. That can't be an easy transition for a mother... or a son.
Well, it's gone beyond just the two of us...
I heard about the incident with Geordi.
Have you heard about the Academy? I called Admiral Brand this afternoon. She said his grades are falling... he's becoming remote, defensive... if he's not careful, he'll wash out next term.
I don't mean to make light of that by any means... but I must say that I went through the same thing.

Oh, yes. I nearly washed out my sophomore year... there were a lot of different factors... my father's death... a teenage love affair with the wrong girl... the point is, I realized what was happening to me and I pulled myself out of it. I'm sure Wesley will do the same.
Jean-Luc... will you have a talk with him? Maybe this is the kind of thing a boy -- a young man has to discuss with another man.
I don't think he wants either of us to talk to him right now.
But he needs help.
Perhaps. But he has to want that help. If he doesn't, then any effort on our part might only push him further away.
Let him work this out on his own, Beverly.
How long have you been watching me?
Since you beamed down.
Well, I'm here. What am I supposed to do now?
I don't know.
I thought you were going to... help me "find some answers".
Yes. But the answers will be to your questions.
What questions? I don't even know why I came here.
I told you before your spirit was troubled. Was I wrong?
I don't know about my... spirit, but I guess you could say I'm a little... troubled.
Then perhaps you do have questions to be answered. Maybe your answers are here... maybe they're not. Will it hurt to look?
Tell me about this... Habak. You said you had some kind of a vision there?
The Habak is a holy place... we hold many of our rituals and ceremonies there. It's sacred to us.
What's sacred to you, Wesley?
To me? Uh... well, I consider a lot of things... important... I respect a lot of things... but I don't know if I consider anything sacred.
Stop.
Look around us. What do you think would be sacred to us here?
Well... maybe some of the designs on the walls... the necklace you're wearing... ?

Everything is sacred to us. The buildings... the food... the sky... the dirt under your feet... and you. Whether you believe in your own spirit or not... we believe in it. So you are a sacred person here, Wesley.
I think that's the first time anyone's used that particular word to describe me.
So if you're sacred... then you have to treat yourself with respect... to do otherwise is to desecrate something holy.
Is that... what you think I'm doing?
Only you can decide that.
Maybe I don't have... a lot of respect for myself right now.
Then perhaps it's time for your own vision quest to begin.

Anthwara... I deeply regret that we have not been able to reach an agreement. But, to put it bluntly, I cannot take no for an answer. This planet will be handed over to the Cardassian government as per the terms of the border agreement. I am very sorry... but you will have to leave.
And if we do not?
Then I will be forced... to remove you... by any means necessary.
A familiar threat... from a white man.

This is not a racial issue... it has nothing to do with ancient hatreds... or with the fact that we have different colored skin. I might just as easily have been a Vulcan or Andorian captain. The orders from Starfleet would have been the same.
We know you won't take us from our land, Captain.
Anthwara... I may regret doing it, but --

When you first came to us, we didn't know why you were the one sent here by the Federation... but we knew there had to be a reason. To us, nothing is truly random. So we searched for the true reason you were sent. We didn't find it until last night.
Are you familiar with the Pueblo Revolt of sixteen eighty?
I am. Several Indian tribes rose up against their Spanish overlords and drove them out of what is now called New Mexico.
Ten years later, the Spanish returned to reconquer the area. They were... brutal... I would use the word savage. They killed our people by the hundreds... maimed thousands more.
One of these killers was named Javier Maribona-Picard. Your ancestor.
I was... unaware of that incident... or of the man you named. But that was seven hundred years ago and I don't see how it has any bearing on --
That is why you have come to us: to erase a stain of blood that your family has worn for twenty-three generations.
Captain... are you all right?
We should return to the Enterprise.
Mister Worf... what's going on?
We have... unwelcome visitors.
I'm Captain Jean-Luc Picard of the Enterprise.
I am Gul Evek. What are these people still doing here? The evacuation should be well underway by now.
May I have a word with you... alone?
As you wish. Wait here.
It was my understanding that there would be no Cardassian presence on this world for another six weeks. Your arrival here may upset some very... delicate negotiations.
Negotiations? The status of this planet has been settled... what are you negotiating?
I would be happy to explain it to you... but for now, I must ask that you and your men leave... immediately.
We were sent here to make a preliminary survey of the buildings and equipment being left behind. I have no intention of leaving until our mission is complete.
Very well... complete your mission... But, this is still Federation territory, Gul Evek... until that changes, this world is under my jurisdiction... and I will protect it.
Is that a threat?
It is a fact... and I suggest you keep it in mind as you conduct your... survey.
This is the Habak... the focal point of our lives.
Strangers are not welcome here...
Wait a minute. When I asked to come here, you said it would be --
You are not a stranger. I told you, I've seen you here before.
What are those?
They are Mansara... dolls representing different spirits who come to this place.
This one looks like... a Klingon.
Yes. Our culture is rooted in the past, but it is not limited to the past. The spirits of Klingons, Vulcans, Ferengi come to us just as the bear, the coyote, the parrot. There is no difference.
What... should I do?
Start the fire... then sit... and wait.
What am I waiting for?
This is your journey, Wesley. I can open the door for you, but only you can go through it.
Is there any indication that the Tribal Council will change their position in the near future?
No, sir.
Then I see no other choice...

Admiral, I have every reason to believe that these people will resist any attempt to remove them. I strongly urge you to request an emergency session of the Federation Council. The issue of Dorvan Five must be reopened.
Captain... I made that request two days ago. The answer was no.
I'm sorry... but you have your orders. Starfleet out.
So much for a reprieve from Starfleet.
Anthwara believes that I am responsible for the crimes of one of my ancestors against his people...
Do you believe that?

No, of course not. I respect their beliefs... but that can't have any bearing on our mission. But at the same time... I wonder if a dark chapter in my family history is about to repeat itself. If these people take up arms against us... there's no way to foresee the consequences.
Picard to Worf. Will you come in here for a moment?
Aye, sir.
Mister Worf... begin preparations to remove the inhabitants from Dorvan Five.
Aye, sir.
Wesley... Wesley...
Wesley...
Dad...
You've reached the end, Wesley.
The end... the end of what?
This journey. The one you started a long time ago... when I left you and your mother.
You mean... when you died.
You set out on a journey that wasn't your own. Now it's time to find the path that is truly yours. Don't follow me any further.
I... don't understand.
I... don't understand.
Yes, you do. It's just hard for you to accept. Good-bye, Wesley. Good luck.
Dad -- wait!
Mister Crusher... Are you all right?
Yeah... I'm fine, Worf...
Lay out a confinement beam trace along the Southwestern edge of the village. Be discreet -- we do not wish to alarm the population.
What are you doing?
We are laying out Transporter coordinates for a security perimeter. It may become necessary to remove these people by force.
Worf... we can't do this. These people deserve better than to be taken from their homes...
I understand. But this is not the time or the place to --
Do you know what they're doing? They're preparing to beam you away -- to take you to their ship! You're not going to just let them do that, are you?
No, we won't. Leave. Now.

Inexcusable. You defied the orders of the ranking officer on the scene... put the entire Away Team in jeopardy... and made an already tense situation worse. Your actions reflect poorly on this ship and on that uniform. I want an explanation Mister Crusher, and I want it now.
What you're doing down there is wrong.
Captain, these people aren't just some random group of colonists... they're a unique culture... one that predates the Federation and Starfleet...
That does not change the fact that my orders are to --
I know Admiral Necheyev gave you an order and that she was given an order from the Federation Council... but it's still wrong.
That is not your decision to make, Cadet. Now, I don't know what's gotten into you lately, and right now I don't care.
But I will tell you this -- while you wear that uniform, you will obey every order you're given and you will conform to Starfleet regulations and rules of conduct. Is that clear?
Yes, it is. But I'm not going to wear this uniform anymore. I'm resigning from the Academy.
Riker to Captain.
Go ahead, Number One.
Gul Evek wants to meet with you to discuss the... situation on the surface.
Let him come aboard. I'll meet with him in here.
Aye, sir.
Why are you doing this?
I told you, Starfleet's not for me.
Dammit, Wesley.
I may not be able to stop you from throwing your entire life away, but you are going to stand here and explain it to me first. You owe me that much.
I saw Dad today. He told me not to follow him.
You... what?
I... was participating in an Indian ritual... I had a vision. And in it... Dad came to me. He told me not to follow him... that I had to find my own path.
Is that what this is all about? Some mystical vision told you to leave the Academy and now you're packing your bags?
It's more than that... I think I've known this was the right thing to do for a long time... I just couldn't admit it to myself.
But you always said being at the Academy was... the best thing that ever happened to you.
I know. And for a while it was. But as time went on... and graduation got closer... I started feeling... depressed. I thought it would go away... but it only got worse.
Why didn't you ever say anything?
I guess I didn't want to disappoint you... or Captain Picard... or my friends. You were all so... proud of me.
I'd be proud of you regardless of what you were doing, Wes. I love you no matter what.

I know that, Mom. Maybe the truth is that I was afraid of disappointing myself. I just never questioned the fact that someday I'd be in Starfleet. But when Dad said not to follow him, I just knew he was right. It seems... so clear now.
Maybe it's partly my fault... I never realized the kind of pressure we all must've put on you... to be exactly what we expected you to be...
I don't blame you, Mom. It was my decision -- it always has been.
You remember the alien from Tau Ceti who could control warp fields with his mind... ?
The Traveller.
He told Captain Picard a long time ago that you were... special -- like Mozart. That you were destined for something... different from the rest of us... Maybe... this is the first step...
What are you planning to do now?
Well, for the time being... I'm going to stay with these Indians.
Wes... you realize they won't be down there much longer. The Captain's orders are pretty explicit on that point.
I know. But I have to go back... even if it's just for a while.
I love you, Wes.
I love you, too.
You shouldn't be here, Wesley.
Why?
Bring them over here.
Why have you taken these men prisoner?
They were invading our homes... violating our privacy... this is not their world. They have no right to be here.
The terms of the treaty do give them the right to... survey this planet.
We don't recognize that treaty. We're not going to let the Cardassians have Dorvan Five. No matter what the cost.
That's right. We're not leaving. Get out of here! Go back to the Federation and leave us alone. This is our home. You're not wanted here. etc.
Worf to Picard. An armed group of Indians has taken two Cardassian prisoners. The situation is extremely volatile. Request instructions.
Stand-by, Mister Worf. Have your ship lock-on to your people and beam them out of there now, before something happens.
My people? What about these Indians of yours -- they've taken hostages. This planet is ours, Captain, and we will not be chased away by some unruly crowd.
Gul Evek to the Vetar.
This is Glin Telak aboard the Vetar. Go Ahead.
Two of our men on the surface have been taken prisoner. Prepare to send an armed squad to rescue them and to occupy the village.
Gul Evek, those people down there are Federation citizens and I am sworn to protect them. If your troops attack the village, my security forces will respond...
I hope you realize the consequences of Federation officers firing on Cardassian troops...
I do. That's why we need to stop this now, before it's too late.
I cannot allow you to hold these men as prisoners.
You have no authority here.
I don't understand...
You've found a new beginning for yourself... the first steps on a journey that few humans will ever take.
Who are you?
The Traveller...
I've been waiting a long time for this moment, Wesley.
So my experience in the Habak... my vision of my father... the things he said to me... those were all your doing?

I merely opened the door for you... what you experienced came from your own mind... your own spirit if you wish. I hoped that you would open your mind to new possibilities... (indicates scene around them) And you did. You pulled yourself out of time... don't you see?
You've evolved to a new level... you're ready to explore places where thought and energy combine in ways you cannot even imagine. I will be your guide... if you'd like.
What about them? I can't just leave them like this.
They must find their own destinies, Wesley. It is not our place to interfere.
But...
Have faith in their abilities to solve their problems on their own.
The Cardassian ship is powering its weapons and Transporters.
This is the Vetar to Gul Evek. Our troops are under attack. They are requesting immediate assistance. What are your orders?

Evek, the last war caused massive destruction... took millions of lives. Don't send our two peoples back down that path... not like this. History is in your hands -- right now. Give us one last chance for peace.
Gul Evek! What are your orders? Can we open fire?
Evek to the Vetar... lock on to our troops on the surface... and beam them aboard.
But sir, they have been fired upon and --
Those are my orders. Carry them out.
Yes, sir.
I had three sons, Captain. I lost two of them in the war. I don't want to lose the last one.
Beam up our Away Team immediately, Number One.
Aye, sir.

Anthwara... I want to make absolutely sure you understand the implications of this agreement. By giving up your status as Federation citizens... any future request you or your people make for assistance from Starfleet will go unanswered. You will be on your own... and under Cardassian jurisdiction.
I understand, Captain. And we are prepared to take that risk. Will the Cardassian government honor the agreement you've made here?

I believe that I can convince them this is an... equitable solution. I cannot speak for every Cardassian you will encounter... but if you leave us alone... I suspect that we will do the same. Will this be acceptable to Starfleet Command?
It will take some doing... but with Admiral Necheyev's support, I think they'll go along with it in the end.
Then if there is nothing else, I will return to my ship. I have a rather... long report to write. Captain... Anthwara...
I was right, Captain... you didn't take us from our land... and you have wiped clean a very old stain of blood.
Captain's Log: Stardate 47755.3. The Enterprise is preparing to leave Dorvan Five. But former cadet Wesley Crusher will be staying behind. It seems that during the crisis, he met... an old friend.
Where will you go?
The Traveller said that my... studies will begin with these people. He said they're... aware of many things... and that I could learn a lot from them. Just what I needed... more studying.
Somehow I think you'll manage.
Me too.
Well... good luck, Mister... ... good luck Wesley.
Thank you, sir. For a lot of things.
Remember to... dress warmly in those... other planes of existence.
I will. Good-bye, Mom.
Energize.

Most people on this colony will remember my grandmother as a "healer"... but her abilities went beyond that. She didn't just relieve pain, or fight illness... because she knew that well-being is more than a healthy body. Her remedies included words of advice as often as they did medicinal teas... And sometimes they were just as bitter-tasting.

But Nana's favorite thing was cooking. My most vivid memories growing up were of Nana in the kitchen... the sounds of bubbling pots and wooden spoons... the exotic tastes and smells... In fact, she was in the middle of writing a cook book when she died. I'd like to share with you one of her recipes... it was my favorite.

"Nana's Gingerbread. Mix one gram currants... six hundred milliliters of flour... two hundred milliliters buttermilk... and a dollop of molasses... " "Two pinches of ginger and cinnamon... and two hundred milliliters of sugar."
"Heat the oven until it's happy... then pour the batter into the arms of a welcoming pan... " I never knew when an oven was happy, and I never saw arms on a pan... but it sure tasted great.
I'll miss Felisa Howard very much... her healing... her advice... and most of all, her gingerbread.
"And so now we commit her body to the ground; earth to earth, ashes to ashes, dust to dust... in sure and certain hope that her memory will be kept alive within us all."
How long are you planning to stay?
Just a few more hours. Why?

Well, as I'm sure you know, Caldos was one of the first terraforming projects of the Federation. Some of our weather controls and fusion systems are nearly a century old. I wouldn't mind having a starship Engineer take a look at them... perhaps give us a few upgrades.
Maybe in exchange for a tour of the colony... and a home-cooked meal?
We're due at Starbase six-two-one tomorrow morning... but we can delay that for a few days. Yes... I'm sure we can find some time.
Excellent.
I look forward to that tour. The Caldos Colony is really an impressive accomplishment. I actually feel like I'm in the Scottish Highlands.

That was the intent. The cornerstone of every building in town was brought from Edinburgh.. Glasgow... Aberdeen... The founders wanted everyone to have a piece of the real thing here. They didn't just want to imitate Scotland -- they wanted to recreate it.
I'm curious, Governor... you're obviously not from Scotland. What drew you here?
There's something about the culture... the heritage. When I was a boy, my family visited Glamis Castle in Scotland. As I looked out across the highlands, I felt as if I'd come home.
I thought it was a beautiful eulogy, Beverly.
Thank you.
You know, I never realized how many friends Nana had...
Did you come home often?
Not really. After I married Jack and moved to Earth... I never seemed to get back here...
Deanna... did you notice a peculiar man at the service? He looked like he was in his midthirties... dark hair?
No...
He threw a flower on Nana's grave... a camellia... it was her favorite flower. She used to keep them all over the house.
Maybe he was a friend... or one of her patients.
Maybe. It was just such a personal gesture... and he gave me the oddest look...
Well... I suppose I should go back to the house. There are some things there I'd like to take care of. It's only a few minutes away. Would you mind coming along?
I'd love to.
Your grandmother had remarkable green eyes...
Every woman in the Howard family has had green eyes... except for my mother and me.
How well do you remember your mother?

Not very well... I was so young when she died. I just have the image of her face... and I can hear the sound of her voice, but I can't tell you anything specific she ever said... Mostly, I remember Nana.
That's beautiful... what is it?

A family heirloom... it's been in the Howard clan for at least twenty generations. It's supposed to symbolize the "enduring spirit of the Howards, wherever they may go -- a shining light to guide their fortune." Nana always kept it lit. I can remember sitting in here listening to ghost stories with only this candle burning...
You should take it with you...
I think I will.
Well... I'm going to head back to the ship.
You don't have to go.
Something tells me you'd like some time alone. I'll see you later.
Thanks.
Who's there?
What the hell are you doing?
Get out of my house.
I wouldn't get so high and mighty with me, Beverly Howard Crusher. I've spent more time here in the past five years than you have in the past twenty.
How do you know who I am?
I'm Ned Quint. I took care of your grandmother's house and her affairs.
Nana never mentioned you...
There's a lot of things she didn't tell you.
Now -- let me get rid of that candle.
What do you mean?
That candle has brought nothing but misery and bad luck to your grandmother.
Now listen, Mister Quint -- I don't know what your relationship was with my grandmother. But this is my house now and these are my things --
I'm telling ya -- that candle has been a curse on your family for generations. And if you had a lick of sense, you'd listen to me right now and do away with it. Now give it to me.
This is a family heirloom and I intend to keep it. I would like you to leave my house. Now.
Howard women... always the same stubborn fools... I wash my hands of it now. You stay in this house and keep that damned candle and I won't be responsible for what happens.
The colony's systems are functioning normally... as are the systems.
Can you check the seismic stabilizers? We've been having a few tremors over the past couple of months.
Certainly.
You can't imagine what it's like trying to enjoy afternoon tea while the earth is shaking.
Governor... did you know you had a power fluctuation in your weather control system?
No... our weather control's been working perfectly for over twenty-two years.
I can't isolate the exact source, but the fluctuation seems to be originating from one of the substations that regulates atmospheric humidity for the colony.
Is this going to be a problem?
Not yet... but power distribution patterns are already off by five percent.
I suggest we analyze the planet's weather patterns to see if they have been affected.

(continuing, off console) I am reading unusually high humidity across the entire Southern desert region... and there is increasing cloud activity over the Northern coastal area... possibly the formation of a storm system.
Storm? It's the middle of Summer -- we don't have rain at this time of year...
Data, let's see if we can correct this. I'll check out the colony's climatic flow array.
And I will run a diagnostic on the thermal regulators.
Don't worry, Governor. We'll keep you dry.
I certainly hope so. There's a caber toss scheduled for tomorrow afternoon... and I'd hate to see it spoiled by an unexpected downpour.
You wouldn't believe what I've been reading about in my grandmother's journals...
You know she had a lover? Can you believe it? Nana was a hundred years old.
It would seem the Howard women have exceptionally... vigorous libidos.
I certainly hope so. I'd like to think that I could find a young, handsome man in his thirties when I pass the century mark.
Thirties?

Yes. According to her journal, his name is Ronin... and he's thirty-four years-old. She met him just after my great-grandmother died. And I think I saw him at the funeral. He threw a camellia onto her grave. The strange thing is, Nana never mentioned him to me in her letters... never once. And they apparently spent almost all of their time together...
It's like she led a whole life I never knew about.
Well... it looks like we're going to be at Caldos for a few more days. This might give you a chance to get your grandmother's affairs in order.
Thank you. I will.
Beverly...
You dreamt you were in bed with someone?
Not exactly. I was in bed... but there wasn't another person in the dream... it was more like a presence...
You said you felt a touch...
A pair of hands. They were moving across my skin...
Like a caress?
