I would imagine that your self-discipline helps you in your work...
I don't know about that... I think maybe my biggest asset is patience.
I let everybody else talk until they're exhausted... then when I start, they're too tired to argue.
You're going to need all your patience at Seronia... I can't imagine how you'll get the two sides talking to each other...
Neither can I. I won't know that until I get there. I tend to feel my way through a situation...
Deck nine. If I were empathic, like you... I'd have a real advantage.
I thought Lumerians were empathic...
Only with each other, not other species. So... I don't have any idea what you might be feeling just now...
Curiosity... What I sense from you is very unusual. Serenity... calmness... tranquility... you seem to embody the very qualities you hope to draw out in others.
Tell me, Counselor... have you ever been involved in diplomatic negotiations?
Several times... with Captain Picard. There've been instances when having an empath along has been helpful.
I'm sure. I could use some of that help. Would you come with me when we reach Seronia?
If the Captain authorizes it, of course I will.
I hope to see you again.
You're late.
Mother, I told you I would be gone for over an hour...
You're late because of her.
Have you mated with him yet?
What --?
That's what you want, isn't it?
Mother, come in, please --
I can always tell. The ones with a certain look in their eye...
I'd better go...
I'll tell you this... if you do, you will regret it for the rest of your life...
Come on, Mother... you need to lie down...
I'll see you later...
Come in.
Hi. It's that time again...
The dreaded crew evaluation reports.
Does it have to be today?
It won't get any easier tomorrow.
It might...
What is it?
I've just had a very -- disturbing encounter with Alkar's mother. (beat, as her feelings emerge) Wil, she frightens me.
The feelings I sense from her are -- malevolent. They're out of proportion -- evil.
I understand she's been ill... and she's very old -- probably senile. Listen... we might all end up like that some day.
You're right. Okay, let's get through these evaluations. When they're done I'm going to reward myself with two pieces of fudge.
First, molecular biology. Lieutenant Jeffrey Fratis...
She's just a bitter old woman... don't give her the power to worry you.
You're right. Okay, let's get through these evaluations. When they're done I'm going to reward myself with a chocolate brownie.
Next, Physical Sciences. Lieutenant Jeffrey Fratis...
Worf to Commander Riker...
Go ahead.
Can you report to Ambassador Alkar's quarters? There's an emergency.
Forty cc's inoprovaline.
I'm sorry, Ambassador.
She was ill... I should never have brought her along...
Alkar...
She was ninety-three... she'd lived a long life... I should be grateful for that.
Counselor... there's a funeral meditation... part of our rituals... as an empath you're the only person on board who could perform it with me...
I'd be glad to help...
Captain...

quote: You wanted to see me, Doctor?
Yes... I'm sorry to bother you, Captain... but I'm a little concerned.
I haven't been able to determine the cause of death.
She was elderly... and Alkar said she had been ill...
I found no evidence of disease. But I did find abnormally high levels of neuro-transmitter residue in her cerebral cortex.
What are you suggesting -- ?
I don't know. I'd like to do an autopsy... but I've already spoken to Alkar. He tells me that Lumerian custom forbids it. Could you talk to him?
Do you have any reason to suspect her death poses some kind of threat to the Enterprise?
... Well, no.
Then I can't see any alternative but to comply with his wishes.
He tells me that Lumerian custom forbids autopsy except in cases where contagious disease might be involved. Could you talk to him?
We're in the middle of a delicate situation. I'd prefer not to go to him with this unless you feel it's absolutely necessary.
I might be able to find other ways to investigate. I'll try those first.
Deanna?
Hello...
Please, come in.
I thought you might like some company. Unless you're busy...
Nothing that can't wait. Would you like something to drink?
No.
I'd like you to talk to me.
About... ?
About you. I don't know anything about you. And... I'd like to.
There's not much to know. I live a simple life...
What kind of woman do you find attractive?
Do you find me attractive?
Extremely.
And... when you're attracted to someone... what do you usually do... ?
That depends... on a lot of things...
Is it really so complicated?
It can be.
Perhaps you overthink things...
Deanna...
I'm here...
I'm sorry. If I've led you to believe... (he stops, trying to find the way to say this) You are very beautiful... but our relationship can't be -- like that.
Deck four.
Wil...
We were going to finish the crew evaluation reports...
Of course, come in.
Sir!
As you were.
Yes, sir. Thank you, sir.
I was just leaving.
If there's anything else I need... I know where to find you.
Yes, ma'am.
Are you bothered by his being here?
Of course not.
Good. Because it's really none of your business.
I know that...
We were still with Lieutenant Fratis in molecular biology...
Why do I think you're upset?
I don't know. Could we just go over these evaluations?
Wil, remember who you're talking to... you are bothered, I can tell...
Look, Deanna, I'm sorry I intruded. When you're ready to work, why don't you let me know?
I will.

Captain's Log, Stardate 46073.6. We have arrived without incident at Seronia, where two members of Ambassador Alkar's delegation have been waiting. They have joined us to report on the situation in the capital city.
Things have deteriorated steadily. Rekag sympathizers in outlying districts have attacked several towns.
I was under the impression there was a cease fire agreement.
It was broken before it went into effect. A Rekag shuttle strayed into Seronian space and was destroyed by fighter craft.
Naturally the Rekags retaliated... there's been fighting ever since.
If they will just sit down with me...
The Rekags have refused to come to Seronian territory for talks. And the Seronians won't go to Rekag. In the meantime -- they fight.
Ambassador... the situation sounds volatile. Perhaps a cooling off period --
These people need an end to the fighting now -- to delay a week, or even a few days, could cost thousands of lives.
Then I recommend asking both sides if they will agree to meet at the coastal city of Darthen.
Why Darthen?
It has been neutral throughout the conflict. Both Seronians and Rekag loyalists live there. It might be acceptable as a compromise.
Contact the leaders. If they will meet in Darthen, I will join them there tomorrow.
No. I will not go with armed guards. I must be a man of peace before I can ask others for peace.
Very well.
Please send a message to the Rekag and Seronian leaders. I will join them tomorrow.
... I know it must be my imagination... but it seems as though Lieutenant Pinder just -- doesn't want me in his section.
Why do you think that?
He's so critical... I can't ever do anything to please him... and I try, Counselor, I try to make sure there's nothing he could find fault with...
Give me an example of what you mean.

Well, yesterday I was running routine diagnostics on the sensor pallets. They checked out... but Lieutenant Pinder questioned me because I'd allowed a point oh-two-three variance. That's well within specifications. He goes out of his way to criticize me.
Do you know of any reason why he might do that?
No... that's why I'm here.
Maybe he's tired of hearing you complain.
Pardon me... ?
I'm certainly tired of it. How do you think it feels to sit and listen to someone whine about themselves all the time?
I... didn't know I was --
This isn't Starfleet Academy. You aren't going to be coddled. If you can't take it here, you might think about a transport ship. There's a lot less pressure there.
I love being on the Enterprise... I don't want to be anywhere else...
But if you aren't up to it... you don't deserve to be here. Isn't that right?
I... guess so...
Then you'd better get hold of yourself. Or be prepared for a transfer.
I will, Counselor... thank you.
Glad I could help.
Here we go... Bio-filter log on Sev Maylor...
Geordi, could this log have been damaged in any way... ?
I doubt it. Why do you ask?
There's a discrepancy between the log... and the tricorder readings I took just three days later.
The tricorder shows massive physiological deterioration compared to her condition when she beamed aboard. It's hard to believe so much damage could have occurred in such a short time.
Well... I could run a diagnostic of the bio-filter system. And your tricorder.
Thanks. But the best way to get the information I need would be to do an autopsy.
Ambassador, we've received word from the Seronian and the Rekag leaders. Both sides have agreed to meet with you in Darthen tomorrow.
Counselor Troi has altered her appearance...
She certainly has...
Am I interrupting?
Hello, Counselor...
You want him... I can tell. But you have nothing to give him...
Deanna, could we talk in private...
And you're envious of him... you pretend to support him, but secretly you want him to fail...
That's not so...
Please, you must return to your quarters.
I won't -- I want to be here, with you --
Excuse me, Ambassador. The Counselor and I are needed on the Bridge.
Of course, Commander.
I don't know what you thought you were doing in there, but you were way out of line...
All right, Deanna... just what the hell is going on?
Imzadi... do you still care about me?
Of course I care about you. I'm worried about you... (gesturing to her attire) What is all this?
Don't you think I'm attractive?
This just isn't... you.
But it is. You want me, don't you?
Deanna...
I need you...
Hey -- what is this?
Please...
Come in...
Deanna... I'm leaving for the surface.
You said you'd take me with you...
I know... but that's not possible now --
You told me I'd be helpful... you needed me...
And I still do. You've done so much for me...
Then take me -- don't leave me here...
Tell me... is Liva going with you?
She's been on Seronia for weeks... she knows the people, the situation --
She wants to take you away from me...
Deanna... you are my anchor. I need you more than you can possibly realize. Do you understand that? I need you, here... making it possible for me to do my work.
I won't let her have you... I'll stop her...
I will go with you... don't leave me... please... Alkar... take me with you... don't do this...
You wouldn't have recognized her. Her dress... her hair... everything about her was...
I'm closer to Deanna than anyone I've ever known... But last night she was someone I'd never seen before.
Do you know of anything that might have caused her to act like that?
No. I've thought and thought about it. I don't have an answer.
Computer... location for Counselor Troi.
Deck six, corridor B.
Ambassador, we've just gotten word that the Rekags and Seronians are in disagreement about the seating arrangement at the conference table.
I'm not surprised.
The good news, however, is that the cease fire seems to be holding.
And that is by far more important... thank you, Captain.
Chief --
Will you take me with you?
Deanna, I've already told you--
Deanna... ?
I won't let her have you --
Security to Transporter Room Two.
No... let go...
It's just a superficial wound.
What's happened to Deanna... ?
I don't know... every system in her body has elevated readings... Take her to Sickbay.
Captain... perhaps we should delay transporting to the surface.
No... I think you must proceed with your mission.
Very well.
Chief, transport them to the surface.
Captain... I want you in Sickbay, too.
We'll have to sedate her. Give her twenty cc's of melorazine.

quote: Medical Log, Stardate 46075.1. I have performed an autopsy on Alkar's mother. But instead of answering our questions, the results have created an even deeper mystery.

I don't have any explanation for this, Captain... but when I examined Maylor's body... I found that her heart, her lungs, her skeletal structure... most of the systems in her body... were those of a thirty-year-old.
How could that be? We both saw the woman.
And that's not all. I compared Maylor and Alkar's DNA. I don't know who that woman was -- but she was definitely not his mother.
Deanna's condition is deteriorating rapidly. She could die. There are questions that only Alkar can answer.
Picard to Lieutenant Worf...
Here, sir.
Meet me in Transporter Room Two. We're going to the surface.
Aye, sir.
No, she wasn't my mother.
And she wasn't ninety-three years old.
Captain -- did you perform an autopsy against my wishes?
Yes, and for very good reason. Deanna Troi is in Sickbay dying. Doctor Crusher doesn't know the cause of her condition. But I believe you do.
Alkar... we need you. The Rekags have withdrawn some of their concessions... now the Seronians are threatening to break off the talks.
I'll be right there.
But --

They've been arguing for hours in there. It seems hopeless. But now -- when expectations are lowest -- is the moment I can be most effective. If I am focused... centered... free of disquieting thoughts... I can turn these factions toward peace.
I'm not particularly interested in your techniques as a mediator --

Hear me out, Captain. It's important that you understand. You see, I discovered long ago that I had the ability to channel my darker thoughts... my unwanted emotions... to others... leaving me unencumbered.
Is this... what you've done to Counselor Troi?
I didn't plan it. I expected Maylor to live through this negotiation. Her death could not have been more untimely.
Then... you deliberately began using Deanna...
She's an empath. I was reasonably certain I could establish a link with her. Frankly, I was amazed when I saw how quickly she was aging. Usually my receptacles survive for years.
Receptacles... ?

Come now, Captain -- surely you can see there is a broader canvas here. If I came to these peace talks hindered by unwanted emotions... the Rekags and Seronians would be condemned to go on fighting...
No, Alkar... you can't explain away a wantonly immoral act just because you think it's connected to some higher purpose.
Do you know how many people have died on this planet in the last forty eight hours? Thousands. Deanna Troi is one individual.
And you think that justifies brutalizing her? And the others you've used?
Ask the Seronian and Rekag children who go to sleep every night in fear of their lives.
Captain... I get no payment for what I do. I have no power base, no agenda. I am willing to risk my life simply to help others.
If you think you appear courageous, you're mistaken. You're a coward. You exploit the innocent so you don't have to shoulder the burden of unpleasant emotions.
This time you will be held accountable. I'm taking you back to the Enterprise to release Counselor Troi.
I have no intention of releasing her. Now -- or ever.
Alkar... everything's falling apart. You have to come now.
Excuse me, Captain. I am needed.
You and your Security Chief will leave.
Lock on to Alkar's signal and bring him aboard.
Sir, I am sure the Seronians have reactivated their security field.
Then work with Mister La Forge to find a way to break through it. I want that man on this ship.
Aye, sir.
I'll be in Sickbay.
If Alkar is flooding her with this... psychic waste... that would explain the high level of neuro-transmitters.
All the negative emotions pouring into her have caused an abnormal chemical response in her brain...
Isn't there something you can do to counteract it?
Enzymic decontaminants will reduce the level of the neuro-transmitters -- but I can't make any headway unless Alkar stops what he's doing.
He has no intention of stopping. He feels perfectly justified in using her until she dies.
Then Deanna has to die.
The only way to save her is to break the link with Alkar. And that will only happen if she's no longer an adequate receptacle.
When Maylor died, Alkar immediately turned to Deanna.
If he thinks Deanna is dead... he'll break the link and turn to someone else -- probably one of his delegation.
Wait a minute... you're talking about... about killing Deanna...

I'll be able to resuscitate her, Wil... as long as it's not more than thirty minutes... the question is -- will that be enough time? Unless he establishes a link with someone else before we revive Deanna he might turn back to her.
We must also keep in mind that we're putting his next victim at risk... I'll want every possible security measure taken to protect that person.
How... will you...
I'll give her a hypospray of dylamadon. It's the most gentle way...
Proceed, Doctor.
Well, my friend, an era of conflict and bloodshed appears to be over...
Alkar...
What is it...
I... I'm fine... just a little light-headed.
You're exhausted.
Do you want a doctor?
No... of course not...
Enterprise to Ambassador Alkar. Respond, sir.
I'm here, Captain...
You must return to the Enterprise immediately. Counselor Troi is dying. We are prepared to transport you from the surface whether you come willingly or not.
There are security force fields protecting us, Captain --
They won't protect you any longer. Transporter Room Two, prepare to energize --
We're ready, Captain.
Computer, note in the log that death occurred at fourteen thirty hours... due to respiratory and renal failure.
Will you wait for me in my quarters?
Of course.
It is a tragic loss. But her death had a purpose.
I intend to make certain that you answer for what you have done.
Your own Federation Council has granted me safe and timely passage to my planet. I expect you to honor that.
How much longer do we have?
Three minutes, forty seconds...
Picard to Transporter Room Two... lock on to the young woman in Ambassador Alkar's quarters... stand by to transport her out of there.
Mister Worf, station yourself outside the quarters.
Aye, sir.
She'd helped me so much... without her, I couldn't have accomplished what I did...
I'm so sorry... Is there anything I can do...
Yes, there is something...
If we could share the funeral meditation...
We have a minute and a half left... Prepare a hypospray of cordrazine.
Yes, Doctor.
We'll use that in conjunction with the cortical stimulator...
Rohm gah... sevi rohm... rohm gah...
Rohm gah... sevi rohm... rohm gah...
We can't wait any longer. Release the stasis field. Ten cc's of cordrazine.
Yes, doctor.
Cortical stimulator...
Now.
... an end to pain...
... an end to pain...
Again.
She has a pulse... blood pressure climbing... ninety over forty.
All right... let's neutralize the neuro-transmitters. Initiate the decontamination sequence...
Levels are dropping, Doctor... down to four hundred twenty percent above normal... three hundred eighty percent...
Picard to Transporter Room Three...
Not yet. I won't know for certain that it's working until we get her below three hundred percent.
... and courage from wisdom...
Alkar... what's wrong?
Neuro-transmitter levels are down to three hundred ten -- three hundred percent.
Picard to Transporter Room Three. Energize.
Let me go!
Neuro transmitter level at two hundred thirty percent...
Worf to Captain Picard. Ambassador Alkar is dead.
Wil...
Doctor Crusher thinks he must have been at a susceptible point in the meditation ceremony... when he was somehow vulnerable.
Then the flow of negative emotions and feelings was reversed somehow -- and went back to him.
That's our guess. And like a man with no immune system... he just couldn't handle the sudden overload...
And... Liva?
She seems to be fine. He never got to the point where he could establish a link with her.
When I think back on the last few days... it's as though I'm looking at a Holodeck projection... of someone else.
That's kind of how it seemed to the rest of us...
Thanks for sticking by me.
I always will. Even when you're old and grey.
Captain's Log, Stardate 44502.7. Early completion of our mission at Harrakis Five has allowed me to grant extra personal time for many of the crew.
Given our recent tight scheduling, this has come as something of a relief.
Our diplomatic assignment in the Evadne system is a ten day journey past the Ngame Nebula, and I expect it to be uneventful. I personally am using the time to fulfill a promise to a colleague.
Dixon Hill around?
He's occupied at the present moment.
Tell him Gloria is here.
Can't do that.
He doesn't want to be disturbed.
I'm here from... Cleveland.
Doesn't matter if you're from the moon, Hon. Mister Hill is incommuni... incommunica...
Incommunicado.
That's it. Sorry, Hon.
Listen, Hon. Just tell him Gloria's here.
When the boss doesn't want to be disturbed, the boss doesn't want to be disturbed. Don't take it personal like.
Mister Hill is expecting me. I have a two o'clock appointment.
It's two-ten.
Sorry. I had a hard time with the outfit... (raising her skirt to show off a garter) It took me awhile to figure out what this thing was supposed to do...
Sorry, Dix. There's a... "lady" here to see you, says her name is...
Gloria...
Gloria...
From Cleveland.
From Cleveland. Okay.
He never heard of you.
Never heard of me?
That's right.

No, you don't understand... it's all been set up in advance... I'm supposed to be Gloria from Cleveland and I was supposed to be in Holodeck Four at two o'clock and you don't have the slightest idea of what I'm talking about, do you?
Hey, you can't go in there...
Get inside. Who's the doll?
She's my cousin.
Gloria. From Cleveland.
Sorry, Gloria -- I didn't want to get you involved. She has nothing to do with this, Johnny.
Yeah, right. What do I look like? A jamoke? You ain't nobody's cousin and you ain't here for a visit. What do you know about my money?
Your money?
The money he stole.
You stole his money?
He's lying, Gloria -- don't listen to him.
Johnny, why don't you tell me all about it, maybe I can help, I'm a good listener...
I'm finished with talking, sweetheart. Now, I'm gonna get some action or else...
This is what you do for fun?
It's a mystery, Guinan... Who was this man? Who killed him? Where's the money he was talking about? A mystery. Now, we begin the search for clues.
And that's fun...
That's fun.
A forty-eight Packard with whitewalls... I couldn't catch the license plate...
Dixon Hill, Private Investigations. Sorry, there's no Captain Picard here. Try down at the docks.
It's all right. I'll take it, Madeline.
What is it?
Please excuse the unusual interruption, Captain. I thought that patching communications through the holodeck program would be less obtrusive.
I appreciate the consideration, Commander. What can I do for you?
Long range sensors have detected a T-tauri type star within a pocket of the Ngame cloud.
Nothing unusual about that.
No, Sir. However, the star's single planet falls within the M-Class range. It is capable of supporting life.
Now that is unusual.
Highly, Sir.
Yes, thank you, Data. Procedures require us to investigate. Recall the bridge crew and set a course.
I'm afraid I have a twenty-fourth century mystery to deal with, Gloria. You're welcome to carry on if you'd like.
No, I've had enough "fun" for one day.
Entering the T-tauri system, now, Captain.
Sensors indicate an energy fluctuation directly in our path. Source unknown.
Still picking up energy distortions -- but fading. It seems to be gone.
A wormhole?
Very likely. Small and extremely unstable wormholes have been mapped near thirty-nine T-tauri systems in the last one hundred years alone.
Captain, I suggest we move to a safer location. It could reappear at any moment.
Agreed. Ensign, take us --
-- Captain!
Captain?
scene: 21   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - CLOSE SHOT OF PICARD

quote: Data?
scene: 21   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - CLOSE SHOT OF PICARD

quote: Careful, Captain. The stun-effect from the wormhole was relatively severe.
scene: 21   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - CLOSE SHOT OF PICARD

quote: Apparently so. How long were we unconscious?
scene: 21   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - CLOSE SHOT OF PICARD

quote: Approximately thirty seconds. I have scanned the ship and detected no life-threatening injuries to the crew.
scene: 21   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - CLOSE SHOT OF PICARD

quote: You were not affected?
scene: 21   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - CLOSE SHOT OF PICARD

quote: No. My positronic system is immune to the effect. This is the third unstable wormhole I have passed through during my time in Starfleet. The first, on-board the U.S.S. Trieste --
scene: 21   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - CLOSE SHOT OF PICARD

quote: -- Thank you, Data.
scene: 21   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - CLOSE SHOT OF PICARD

quote: Well, where the hell are we?
scene: 21   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - CLOSE SHOT OF PICARD

quote: Point five-four parsecs from our previous position. Almost a day's travel... in just thirty seconds.
scene: 21   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - CLOSE SHOT OF PICARD

quote: Sir, I should re-align the ship's clock with Starbase Four-ten's subspace signal to adjust for the time distortion.
scene: 21   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - CLOSE SHOT OF PICARD

quote: Proceed.
scene: 21   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - CLOSE SHOT OF PICARD

quote: Captain, Sickbay here.
scene: 21   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - CLOSE SHOT OF PICARD

quote: Go ahead, Doctor.
scene: 21   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - CLOSE SHOT OF PICARD

quote: I'm getting scattered reports of minor injuries. What happened?
The Enterprise just jumped through a wormhole.
We were all unconscious for about thirty seconds.
Everybody okay up there?
Little or no damage on the Bridge, Doctor.
Acknowledged. Crusher out.
Ship's status?
Reports coming in now. Nothing serious so far.
Impulse engines and warp drive are unaffected, Captain.
Shields and weapons systems are fully functional.
Counselor? Are you alright?
Yes... I think so... Excuse me, Captain, but I feel a bit... unfocused... It will pass.
Not too bad, all things considered.
We're lucky we didn't end up half-way across the galaxy and in the middle of next week.
I do not believe that was ever a possibility. The wormhole's small size and extremely short period indicate a relatively local phenomenon.
I didn't mean that literally, Data.
There's still the anomalous M-Class planet we were going to investigate. Do we go back?
The unpredictability of the wormhole would make our investigation a hazardous one. A probe from our current position would be more advisable.
Make it so.
Nothing broken, Chief. But the ligaments around the elbow have been twisted pretty severely. What in the world were you doing when you fell?
Hanging a plant for Keiko. Part of her running project to give me a green thumb.
How's it working?
Everything I touch seems to turn brown and wither away.
Alyssa, would you get me the --
-- Never mind. I'll do it. You, don't go away. We'll fix that right up.
This is impossible.
Straighten your arm.
Alyssa?
Yes, Doctor?
Did you see anybody near the lab today?
No, I didn't.
You didn't happen to adjust the environments on the incubation containers?
I would never touch one of your experiments unless you asked me to, Doctor.
Of course, I'm sorry, Alyssa.
Probe approaching the T-tauri system, Captain.
Readings, Data?
Coming in now, sir. The probe has moved within visual range of the planet.
On screen.
Sensors indicate a hydrogen-helium composition. With a frozen helium core.
Wait a minute, didn't your readings indicate a Class M planet before we went through the wormhole, Data?
It is very possible that interference from the wormhole affected the sensors, Commander. This is clearly not a Class M planet.
Data, run a full diagnostic to make sure the wormhole didn't cause any permanent damage to the sensors.
Aye, Captain.
Ensign, set us back on a course for... Number One? A problem?
It's awfully strange that a malfunctioning sensor should give such a specific misreading of a planet. I would have thought that a space/time disturbance would cause a lot more confusion than that.

It is conceivable that the sensors picked up the afterimage of an actual planet that lies on the other side of the wormhole. We could survey the nearby stars for such a planet. It would require approximately six weeks.
We don't have the time.
We've encountered a minor mystery, one that has been solved to my satisfaction. Number One, unless there's a major objection, Ensign McKnight will set us a course for Evadne Four.
No objection.
Ensign.
You wanted to see me, Beverly.
I have something of a minor mystery on my hands.
A "minor mystery"? That seems to be a recurring phrase around here lately. Please.
Diomedian scarlet moss. I didn't know you were an enthno-botanist.
It's a hobby.
You've got a good crop going there. As I recall, it's not easy to cultivate.
That's just it -- I started the spores right before we were all knocked unconscious by the wormhole. You said we were out for thirty seconds?
Correct.
Then how come this shows a full day's growth?
Perhaps you've got some sort of fast-growth strain.

Each of these incubators were set with spores from completely different sources in the Diomedian system. I've got a dozen more back at the lab. Perhaps something extraordinary could have happened to one of them, but not to all of them.
But that would mean we were unconscious for a full day. And yet everything else on board indicates that we were out for only thirty seconds. The ship's chronometer, the computer...
Everything else... including Commander Data.
Captain's log, supplemental. Commander Data continues to maintain that we were unconscious for only thirty seconds, despite Doctor Crusher's evidence to the contrary.
Captain, I have a hypothesis.
The twenty-second century physicist Pell Underhill conjectured that a major disruption in time-continuity could be compensated for by trillions of counter reactions.
The effect could have allowed Doctor Crusher's mosses to arrive at the other side of the worm hole with the unanticipated growth.
Underhill was talking about energy!
True. Nevertheless, it is possible that the phenomenon could occur in matter at much higher levels of organization. Given the proper conditions.
Thank you, Data. An intriguing hypothesis.
Perhaps we've got a tempest in a test tube, after all.
Captain --
Data, I promised Mister Nelson in Engineering that you would assist him on the sensor diagnostics. You'll find him hard at work on Deck Thirty-six.
As you wish, Captain.
Did you believe Data's explanation?
A frank answer, Commander.
Not for a second. I'm honestly amazed that he even proposed it.
What are you suggesting, Captain?
I'm not sure. I have never known Data to lie, and yet...
If we never went through a wormhole... then what happened to us during that missing day...
If we were out for a whole day, why didn't our beards grow?
Whatever it was... it seems to be something Data doesn't want to tell us about...
It could be that whatever caused this situation affected Data as well. Or it could be that he's telling the truth... and this is just... another minor mystery.
I can check the computer's chronometer... see if there's evidence of tampering...
A transporter trace analysis might give us another indication of how much time has actually passed.
Proceed on both counts. Meanwhile, we'll maintain our present course. If there is something wrong with Data, we don't want him aware of our suspicions.
Gentlemen, how goes the battle?
The long-range, infra-red sensors suffered no apparent damage as a result of the wormhole. We are presently checking the neutrino and heavy particle detectors.
Great. I'll take over, Data. The Captain wants you back on the Bridge.
See you later in Ten Forward.
Yes. I will see you then.
Nelson, I need your help with the computer.
Hello, Chief. How's the elbow?
Much better. This isn't a house call, is it?
No, it's not. Tell me, who was the last one to use the transporter before we went through the wormhole?
Ensign Locklin. She's one of my technicians.
Have her report immediately to Sickbay.
Electrolyte concentration.
Twelve point five deviation from previous.
Interesting... Let's check the cellular membrane. I'm willing to bet the internal turgor pressure is off by almost the same amount.
Eleven three deviation from the norm.
That's what I wanted to hear. Thank you, Ensign Locklin. That'll be all.
Crusher to Captain Picard.
What is it, Doctor?
I need to see you immediately.
I'm on my way to Engineering. Join me.
Physiologically, each of us is on a daily cycle. Our cells have developed rhythms based on a twenty-four hour period.
Our internal clocks.

Exactly, and I can measure that effect at the molecular level. I took a trace from the last person to use the transporter, and compared her cell function levels to what they are right now. If we were unconscious for only thirty seconds, those cycles would be nearly synchronous.
And were they?
No. We were out for longer than thirty seconds, Captain. A lot longer.
I've got some good news, and some bad news...

The good news is that we were right about the computer's chronometer. There's a security program to prevent tampering. But it looks now like it was disabled, and a new program put in its place. Someone reset the clock.
And the bad news?
Data and I are the only ones onboard this ship capable of doing it.
A bit of a mystery, Captain.
That's an understatement. Is it possible that something or someone affected you -- without your knowledge?
I am unable to answer that question, Captain.
Data, would you consent to being examined by Commander La Forge?
As you wish, Captain.
Come.
Please escort Commander Data to Engineering.
I know the way, Sir.

Captain's log, supplemental. It has become clear that everyone aboard the Enterprise has lost an entire day. As the mystery of what actually occurred during those missing hours continues to deepen, so do my doubts about Commander Data.
We'll start with the higher functions before we get down to basics.
Now, this won't hurt a bit...
Have you forgotten that my sensory inputs are not programmed to experience pain, Geordi?
It's a figure of speech. Bedside manner. I was just trying to make you comfortable.
I am perfectly comfortable.
Pattern recognition, syntactic algorithms, heuristic functions -- all normal.
However, I cannot help noticing that you appear a bit uncomfortable yourself.
I just don't like having to do this, that's all...
The Captain has expressed doubts about my operational capacities. Doubts which, given the circumstances, seem entirely justified. I do not understand your reluctance to carry out his instructions.
It's not reluctance exactly... more like concern. I don't want to find something wrong with you. On the other hand...
Yes?
It feels like you're not being completely... honest with us. Data, I'm your freind... if something is wrong, tell me... maybe I can help you...
There is nothing I can tell you, Geordi, beyond what I have already stated.
Okay.
Okay...
I've finished examining Data, Captain.
And?
Nothing's wrong with the technology that I can see. He's in perfect condition.
I was almost hoping you'd find a problem.
He could still be malfunctioning beyond my ability to detect it.
This entire mystery began when our sensors detected that planet. First it was class "M"... now it isn't...
But the sensors were malfunctioning. Our probe clearly established the planet could not support life...
Data launched that probe.
If he rigged the probe, could you prove it?
I could try.
What happened to us in that missing day? Surely clues must exist. Each of you think back to what you were doing right before we blacked out. Reenact it if need be. Look for anything odd or --
-- Counselor!
Deanna, are you alright?
Just a moment... Yes... I'm fine...
What happened?
I suddenly became dizzy... I'd better go to my quarters.
Perhaps Sickbay would be a better idea.
No. Really, I'm alright.
See the counselor to her quarters.
Aye, Captain.
Thank you for coming with me, Worf.
Of course. You're certain you are well.
I just need some rest.
Counselor!
Security! Override the lock on Deanna Troi's quarters! Now!
What's wrong?
The mirror... I came in here... and I looked into the mirror... It wasn't me, Worf... Not me... It was my face, but it wasn't me inside...
Is she alright?
I feel fine...now.
Signs of stress, adrenaline by-products higher than baseline. But that's a normal reaction to sudden fright. All brain functions check out okay.
Deanna, what happened?
A hallucination perhaps.
What did you see?
It wasn't what I saw. It was what I felt. I looked into the mirror, and it seemed a stranger was staring back at me from behind my own eyes.
As if my own face was a mask.
La Forge to Captain Picard.
Yes, Geordi.
I found something, sir.
Hello, Worf.
Doctor.
Can I help you?
Perhaps not.
-- Worf.
You came in here for something. You can trust me.
A warrior does not complain about physical discomfort.
Are you in pain?
But the Captain ordered us to report anything out of the ordinary.
How did this happen?
Do you recognize the planet, Data?
Yes, it is the planet our probe detected in the T-tauri system.
No it's not. Actually, it's Tethys Three. I retrieved the image from the ship's library. The geophysical figures have been slightly altered, but it's definitely Tethys Three.
Strange that an obscure planet several hundred light years from here should be picked up by our probe.
Data, did you take this image from the ship's library and then program the probe to send it back to us?
I cannot verify that hypothesis.
But you don't deny it.
No, Sir.
Geordi, send another probe to the T-tauri system.
Yes, Sir. Sorry, Data.
Counselor Troi just had a very disturbing hallucination.
Is she alright?
For the moment. Can you tell me if Deanna's incident is in any way related to the missing time period?
No, Sir. I cannot.
Data! You're the key to this entire mystery. And you've done nothing but block my attempts to solve it. Why are you fighting me?
It is not by choice.
What does that mean?
I cannot say.
